Location: 120  sea miles east of Lianyungang Port
SummaryOfEvents: Two sailors died, three were rescued and an additional 15 crew members remain missing after the M/V KANG BONG sank on Friday 31 December in the Yellow Sea. The 69-meter-long general cargo KANG BONG sank 120 sea miles east of Lianyungang Port, east China's Jiangsu Province, on early Friday morning after water enter the ship amid strong gales.  A rescue ship, EAST CHINA SEA R 111 and two helicopters rescued three sailors, two bodies were recovered and fifteen were assumed lost. The Gale force winds made the rescue work difficult.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: In the area of Puerto Coquira
SummaryOfEvents: On December 30, the passenger boat NINA KEYSI sank off Panama's Pacific coast, in the area of Puerto Coquira. The incident took place about 80 km east of Panama city, when the motor of the NINA KEYSI got caught up with the rope of another boat's anchor. Nine of the 14 people aboard swam to the closest beach and survived. Three people died and two others were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

InitialEvent: Accidents due to heavy weather conditions
SummaryOfEvents: The oil tanker AEGEAN ANGEL was on voyage from Tallinn to Houston when heavy weather struck the vessel about 180 miles North-East of Bermuda. As the vessel encountered heavy weather, the Captain, the Chief engineer and others had gone forward to check for damage. While they were forward, a heavy wave broke on deck, the seamen were struck by the water and knocked down. The Master and Chief engineer died immediately, the first officer was injured. The US Coast Guard picked him up by helicopter and took him to Bermuda for further treatment.  At appoximately 0940, on Sunday the helicopter crew transferred the new crew members to the AEGAN ANGEL. The vessel sustained only minor damage.

The stern trawler BAHIA DE PORTOSANTO took water, developped list and sank in the Atlantic Ocean, 27 miles Southwest of Cape Silleiro, Vigo, Spain on 28 December 2010. The tug MARIA PITA and MV SLOMAN TRAVELLER proceeded to the scene.  All 10 crew were rescued by helicopters and take to Vigo and La Coruna.  No injuries were reported.  BAHIA DE PORTOSANTO sank while under two of FV PORTOSANTO.

On 28 December 2010, at 0258 hrs, the cargo ship VAN DON 02 foundered in the South China Sea, 250 miles SW of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.  Eleven crew members were rescued by fishing boats KG 91371TS and KG 91907TS; 2 members sustained serious injuries and another injured member was rescued by fishing boat BD 95690. Eleven crew members were reported still missing.  Survivors were transferred to the rescue ship SAR 413 and taken to hospital at the nearest port.

The M/V VAN DON 02, transporting material for making iron, sunk in high winds in the South China Sea, 250 miles off Ba Ria Vung Tau province of Vietnam. 12 crewmembers were saved by two local fishing vessels, including two seriously injured, but 11 were missing. The vessel, was heading from Malaysia to HCM City when it ran into trouble and sank.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: COSCO NAGOYA: SOLAS, SHANDONG JIAOZHOU: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Fully cellular containership COSCO NAGOYA collided with SHANDONG JIAOZHOU fishing vessel in the tidal waters of Liandao on December 28, resulting in the sinking of the fishing vessel. The sea rescue centre in Qingdao conducted a full search and rescued five crewmen but one is still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 27/12/2010 at around 0130 hrs LT, AB, X saw 5/E, X last onboard when he was leaving the crew mess room through the door which leads to the Alleyway of A-Dk when the position of the vessel at 0130 hrs was 22 21 S 40 48 W. The officer was in drunken state but was able to walk and speak and apparently looking in his sense. His Cigarette lighter was found at port Gangway. Suspect that near to port gangway, he leaned over on railing, probably to vomit and then went overboard. At around 0420 hrs when 5/E did not come on his watch, C/O informed the Master that 5/E was missing. 0445 alarm was raised and all crew mustered at the crew mess room. Head count taken and all crew started search on main deck, accommodation. Engine Room, Funnel, Life boat etc. No trace of 5/E found, search stopped at 0630 hrs. MRCC Brazil was informed. Unfortunate1y despite extended search by the ship assisted by up to 6 other vessels and Brazilian Navy He1icopter and Naval Ship 5/E, Balaji Mani was not found. As advised by the MRCC’  the search operation was completed at 1930hrs (L T) on 28th December and the vessel was advised to proceed to her next port Vitoria.

The passenger ro-ro ship "HANGRO FERRY" developed list, took water, capsized and sank in the Yellow sea, 17 miles Southeast of Manjae island, Mokpo, South Korea at 0915 Hours on 26/12/2010 in heavy weather. All 12 passengers and 3 crew members were rescued by coastguard vessels. No injuries were reported.

On 24 December at approximately 1950, the general cargo EREN TURGUT has lost all power and was anchored in lat 51 11.7N, long 001 46.8E. The vessel first reported problem at 16.33, UTC, and estimated that it would take until 2100 to fix it. Three crewmembers airlifted off vessel with smoke inhalation. The M/V EREN TURGUT had been towed to Rotterdam by tug FIELD EXPRESS. One of the crew died and two had burns and were placed in a specialised burns unit.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The bulk carrier "HUNG CUONG 168" sustained mechanical failure, capsized and sank in east China Sea, 20 miles East of Mawei, China at 1552 hours on 24/12/2010 in heavy weather. SAR operation conducted by ships and helicopters, 14 crew were rescued by the tug "DONG HAI JIU 113" and M/V "CAO AN 628". 2 crew members were missing and 1 dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

ShipsInvolved: CMA CGM LAPEROUSE (-), CMA CGM LAPEROUSE (IMO 9454412), THEBE (IMO 9199696), THEBE. (-)
SOLASStatus: CMA CGM LAPEROUSE: Unknown/unspecified, CMA CGM LAPEROUSE: Unknown/unspecified, THEBE: Unknown/unspecified, THEBE.: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 23 December 2010, the container carrier CMA CGM Laperouse sailed from Le Havre bound to Hamburg.

At the end of the afternoon, as she was within the off Vlieland TSS, off the Netherlands, she was overtaking two ships among which Thebe a ballasted coaster heading from Termeuzen to Hamburg.
During her overtaking manoeuvre, CMA CGM Laperouse collided with Thebe port stern with her bulb, then more on the bow with her starboard stern. There were no wounded nor pollution.

Both ships have had hull damages but remained manoeuvrable. Thebes went to Den Helder harbour and CMA CGM Laperouse continued to run to Hamburg , with Den Helder MRCC agreement. 

Up to today, despite several requests from Beamer, no information had been transmitted by the shipping company operating Thebe.

On December 23, 2010, at approximately 1000hr/LT, the Liberian flagged cargo vessel, MCP ALTONA was transiting in the North Pacific Ocean from Vancouver, Canada to Zhanjiang, China when she encountered extremely inclement weather conditions.  There were gale force winds with high seas and swell; in order to maneuver the MCP ALTONA safely during these dangerous conditions, the vessel reduced speed and maintained a variable course. Sea water covered the main deck, hatch covers, and vessel cargo. When the weather subsided, the crew carried out an inspection of the vessel; they noted that the some container cargo had fallen down in Hold No. 1 and leaked. The cargo in question was drums containing International Maritime Dangerous Goods (IMDG) Code Category 7 (Triuranium octoxide). The contamination area was sealed until specially equipped teams could contain and clean up the triuranium octoxide.  There was some minor hull damage and no injuries to the crew or environmental pollution reported.

The M/V WILSON MERSIN was moored at Antwerp on January 12 at 15.36. The M/V WILSON MERSIN suffered a leak of poisonous gas into its cabin on December 23 and was detained at Antwerp since two sailors were intoxicated by gas that was used to protect the cargo of grain. One sailor died on board. The maritime police investigated and prosecutors detained the ship, and for safety reasons the crew was evacuated.

MV “JIA FU STAR” sailed from Panaji, Mormugao Port Trust, and Goa on 15th December 2010 to Singapore with a cargo of iron ore fine in bulk 167,870 MT.

On 17th December 2010, while the 2nd Engineer,  was having his dinner and chatting with other crew in the crew mess room, he noticed the oiler though the large clear view window, walking out onto the boat deck and walking passed the railing which was not chained up. The 2nd engineer also saw that the oiler was carrying a waste paper basket with him.

As the vessel was underway and making way, 2nd engineer rushed out of the crew mess room to warn the oiler on the dangers, but as he came out to the boat deck, there was no sight of the oiler anywhere. The 2nd engineer then rushed to the ship’s rails and saw the oiler in the water. The 2nd Engineer then threw the nearest life buoy to him and shout “X overboard…..” a few times.

On hearing the cries from the mess room. the  engine cadet and the  Bosun, immediately notified the bridge and engine room via telephone. Followed by the deck fitter, the Oiler Cook and, able bodied ran to the ship’s stern to keep an eye on the oiler. At this time, Master and Chief Engineer who were on their routing walk on forward port quarter deck, when they saw some commotion at the stern area and they rushed to stern to where the commotion was taking place. 

Upon knowing the situation, Master ran up to the bridge to take over command from the chief officer who was at this time executing the Williamson turn to port ( side where the crew fell overboard). The captain ordered for additional lookout to be posted. Chief Engineer then went down to the engine room to put the engine on emergency manoeuvre.

The Master assess the situation and he noted the position of the vessel and then broadcast “PAN PAN” on vessel’s VHF followed by a Search and rescue operation.

After a search & rescue operation running for over 50 hours, the missing crew could not be traced. The Master took all considerations and consultation with their Management office, before terminating the search and resumed passage to its original destination to Singapore.

On 23rd December 2010, Panama Authority was informed that the vessel is sailing to Cao Fei Ding, China and not stopping in Singapore.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Durante el embarco de prácticos de canales, desde una lancha de embarco de prácticos a la nave "Seri Bijaksana" de bandera de Malasia, la cual navegaba con velocidad reducida para facilitar la maniobra de embarco, el segundo práctico que subía por la escala de prácticos, al llegar a la plataforma de la escala real, se golpeó la cabeza, se soltó de la escala y cayo sobre la lancha "Choique", que lo transportaba. La caída a desnivel se produjo desde una altura de 2.5 metros y resultó en heridas cortantes en la cabeza del práctico, quien debió ser trasladado a un centro hospitalario. Se recuperó y volvió a realizar actividades profesionales de practicaje.

On 17 December 2010, at 0630 hrs, the cargo ship, TIO sustained engine failure at Kumluova Cavurali Bay, Turkey.  Tug ANTAK effected the tow to safe achorage at Fethiye, Turkey for inspection and repairs.  On 24 February 2011, TIO arrived at ALIAGA, Turkey for breaking up.
The general cargo ship "IBRAHIM Y" stranded after dragging anchor off Tarkhankut point, Ukraine on 17/12/2010 in heavy weather. All 15 crew were rescued. No injuries or pollution were reported.
The M/V PHU TAN sank on December 16 off Quang Binh province in stormy seas. 27 crewmembers were missing
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 15 December 2010, at 1215 hrs, the fishing carrier, REFRIGERATOR-604 stranded on rocks, whilst entering Malo-Kurilsk, Shikotan, Russia.  The carrier sustained damage to ballast tanks, No.'s 2 and 4 and took water in the engine room and holds, No.'s 3 and 4.  No injuries or pollution were reported.  All 14 crew members were rescued by fishing boats DANILOVO and GRINDA and taken to Malo-Kurilsk.  The tug RUBIN assisted with the salvage operations; cargo was lightered using the crane barge; all bunkers and pollutants were removed by salvors.  Further salvage attempts were abandoned due to the severity of the damage and subsequently the wreck was left in its location.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: Vessel type tug sunk at 12:30 local time, 14/12/2010. Sailing from San Lorenzo, Honduras to Balboa, Panama. Five persons onboard. No casualties, tug lost. Persons rescued by container vessel Ulf Ritcher and for Costa Rican Coast Guard.

Sailing against the wind and sea, water entered the foreship. Hatches and ventilator openings were not properly closed. Subsequently the vessel developped a trim forward. Fully loaded with empty shells, the open hold got filled with water. Due to the insufficient capacity of the single bilge pump for the hold, the water could not be pumped out. Several spaces, incl. ballasttanks and cofferdams later turned out to be partially filled with water, due too improper deballasting and leakage (improper welding).

The stability of the vessel diminished causing it to capsize.

airtemperature -2C, watertemperature 5C.

One crew member got stuck and was pulled with the vessel under water. The other crew members did not have possession of proper immersion suits. One crew member did not fit in the suit. the other crew member used the suit still half opened, and the inflatable lifejacket did not function due to missing gascilinder.

Though a merchant vessel arrived at the accident location about 20 minutes after the capsizing and still managed to take one of the crew members out of the water (already Unconsiousness) all three crewmembers died. One of suffocation, the other of hypothermia.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At 17:55 hrs on 13 December 2010, an able seaman (AB) fell into the River Clyde from the St Vincent and Grenadines registered cargo ship Joanna, while the ship was alongside in Glasgow, Scotland. He was recovered from the water about 25 minutes later, but could not be resuscitated.

Seventeen fishermen are missing in icy waters following the sinking of the South Korean vessel In Sung No. 1 in the Southern Ocean.
At least five of the 42-man crew died and 20 were rescued after the deep-sea trawler went down about 2,000km (1,250 miles) south of New Zealand.
Rescuers have scaled back the search, saying it was unlikely that any of those missing would survive for long.
The crew included nationals from South Korea, China, Indonesia, the Philippines and Russia.
South Korea's foreign ministry said the 614-tonne ship, the Number One In Sung, sank at around 0630 hours on 13.12.2010. Twenty sailors were rescued by another fishing boat operating nearby. New Zealand rescuers said it was not clear why the boat sank. Conditions were calm and no SOS was sent. 
Survival times in the water in the area would be about 10 minutes without life-jackets or immersion suits, rescuers said after scaling back the search.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At 05:18 on 13 December 2010, the Frisia Rotterdam collided with the Cleantec west of Denmark. There was considerable material damage; however, nether people nor the environment were adversely affected.

The bulk carrier Cleantec, en route from Klaipéda to Paranaguà, was fully laden and had just passed Skagen as the container ship Frisia Rotterdam, en route from the port Aarhus to Bremerhaven and approaching from astern on the port side, struck the port side of the Cleantec with her bow. After the collision, each crew inspected the damage to its ship and found that she was still buoyant. The two ships were subsequently inspected by the Danish authorities and the classification societies. It was decided that the Frisia Rotterdam should be permitted to continue to Bremerhaven. However, the Cleantec had to be towed to the shipyard in Odense due to the heavy damage she sustained. She was not able to continue her voyage until 10 January 2011.

Location: 7 miles of West of Ashood, Israel
InitialEvent: Incident due to heavy weather conditions
SummaryOfEvents: On 12 December 2010, under heavy weather conditions, the ship ADRIATICA took in water in the forward compartment and sank in the Mediterranean Sea; 7 miles west of Ashood, Israel. All 11 crew members abandoned ship to liferafts and were later rescued by M/V YM GREAT and taken to Ashdod.  There were no injuries or pullution reported.

The M/V ship ARIJ stranded on a beach after dragging anchor for 1 mile North of the breakwater at Tartous, Syria on 12 December 2010 in heavy weather. It was reported that damages were beyond economical repair. No injuries or pollution are reported. There were sustained damages to keel and took water in holds and engine room. The damages were beyond economical repair and subsequently it was broken up.

ShipsInvolved: BERING ID (IMO 9146807), GIORGOS B (IMO 9100293), PACIFIC MERMAID (IMO 9045924)
SOLASStatus: BERING ID: Unknown/unspecified, GIORGOS B: Unknown/unspecified, PACIFIC MERMAID: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On December 11, 2010 at approximately14.50, the Liberian flagged reefer vessel, PACIFIC MERMAID was berthed at N13 at the Port of Novorossiysk; the vessel was completing the discharge of her cargo. A representative of the Port Authority had visited the vessel to issue a gale warning; the wind had registered  6/7 on the Beaufort scale. Due to the intense wind, all the lines from the forecastle had broken. A pilot and two tugs were brought in to assist in stabilizing the vessel. The PACIFIC MERMAID contacted the lifeboat on board the neighboring Maltese flagged vessel GIORGOS B; there was no damage to the GIORGES B except for the lifeboat. Tugs were unable to bring the PACIFIC MERMAID back to berth; the decision was made for the PACIFIC MERMAID to leave the harbor. While attempting to maneuver out of the harbor, the PACIFIC MERMAID contacted the Hong Kong flagged vessel, BERING ID. This contact damaged the PACIFIC MERMAID’s ladder accommodation and her board. The PACIFIC MERMAID was able to leave the harbor in the rough weather and return once the weather had subsided.  and the BERING ID sustained minor damage. There were no injuries or any incidents of pollution reported.

On Dec 10 2010 the general cargo ship North Spirit requested immediate assistance 50 miles off Cape Ortegal, Bay of Biscay. The ship which was enroute between Sweden and Alger with a cargo of timber, presumably the cargo shifted and the vessel started to dangerously list. Spanish authorities sent three helicopters to the scene, all 17 crew were evacuated and transported to the airport at La Coruna, no causalities or injuries were reported. The crew on board were 9 Ukrainians and 8 Russians.

On 11 December 2010 at 05.55 the ship’s was reported sunk at lat: 44 31.46’ N  and Long: 008 33’ E

The crew’s passports, certificates and ship’s Certificates were the only documents which were taken from the ship.

Antonis, a Greek registered bulk carrier, was being manoeuvred stern-first from the port of Liverpool’s Langton Dock to Alexandra Dock with a pilot on board.  As she entered the passageway between the docks, her stern started to drift towards the eastern wall under the influence of a north-westerly wind. The pilot was unable to counter the drift, and the ship’s hull, in way of a topside fuel oil tank, made contact with the sharp edge of a counterweight fitted on the open swing bridge. This caused a 1.5 metre gash in the ship’s side that resulted in about 330 tonnes of fuel oil spilling into the dock system

The Clipper Miki and the Christopher transited westbound on the Kiel Canal (NOK) on the night of 10 to 11 December 2010. Due to her draught, the Clipper Mikki was only permitted to sail at 12km/h while the Christopher was underway at the regular canal speed of 15 km/h. 
The Christopher caught up with the clipper Miki in the Königsförde siding. The pilots of the two ships discussed the overtaking manoeuvre in the next main siding, Audorf-Rade, over VHF. However, the course of the overtaking manoeuvre in the main siding was such that the two ships were next to each other as they  passed a narrowing of the canal’s cross-section. At the same time, the Christopher was pushed away due to hydrodynamic effects between the ship and bank, which caused her to turn to starboard and ram the Clipper Miki.

Significant material damage was caused to both ship, but nobody came to physical harm and the environment was not polluted. After the crews had finished inspecting the damage, it was decided to allow the two ships to continue to Brunsbüttel.

On 09 December 2010, the electric cable ferry Ecolos was undertaking its last crossing of the year from Thurso, Quebec to Rockland, Ontario on the Ottawa River. At 20:45 hrs Eastern Standard time, the ferry experienced cable, drive assembly and shore attachment failure as ice pans accumulated against the upstream side of the hull. The ferry remained tethered to the shore at Rockland by the damaged west cable. It then drifted downriver until coming alongside the shore ice. The 6 people on board were evacuated. There were neither injuries nor pollution.
During the voyage the vessel sustained failure of the ME cylinder No. 7. The vessel  was towed to the port with assistance of the tug.

6'"lDec/2010 (Time in JSTl 
1430 hrs: Vessel departed from repair dockyard at Yura, Japan bound for San Oiego, USA. 2330 hrs: Out Y crew heard Filler 's voice during safety patrol. 
y'hlDec 
08:00 hrs: Filler was noted missed in his cabin. 
08:20-12:45hrs: Vessel's crewmembers start searching, but not found him onboard. 
13:00 hrs: Company received initial report on this matter from Master, and he Id a emergency meeting in our office and contacted all relevant parties of Japan Coast Guard, Owner, Chtrs and P&I Club etc .. 
At the same time, Japan Coast Guard started searching by 4 vessels and one aircraft along with ship's navigation rule. 15:40 hrs: Company ordered Master lo change ship's course U-turn along lo last ship's course line for searching lill back to position last mid night (Lat:33-58N, Long137-39E). 
8th/Oec 
11 :00 hrs: The vessel reached the position where expected him lost, but nothing found. The vessel return lo original course bound for USA under continuous searching. 
16:30 hrs: Japan Coast Guard slopped searching, and no further searching will be conducted.

The tug ANYA stranded at Kylios, Turkey at 0939 Hours on 05 December 2010 in heavy weather. The rescue vessel SGK-312 and coastguard team attended the scene. All 6 crew were rescued. No injuries or pollution reported. The tug was towing barges "MHRT-1057" and "HEMLEVO 2" which also stranded.

On 5 December 2010, at 0730 hrs, the tanker POLAI foundered in the Singapore Straits, 3 miles SW of Tanjung Ayam, Malaysia.  All 5 crew members were rescued by ship KAM FUNG with no injuries or pollution were reported.  The Malaysian coastguard ship attended to the scene.  It is reported that the tanker was transerring fuel to the ship KAM FUNG when the incident occurred.

On Saturday 4 December 2010, at 13:43, the Panamanian cargo ship HONG WEI sunk off the north Philippine coast; around 120 nautical miles (222 km) off the Itbayat Island, situated between Taiwan, China and the Philippines.  The ship was carrying 40,000 tons of nickel ore and 24 passengers and crew members. Twelve members of the crew and 2 passengers were rescued by 3 ships sent by Taiwan's Coast Guard, while the search for the missing 10 colleagues continued despite the strong windes.   Authorities are still trying to determine what caused the ship to sink.

On Friday 4 December 2010, the 738-foot cargo ship GOLDEN SEAS, carrying 457,500 gallons of fuel oil, nearly 12, 000 gallons of diesel fuel, 10,000 gallons of lube oil and canola seeds suffered engine failure, became immobilized and started drifting towards nearby islands.  The ship was en route to the United Arab Emirates from Vancouver, Canada. Limited engine power, prevented the ship from overcoming the 29-foot seas and winds blowing at 45 mph.  Improving weather conditions, enabled the ship, positioned in the Bering Sea, about 28 miles north of Atka Island to begin moving away from shore at about 4 mph.  On Saturday 5 December 2010, the cutter ALEX HALEY and the towing ship, TOR VIKING II headed to GOLDEN SEAS from the Dutch Harbor, about 350 miles away, expecting to arrive by midday.  Atka is about 1,300 miles southwest of Anchorage.  There were no immediate reports of injuries among the 20 crew members on board.

Location: Red Sea, 190 miles north west of Al Jazan Port
SummaryOfEvents: On 3rd December 2010 the Centre for Coordinating Search and Rescue operations in the Red Sea Axis and Al-Aqaba Gulf received a distress call from the vessel LONG BEACH reporting that a crew member had been injured. The ship was met by the coastguard's boat some 77 nautical miles from Al Jazan, and at 19.30 of the same day the injured sailor was evacuated. He was admited to hospital on 4th December where he remained until 6th December when he returned to his home country. as a result of the accident, the injured sailor had lost three fingers from his left hand whilst on duty.

InitialEvent: UNCONTROLLED DESCENT OF AN ACCOMMODATION LADDER
SummaryOfEvents:
At 15:35 hours on December 1, 2010, aboard the General cargo Marshall Islands flagged vessel "ALPHA", IMO 8312100, IRIN V7MXS,  built 1984, occurred an accident with a person aboard, whilst alongside the berth in front of the warehouse 10 of the port of Rio de Janeiro, approximate coordinates Latitude 22 ° 53.3 'S / Longitude 043 º 11.5' W, during the manoeuvre of lowering the accommodation ladder. 
According to information obtained by the experts at the scene, at a certain moment, during the manoeuvre of lowering the accommodation ladder, with the 3rd Officer still on the upper platform, it moved out of its base. This displacement provoked the inclination and partial fall of the accommodation ladder, throwing to the quay the people that were on it.
As a result of this accident one crewman died.

Location: Nissan Motor Honmoku Wharf, Yokohama Section 5, Keihin Port
InitialEvent: Injuries on longshoremen during cargo loading
SummaryOfEvents: The pure car carrier VEGA LEADER berthed at Nissan Motor Honmoku Wharf, Yokohama Section 5, Keihin Port, during car loading work on December 1, 2010. While cars were being loaded on a deck panel of car deck No. 7, of which the height had been readjusted, the deck panel fell down onto car deck No. 6 at around 0950 hrs. Six longshoremen stevedoring on the deck panel and four longshoremen stevedoring on car deck No. 6, immediately below the panel—ten persons intotal—were injured.

Location: 12 miles south east of Cape Emine, Bulgaria
SummaryOfEvents: On 29 November 2010, at 1745 hrs, merchant ship 'KARAM I' sank after a collision with ship ALESSANDRO DP, 12 miles southeast of Cape Emine, Bulgaria.  Five crew members were reported missing, and 5 members were rescued by ship ALESSANDRO DP.  The ship PALFLOT-5, Coastguard, other merchant ships and helicopters effected SAR operation.  An investigation was effected.

On 29th November 2010 the M/v Keram 1 was sailing under Sierra Leone flag from Varna to Karpeka loaded with iron scrap. At approximately 17.38 hours she collided with m/v Alessandro DP sailing under flag of Netherland from Bosphoros to Varna under ballast. As a result of the collision the m/v Karam 1 sank, and 5 seamen went missing. After intensive SAR operation by sea and air crafts 5 seamen were rescued.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

SummaryOfEvents:
A fire was caught in the engine room of the F/V "BRITT JANNE" whilst moored at the Bat Og Oppdrettsservice shipyard, Hasloya, Norway at 0200 H on 28/11//2010.
Rescue boat "ERIK BYE" and local fire services brought the blaze under control later the same day. No injuries were reported. The vessel was unmanned at the time of the incident, fire spread to adjacent FV "FROYVAER". The damages were reported beyond economical repair, subsequently sank at berth on 30/11/2010. The wreck was raised by crane barge on 18/02/2011.

At 00:44 hrs on 28 November 2010, the eastbound container ship National Glory, which was entering the siding at Kiel-Holtenau Nordhafen (north harbour), collided in heavy fog with the westbound general cargo ship Malaga, which was waiting in the siding, in the Kiel Canal (NOK). The ro/ro ship Balticborg was proceeding at a distance of 300 m ahead of the National Glory. About 4 minutes earlier, the National Glory had passed the oncoming container ship Sandy Rickmers. At about 00:44 hrs, the Malaga took up position behind the container ship Sandy Rickmers on the western row of dolphins in Nordhafen. The two ships initially waited there until they were scheduled to proceed and then passed the gas tanker Gas Crystal, which was moored in front of them at the dolphins. The Sandy Rickmers sailed through the siding’s stop signal. The oncoming Balticborg passed the Sandy Rickmers between Projensdorf and the siding and after that the Gas Crystal and the Malaga at the same time in the siding. All ship under way had pilots and canal helmsmen on board.

Location: At sea, Off the Queensland coast
SummaryOfEvents: At 13.25 hours on 15 November 2010, a crew member on board Polska Walczaca is reported to have fallen about 6 m in the ship's number five cargo hold, and sustained fatal injuries.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

ShipsInvolved: M.V. GREEN VALLEY (IMO 9101807), M.V. TIGER SPRING (IMO 9301108)
SOLASStatus: M.V. GREEN VALLEY: SOLAS, M.V. TIGER SPRING: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: GREEN VALLEY inbound to Kolkata for unloading containers with 1 senior pilot & 1 trainee pilot. Pilots boarded 0815 hrs. on 23.11.2011 & courses adjusted as per pilot's advice. Pilot passed ETA Eastern Gut as 1130 to shore stn. Pilot of outbound container vessel TIGER SPRING  confirmed he would clear Eastern Gutbefore GREEN VALLEY, that was doing about 14 kts. with following current of 2- 2.5 kts. About 1125 hrs., when rounding off Waterloo Buoy, pilot made first visual contact with TIGER SPRING, that was at UWN  buoy doing about 12 KTS. Both pilots were using laptops for navigation. However, pilot on TIGER SPRING could get only GPS position as the cable was damaged. At UWN buoy, pilot of TIGER SPRING realised he was too slow to pass Eastern Gut before GREEN VALLEY. He informed pilotof GREEN VALLEY that he is forced to meet GREEN VALLEY at UWN buoy. Both pilots agreed & decided to pass port to port. When both ships were 2 to 3 cables from each other, TIGER SPRING'S pilot ordered a course change to 220 degrees. The helmsman put the wheel to 3 degrees port, & when the vessel started turning to port, he put the wheel amidships. As the turning rate of TIGER SPRING increased, the helmsman put the wheel on stbd. 20. Pilot immediately ordered hard a stbd., but vessel continued swinging to port. Pilot of TIGER SPRING asked pilot of GREEN VALLEY to go hard to port. Pilot of GREEN VALLEY ordered hard to port & full astern but by this time, TIGER SPRING was almost perpendicular to GREEN VALLEY, which resulted in collision.

ShipsInvolved: CARAKA JAYA III-MULI ANIM (IMO 9310501), MSC HOBART (IMO 9077288)
SOLASStatus: CARAKA JAYA III-MULI ANIM: Unknown/unspecified, MSC HOBART: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On November 22, 2010 at approximately 19:57 LT, Liberian flagged containership, MSC HOBART collided with another vessel, MULIANIN while under pilotage. While approaching buoy no. 6 while leaving the port of Surabaya, Indonesia, both vessels were navigating seawards.  The pilot onboard the MSC HOBART decided to overtake the MULIANIN; there was communication between the pilot and the MULIANIN and it was agreed that the MSC HOBART should pass on the port side of the MULIANIN. While overtaking MULIANIN, the Master of the MSC HOBART noted that the vessel was turning too fast to starboard; he ordered the helm be eased to 20 degrees port. The order was not executed in time and as a result, the MSC HOBART collided with the MULIANIN.  Due to the collision, the two vessels were stuck together for a period of time. The MSC HOBART was inspected by her crew which noted hull damage and that an unknown amount of oil had spilled into the sea. There were no reported injuries to either crew members.

The general cargo ship "HAI XIN" foundered in the East of China Sea, 100 miles Northeast of Lianyungang, China at 0035 Hours on 22/11/2010 in heavy weather. 18 crew were rescued from liferafts by rescue vessels "DONG HAI JIU 111" and "BEI LUN 5". No injuries were reported.

During the loading of cargo, one stevedore, who was in the close proximity of the cargo operations was hit by a reefer that was being loaded by the shore crane.  The stevedore sustained fatal injuries.

The ro-ro passenger ship, MECKLENBURG-VORPOMMERN operates the Trelleborg-Rostock route on a regular basis.  On 19 November 2010 at 2035 hrs (local time) and HGV trailer on deck 4 of the ship caught fire.  The HGV trailer's slot position was on the outer right parking lane of deck 4 on the starboard side at the front parking position.  The MECKLENBURG-VORPOMMERN was incoming on the maritime canal of the international port of the Hanseatic City of Rostock when the fire broke out.  Due to the early discovery of the source of the fire, the immediate initiation of the firefighting operation, coupled with the favourable slot position of the HGV trailer and the proximity to the port facility, the fire was controlled and any further damage was prevented.  At 2216 hrs, the fire was fully extinguished. 
Fire experts concluded that a technical fault probably triggered the fire and that a VW transporter situated on the load space of the trailer had caught fire.  There were no injuries and the MECKLENBURG-VORPOMMERN was slightly damaged by the fire and the ceiling above the slot position of HGV trailer was scorched.

Alors qu’il est dans sa zone de pêche, au large d’Hourtin, depuis la veille au soir, le fileyeur Vent Divin pose à nouveau ses filets le 18 novembre 2010 après-midi dans une bande située entre 3,5 milles et 4,5 milles de la côte. Vers 17:00 hrs, il se met au mouillage à proximité de ses filets, cap à l’Ouest.
Quatre hommes sont à bord : les trois hommes d’équipage et un passager (non déclaré). La météo étant stable et deux autres fileyeurs, également au mouillage, suffisamment distants, le patron descend se reposer vers 17:30 hrs; les deux autres membres d’équipage et le passager restent dans la vaste timonerie pour se restaurer.
Vers 23 :00 hrs, le patron revient en timonerie pour contrôler la position du navire et le mouillage, alors que les autres marins sont déjà couchés. La tenue au mouillage étant bonne, il descend à son tour se coucher dans le poste équipage. Le moteur et ses auxiliaires attelés restent en marche, mais les alarmes des appareils de navigation ne sont, semble-t-il, pas en service. Entre minuit et 1h00, l’équipage est réveillé par le bruit d’un paquet de mer ayant déferlé sur le pont ; le navire se couche brutalement sur tribord. Les quatre hommes regagnent avec difficulté la timonerie. D’autres paquets de mer frappent le navire et le pont est envahi. Craignant un chavirement imminent, le patron arrache la porte de la timonerie, déjà bloquée par la pression de l’eau sur tribord, et plonge vers l’extérieur, suivi du mécanicien. Le matelot et le passager restent un moment dans la timonerie qui se remplit d’eau, puis l’évacuent également. Les trois marins perdront rapidement le passager de vue. Bien qu’exténués, ils rejoindront finalement le rivage à la nage, mais le mécanicien décèdera peu après et son corps sera emporté par les rouleaux.
Le corps du passager et du mécanicien seront retrouvés après plusieurs jours de recherches.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The landing craft "CHRISTINE" sustained mechanical problems and sank in Aghia Kyriaki bay, Kefalonia, Greece on 18/11/2010. All 6 crew members swam to shore and no injuries were reported. The coastguard attended the scene and some oil pollution were reported in sea. Anti-pollution measures and cleanup operations were effected. The wreck was lying in 14 metres of water.

The incident occurred on November 17th 2010, in Zanzibar, during which one of the crew members, a Pakistani citizen of AB rank, named X, disappeared from the ship, while sailing, without leaving any traces on board. As per information gathered from interviews from the other crew members, the day before and the same day of his disappearance, he carried out his duties normally and nothing unusual was noticed in his behaviour. The day of the incident the vessel was scheduled to be attended by a radio technician, who boarded the vessel with a pilot boat. As soon it was noticed that he was missing, an extensive search on board the vessel was carried out without results. After searching the seafarer’s personal belongings, the only unusual thing found was a large quantity of medicine pills. The local authorities were informed a search & rescue operation was initiated but in vain as the seafarer not found. The search & rescue operation ended three days later, after the incident, without positive results. Also, it was checked if the seafarer was boarder, unauthorized, the pilot boat but such possibility was not confirmed as nobody has noticed or observed anything unusual.

PEARL OF SCANDINAVIA departed from Oslo on 16 November 2010 at 17:30 on a voyage to Copenhagen.

At 05:58 a fire alarm indicated fire on the car deck and it was established that some cars and trailers were on fire in two sections on the car deck aft in the port side.

The fire was extinguished by the ship’s sprinkler systems and subsequently by the ship’s fire-fighting teams assisted by Swedish fire-fighters who had been flown to the ship by helicopter.

The cause of the fire was an electric car that was being charged during the voyage.

After having recognized the fire, all passengers were evacuated to safe areas in the ship. Neither the passengers nor the crew were injured.

PEARL OF SCANDINAVIA arrived at Copenhagen on 17 November 2010 at 12:15 by its own power.

The vessel loaded 58 trucks from the port of Korinthos, Greece.  Cargo operations were completed on 16 November 2010 and at 2000, MV Colossus departed to her discharge port of Ancona, Italy.  On 17 November 2010, at about 0442, the vessel ran aground on the shores of Lefkada Island near the Cape of Doukatou.  Whilst no injuries and pollution were reported, the vessel sustained major structural damages to the fore peak tank, no. 1 fresh water tank, and deformation of the steel plates in several areas.

The M/V AL MUSTAFA 1 capsized and sank 10 nautical miles off Soccotra, Yemen on November 17. Local coastguard attended the scene and effected the search and rescue operation. The 10 crew members were rescued from floating timber and taken to safety.

The cargo ship ARKLOW RAIDER approached the river bar at Drogheda port at a speed of 4.9 knots.  At 1930 hrs the course 053°T at 4.3 knots at which point she took the ground, 20 minutes before the prodicted high water.  At 1934 hrs, the ship was not responding to rudder commands.  Additional engine power was applied and the bow thruster engaged in an attempt to resume the correct course.  At 1935 hrs, the ship touched bottom, veered to port and ran aground with the Aleria Light bearing 260° T X 183 metres.

On 16 November 2010, the cargo ship ARKLOW RAIDER approached the river bar at Drogheda port at a speed of 4.9 knots.  At 19:30 hrs (local time), the course was 053°T at 4.3 knots, at which point the ship took the ground, 20 minutes before the predicted time of high water.  At 1934 hrs, the ship was not responding to neither rudder commands nor the helm.  Additional engine power was applied and the bow thruster was engaged in an attempt to resume the correct course.  At 19:35 hrs, the ship touched bottom, veered to port and ran aground with the Aleria Light bearing 260° T X 183 metres.  
No crew members were reported injured
On 19 November 2010, on the evening tide at 21:55 hrs, the ship was refloated with the help of tugs OAKGRATH, MOURNE SHORE, HUSKIE and BOYNE PROTECTOR.  

Upon further inspection there was a clear problem with the ship's rudder.  On 20 November 2010, ARKLOW RAIDER arrived in Dublin in tow; its cargo was transhipped to another ship and it was brought to the dry dock for hull and steering gear repairs.

Whilst discharging machinery and vehicles from the vessel, an issue was raised with the master which eventually led to the stevedores refusing to unload a piece of heavy equipment.  The crew members took the initiative to unload the equipment themeselves and during eh process of working their way out of eh garage space, one crew member was trapped between the rails and the ramp side, resulting in fatal injuries.

The stern trawler "IN SUNG No. 205" caught fire in forward compartment whilst moored at berth 10, Montevideo, Uruguay at 0137 hours on 15/11/2010. The local fire services proceeded to assist. All 38 crew members were evacuated safely. No injuries were reported. It was towed from berth to outer harbour to protect adjacent vessels and reduce pollution risk. The blaze brought under control using fire fighting tugs. The ship was completely burnt out and was beyond economical repair.

The fishing vessel "FRISIA" took water and capsized in the North Sea 3 miles North of Terschelling, Netherlands in heavy weather. One crew member was rescued by M/V "OSTZEE" and airlifted to hospital in Leeuwarden, Netherlands, where he subsequently died. SAR operation was effected by naval helicopters, police and coastguard vessels and other ships, the hull was upturned and towed to Harlingen, Netherlands on 16/12/2010. Bodies of 2 missing crew members were later recovered.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo ship "MARYAM" sank whilst moored at port Tawfiq, Suez, Egypt on 14/11/2010. All 8 crew members were evacuated safely. No injuries were reported. Some of the cargo barrels of bitumen spilled into the water. Anti-pollution measures were deployed.

THE BOSUN WAS FOUND LYING ON THE MAIN DECK WITH SERIOUS INJURIES AND WAS PRONOUNCED DEAD SHORTLY AFTERWORDS.  HE WAS ALONE ON THE DECK IN GALE CONDITIONS.  THE CREW HAD BEEN WORRIED TO REMAIN IN THE ACCOMMODATION IN VIEW OF THE SEVERE WEATHER  FORECAST.  INVESTIGATION BY POLICE IN ROTTERDAM DID NOT SHOW THAT THE CAUSE OF DEATH WAS CRIME, ACCORDING TO THE MANAGERS. IT IS POSSIBLE THAT THE SEAMAN, FAITHFUL TO HIS DUTIES, WENT ON DECK AND ATTEMPTED TO CHECK ON RETIGHTEN LASHING AND SECURING DEVICES.

During changeover to Low Sulphur Fuel in order to comply with Port Regulations, a valve failed and allowed fuel under pressure from the low sulphur diesel oil system to spray out. The fuel ignited on contact with nearby superheated steam valves. The resulting fire was quickly extinguished by the crew. The ship was subsequently towed to a repair port and returned to service 6 weeks later.

Antigua and Barbuda flagged tug Fairplay-22, with a crew of five, capsized near the entrance Europoort Rotterdam, south of the northern breakwaters some 100 metres off the shore near the Berg Harbour. 
The accident happened during daylight in the afternoon hours of 11 November 2010 during bad weather conditions with rough sea. 
Three crew were rescued.
The tug was about to assist the British flag vessel Ro Ro Stena Britannia while being in process to getting berthed. 
Fairplay-22 approached the bow of Stena Britannia to pass a heaving line to get the rope connection established. When this failed Fairplay-22 in a second try came closer towards the bow of Stena Britannia where she was hit by the bulbous bow of Stena Britannia and slipped around. 
Fairplay-22 listed heavily and finally capsized rapidly when the bulb of Stena Britannia cracked into the schottel pod of the tug while she was pushed ahead in her 
already critical list. 
A fast rescue operation was mounted by the local rescue centre together with the Coastguard, who employed helicopter and airplane beside boats and water rescue equipment. A sheerleg floating crane was called to raise the tug; however, the salvage was hampered by winds of about 110 km/h. 
The dead body of one of the missing crew was found a day later drifted towards the shore. The master, however, who was missed as well, was only found dead later when the tug had been salvaged already.
The deteriorating impact on the surrounding environment close to the accident site was marginal because only a minimal amount of Diesel and lub oil was spilled from the sunken tug.

The two flag States involved (Antigua and Barbuda/UK) and the Netherlands, being substantially interested as coastal State, have mutually agreed to conduct a joint investigation with the Netherlands leading. 

An interim information report was agreed to be released by the Netherlands authorities periodically while the investigation is in process. A first one issued revealed that the human factor may have triggered this fatal casualty. The current standing of the case study gives cause to assume that there appears to be a lack of awareness of all the risks and dangers of operation of tugs very near to moving ships during the phase of fastening towing lines (see page 2/3 of De Onderzoeksraad Voor Veiligheid letter 10 March 2011).
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: 340 km (210 miles) south of Iriomote Island in the Pacific
SummaryOfEvents: On 4 November 2010, the ship NASCO DIAMOND, with a cargo of 55,000 tonnes of nickel ore, left Indonesia destined for Lianyngang, China.  The Maritime Authorities of Taiwan, China informed Japan's Coast Guard that the ship went missing about 340 km (210 miles) south of Iriomote Island in the Pacific.  Search and Rescue operations were effected; the Japanese and Taiwan, China patrols recovered 1 body, rescued three crew members and found another crew member in critical condition.  The Japanese patrol also recovered any empty life raft drifting 28 kilometres southwest of the site where the ship was believed to have sunk.  Of the 25 crew members on board, 20 are still reported missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: the Pacific Ocean between the Philippines and Taiwan, China
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 November 2010, at 1920 hrs, the bulk carrier NASCO DIAMOND developed a list to port, took water and sank in the Pacific Ocean, 200 miles SE of Eluanbi Point, Taiwan, China.  An initial distress call was received at 0355 hrs and Japanese, Taiwanese and Philippine coastguard ships and aircraft effected an SAR operation.  Three crew members were rescued and taken to hospital in Ishigaki, Japan with hyppothermia and other injuries; 20 members were reported missing and 2 crew members died.  Empty liferafts and an oil slick are found at the scene of the incident.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The bulk carrier "JIANMAO 9" took water in holds and sank in the South China Sea, 135 miles Southeast of Da Nang, Vietnam at 1528 hours on 09/11/2010 in heavy weather. All 27 crew members were abandoned ship and were rescued by M/V "NYK AQUARIUS" and taken to the Phu My, Vietnam.

The general cargo ship "BIEN DONG 02-ALCI" sustained engine failure, took water in hold and sank in the South China Sea, 35 miles North of Da Nang, Vietnam at 0620 on 09/11/2010 in heavy weather. The rescue ship "274" and M/V "PHUONG DONG STAR", "THANH TRUNG 26" and "LONG HAI 18" proceeded to assist. All 7 crew members were rescued by "LONG HAI 18" and taken to DA NANG. No injuries reported.

The French flagged chemical tanker Chantaco departed Riga, Latvia, on the 7th of November bound for Oxelösund, Sweden, loaded with 16 543 of HSVGO (High Sulphur Vacuum Gas Oil). On departure the draught was 8.75 meter even keel. The cargo as loaded with a temperature of 35°C. The terminal/receiver in Oxelösund required that the cargo had to have a temperature of 45°C before discharging.

When approaching the area of Oxelösund, contact was established with the VTS on the morning of 8 November on VHF channel 9. The ship was advised by the VTS to drop anchor at anchorage “B” but the master onboard Chantaco informed the VTS that he intended to anchor N of N Kränkan due to coming bad weather. 

Oxelösund VTS agreed that the ship could use the inner anchorage since the area of the anchorage is outside the area of compulsory pilotage.

At 08:30 hrs Chantaco dropped anchor in position N 58° 37,’75  E 017° 22,’58 (about 6 cables east of Hörngrund) with six shackles on deck. 

Due to the increasing winds during late afternoon the master decided to increase the length of the anchor chain to eight shackles on deck.

On 9 November at 02:00 hrs, the officer on watch noticed that the ship started dragging her anchor. He immediately called the captain and informed him about the situation and a few seconds later he called the engineer on watch, bosun and one AB.

Chantaco dragged with a speed of about 1.5 knots in a west-southwesterly direction heading north, with the wind and sea on her starboard side, toward Hörngrund. At around 02:10 hrs, she dragged aground in position N 58° 37,’74  E 017°21,’66 just before the bridge had the engine control.

On 7 November 2010, at 2300 hrs, the trawler SOLBERG caught fire in hold whilst berthed at Montevideo, Uruguay.  All crew members were evacuated.  The ship was towed to the outer harbour area, where tugs and local fire services extinguished the blaze the following day.  The ship sustained extensive damage.  There were no reports of any injuries.

Shortly after departure from Tangier for a voyage on three West African ports, a Philippine able bodied seaman (AB) showed signs of strange behaviour. Based on the AB’s own statements, the master believed the AB’s behaviour was the initial symptoms of a depression.

En route to Walvis Bay in Namibia the ship called at Luanda, but due to the lack of medical resources in this port, the AB was not sent ashore for medical attention in Luanda. 

After departing Luanda, the AB’s condition deteriorated further and the master decided to sign off the AB upon the ship’s arrival in Walvis Bay, Namibia. The master came in doubt whether the AB was fit to be transported to his home by airplane, and he arranged for AB to be taken to a local hospital for examination before being considered fit for repatriation.

When the ship arrived in Walvis Bay, the AB was submitted to the local hospital in the afternoon of 4 November 2010. The ship owner local agent reported that, during the examination and interviews with the medical personnel at the hospital, the AB was very aggressive. The doctors decided to keep the AB in the hospital for observation. In the morning of 5 November 2010, the AB’s condition deteriorated further, and the AB died at 07:30 hrs local time.

Radio Medical was not contacted during the course of events.
On 5 November 2010, in heavy weather conditions, the tanker SRIVICHAI NAVEE foundered in the South China Sea, off Surat Thani Province, Thailand.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

On 1st November 2010 the Liberian container ship MSC Basel, with a harbour pilot on board, grounded in Moreton Bay between M4 and M6 beacons while outbound. An intermitent fault in the ship's steering gear caused the ship to veer to starboard, into a channel bank outside the main channel. The ship refloated on the tide.

Location: Off Glendad, Malin Head, Co. Donegal
SummaryOfEvents:
On 1 November 2010, the owner and a another man left their homes at Ross Head, Glendad, Co. Donegal, Ireland at approximately 07:00 hrs and travelled by road to the F/VJenniver at Portmore Pier, Malin Head to move crab pots from their location at sea to Glendad.

The ship sank shortly afterwards and the bodies of both of them were subsequently recovered.

The tanker "GLOBAL JUNO" took water and subsequently sank in the South China Sea, 105 miles Southeast of Waglan island, Hong Kong, China at 0153 Hours on  30/10/2010 in heavy weather.  All 17 crew members were transferred by helicopter to M/V " RBD FIUGGI" later the same morning and taken to Tanjungbara, Indonesia. No injuries or pollution were reported.

While MT Marios G and MT Uraga Princess were anchored, the two vessels were situated 0.4nm apart. MT Uraga Princess requested the MT Marios G move away from being too close. In attempting to move, MT Marios G encountered strong current and moderate swell conditions causing the two vessels to contact and incur hull damages.

Location: Extrémité Ouest du DST des Casquets
SummaryOfEvents:
Le 28 octobre 2010, le chalutier CAP FRÉHEL est en pêche à l’extérieur Ouest du
dispositif de séparation du trafic des Casquets. Le pétrolier KRASNODAR navigue dans la voie descendante, à destination de Gibraltar.
Peu avant 20h00, le KRASNODAR sort du DST des Casquets et vient au 240° pour poursuivre sa route vers le DST de Ouessant. Une fois le changement de cap effectué et la situation claire, le commandant passe la suite au troisième lieutenant et
quitte la passerelle.
A bord du navire de pêche, après s’être fait remplacer et avoir pris un rapide repas, le patron rejoint la passerelle à 20h50.
Un quart d’heure plus tard, le CAP FRÉHEL se trouve droit devant le KRASNODAR, à environ 1,5 mille. Sur la passerelle du pétrolier, les hommes de quart n’identifient ni ne suivent le navire de pêche ; ils sont accaparés par un navire de charge sur leur tribord qui fait route au Sud/Est. Alors que le CAP FRÉHEL vire son train de pêche, après une croche, et n’est de ce fait plus manoeuvrant, le KRASNODAR conserve son cap.
Le patron du chalutier, ayant tardivement pris conscience du risque de collision, tente cependant une manoeuvre de dernière extrémité, barre à gauche et machine en avant toute, mais le choc, bordé contre bordé, est inévitable. 
Après l’abordage, le patron du navire de pêche entre en liaison radio avec le KRASNODAR. Les deux officiers n’arrivent pas à se comprendre et à converser en anglais. Le KRASNODAR poursuit sa route vers Ouessant et le CAP FRÉHEL, qui a deux blessés légers à bord, fait route vers Saint-Malo, après avoir informé le CROSS Jobourg de l’accident.

Location: South East of Hong Kong  276 nm
SummaryOfEvents:
On 28 October 2010 m/v Vega Turmalin was traversing the South China Sea en-route from Laem Chabang/Tailand to Osake/Japan. The weather was bad with strong winds and heavy seas. The ship was working heavily. The chief mate had given early instruction to the bosun and the deck crew to not enter the deck on foreship for safety reason and to proceed with indoor paint and repair works they had started the day before already.

After breakfast the bosun instructed two ABs to join him for works necessarily to be performed on deck, thus ignoring the safety instructions given by the chief mate ear-lier that same morning. Although the two AB’s were reluctant to follow the bosun and to better obey the chief mate order they finally followed the bosun on deck. As per the boson’s direction the two pilot ladders installed on either side of the vessel’s main deck should be protected and secured for the potential risk of being washed away by overcoming seas
.
After works on starboard side were done the bosun together with the two ABs’ crossed over the free hatch covers toward port side to secure the pilot equipment over there. While one AB remained on the hatch cover the other AB together with the bosun passed through the catwalk ladder down to the main deck. There, the bosun was hit by a strong surging green water sea swell pouring onto the port side main deck. As observed by the two ABs’ who had found shelter on time the body of the bosun – apparently unconscious – was adrift in the wave and was then washed overboard.
Although an effective and full scale MoB manoeuvre was sparked immediately, fol-lowed by SAR actions, the body of the bosun could not be recovered.

The bosun remained the only casualty in this calamity. The two ABs’ could escape without injuries. There was no damage to the ship and no environmental impact on the surrounding sea.
The occurrence was classified to being a very serious marine casualty subject to be fully investigated as per the Casual Code.
The objective was to find out why the bosun violated the written work order to not en-ter the foredeck weather permitted.

CAUGHT FIRE AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK WHILST BERTHED AT SALALAH, OMAN AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 28/10/13.
ALL CREW EVACUATED SAFELY. NO INJURIES REPORTED. LOCAL FIRE SERVICES AND FIRE FIGHTING TUG 'HASIK' ASSISTED WITH FIGHTING THE BLAZE WHICH EVENTUALLY SPREAD TO THE ENTIRE VESSEL. TOWED TO A SAFE AREA 3 MILES EAST OF THE PORT TO CONTINUE FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS BUT SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN LAT. 19 56N., LONG. 054 04E., AT APPROXIMATELY 1130 HOURS LT THE SAME DAY.

Vessel was on passage from Olen to Haugesund and grounded on a charted rock which resulted in material damage to one of her voith thruster units. Vessel was able to proceed under her own power back to Olen for assessment of damage.

SOLASStatus: Cardiff Bay Yacht Club RIBs: Non-SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 27 October 2010, two Rigid Inflatable Boats (RIBs) belonging to the Cardiff Bay Yacht Club (CBYC) collided while transporting a number of children across Cardiff Bay. As a result of the impact three children were thrown into the water, while others suffered abrasions and muscular injuries.

The bulk carrier "JIAN FU STAR" took water in ballast tank and sank in the South China Sea, 90 miles Southwest of Cape Eluanbi, Taiwan at 0930 hours on  27/10/2010 in heavy weather. All 25 crew abandoned the ship and coastguards ships and helicopters and others MVS effected SAR operation. 12 crew members were rescued and taken to hospital in Kaohsiun. 1 crew member was dead and 12 are missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The grounding site is on the Western shore of “ Sin-aun Taung “ island ( 4436 ) at the Global Position, ( Lat 19˚ 52′.559 N , Long 93˚ 26′.612 E ), and about two miles away from a village named “ Min Kyaung “,( 65 ) miles South East of Sittwe City, Rakhine coastal state, Myanmar

On March 22 2010, at 19:20 hours, on berth no.13, in the port of Split, ro-ro passenger ship "Tin Ujevic",port of registry Rijeka, GT 4103, length 98.3 m, year of construction 2002., with 140 passengers, 15 crew members and 32 loaded cars, on a regular line no.635 Split - Stari Grad (island of Hvar), the sea state calm, low wind predominantly northern direction, good visibility, due to the nautical fault of the master,during maneuvering, made contact and hit the left aft part of the southern edge of the ro-ro ramp connections No.12 (western edge connection No.13) on the pier of St. Peter in the port of Split.Ship suffered considerable damage in the part of the waterline with holed left aft fuel tanks in diameter 3 x 3 m and 34.8 tons of diesel oil leaked into the sea caused pollution in the port of Split .By means of floating booms, absorbents and dispersants it was stopped further expansion.
All passengers and crew members have passed without injury.

The vessel arrived at the port of Anwterp on 21 October 2010.  Following the discharge of her cargo, the vessel shifted in preperation for the cargo operations.  The operation necessitated the shifting of pillars and beams inside the vessel's holds - an operation which necessiated the use of the ship's deck cranes.  One AB and a deckhand were engaged in this operation together with the bosun, who was manning the cargo crane.  Whilst handling the fourth pillar, the crew members observed some problems with what seemed to be a jammed sling or wire.  The deckhand, who at the time was inside the designated shelter within the cargo hold, came out and attempted to free the sling.  However, at this point in time, he lost his balance and fell to his death inside the cargo hold.

Location: 42 MILES OFF SHORE SOHAR PORT- OMAN
SummaryOfEvents:
20th Oct. 2010 vessel is 42 miles away from Sohar Port-Oman 23:30 @ Watch bridge (Master) Engine Room watch (Ch/Engineer) 
Vessel start to enter some water in Engine Room two oilers in duty report to ChiefEngineer also report to the bridge, Captain instruct to the Engine Room to start pumping pumps and also call al! affairs to bridge after report of Ch/Engineer cannot start pumps due to the flow of water, Chief Engineer shut down all generators to avoid any sparks or side effects of electric shocks. Captain inform and call for abandon the vessel. Chief Officer and crew prepare the life boats and life rafts. Second mate call al! vessel for help and contacted the coastguards of Oman which they sent after 90 mins. boat to assist to the vessel. Al! crew was disembarked from the vessel by pilot ladder to port side. At 2:00 AM on 21st October 2010 al! crew arrived to safe place at 9:00AM 21th ofOctober 2010.

Location: Taiwan Strait, 40 miles SE of Putian, China
SummaryOfEvents: On 20 October 2010, at 2036 hrs, during typhoon Megi,  the cargo ship SHENG JIA 16 foundered in the Taiwan Strait, 40 miles SE of Putian, China.  The rescue ships DONG HAI JIU 159 and Coastguard 131 proceeded to assit at the scene.  Eight crew members were rescued; 2 died and 3 were reported missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: approx. 30’ west of Chi Mei Yu Island
SummaryOfEvents:
The main details of the accident are listed below 
Time and date of casualty 	00:30 hrs / 19th OCT / 2010
Location of casualty	: (approx. 30’ west of Chi Mei Yu Island - (23-14N 118-54E))
Type of casualty	Foundering in heavy weather ( N.W. Monsoon, influenced by Super Megi Typhoon outer range), vessel listed 300  STBD
Damage / Loss	Total loss of vessel 
Number of fatalities / injuries	NIL 

Atmospheric Conditions 	CLOUDY
Distance of Visibility	RESTRICTED
Wind	STRONG WINDS
Wind Direction	N-NELY
Sea	8-9 BEAUFORT SCALE 
Direction of Sea	NE
Swell	8-10 meters

SOLASStatus: HS CHALLENGER: SOLAS, SAIPAN VOYAGER: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 0521 hours on October 18, 2010 and while Liberian flag container vessel, HS CHALLENGER, was engaged in cargo operations, another vessel, M/V SAPIAN VOYAGER collided into HS CHALLENGER while un-berthing. The windy and rainy weather conditions caused the vessel to slowly roll closer and closer to HS CHALLENGER without anyone realizing the impending danger of the collision. Upon impact, the duty officer rushed to check the hull damage. The hull damage on the port side of the HS CHALLENGER was considerable and required immediate repair, however there were no serious injuries and there was no was no incident of pollution.

Durante la madrugada, estando la nave a la gira se produce un cortocircuito en la cablearía del entre-cielo de la oficina del capitán, generándose humo y fuego en el compartimiento. En el recinto contiguo dormía el capitán, camarote el cual tenía la puerta cerrada con llave por su interior. El incendio se comunicó por el cielo del camarote produciendo humo y cayendo gotas de plástico derretido desde el cielo del camarote. El capitán despertó pero producto del humo y del plástico caliente que lo quemaba no logró abrir la puerta.
El tripulante de guardia en el puente sintió olor a plástico caliente detectando el incendio. Dio la alarma y con un hacha intentó derribar la puerta del camarote del capitán sin lograrlo.
El incendio fue controlado por la dotación y cuando lograron entrar al camarote del capitán, rescatarlo y suministrarle primeros auxilios, este ya había fallecido de "asfixia por inhalación de humo".
La nave sufrió daños de mediana consideración. No se produjo contaminación del mar.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On the afternoon of 12th October 2010 departed from Coliemore Harbour with the intention of rowing out to Dalkey Island. When he had not returned after one and a half hours the alarm was raised. The Dun Laoghaire Lifeboat and a rescue helicopter were tasked to search and subsequently the lifeboat found his boat washed up on the rocks on the South East side of Dalkey Island. A short time later the rescue helicopter located the casualty in the water just south of Dalkey Island and recovered him. He was later pronounced dead at Tallaght Hospital.

Location: Black Sea, 25 miles South of Kerch, Ukraine
SummaryOfEvents: On 11 October 2010, at 0438 hrs, the cargo ship, VASILIY foundered in the Black Sea, 25 miles south of Kerch, Ukraine.  The Ukrainian coastguard and other ships effected search and rescue operations.  At 0820 hrs, coastguards spotted a red flare and floating objects 2 miles off Kyz Aul point, Ukraine.  At 0955 hrs, tug PITER spotted 2 drifting lifeboats.  Nine crew members were subsequently rescued by tugs PITER, BORA and DON-3.  One crew member died and 3 were reported missing.  Some oil pollution was reported in the sea.  The rescued crew were taken to hospital in Feodosiya, Ukraine.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo AYNUR KRK sustained engine failure, took water through stern gland and sank in the Mediterranean Sea 270 miles Northwest of Benghazi, Libya at 23.55 on 10/10/2010. All 16 crew abandoned the ship and were rescued by MV "ACONCAGUA BAY" and taken to Benghazi, Libya. No injuries were reported.

M/V “APJ KAIS” planned for a routine rescue boat lowering and manoeuvring in water at the Iron Ore Berth at Paradip Port-India, on 10th October 2010. The rescue boat was lowered and maneuverer in water with the following complement: 2nd Officer, 3rd Engineer and two ABs. The Rescue boat was successfully lowered and maneuverer in water. The boat was being recovered by the remote hoisting switch from the vessel. During the recovery operation, and while the boat was about 3 meters from the waterline, a sudden jerk occurred and the rescue boat was unhooked and collapsed into the water. Immediately, the ship’s crew had initiated emergency response and retrieved all the crew members in the fallen rescue boat via the starboard gangway except the 2nd officer who was transferred to the vessel by a stretcher. Moreover, all of the four crew members were sent to a shore medical facility in an Ambulance, in order to perform necessary medical examination. Later it was informed by the Agent that the 2ndOfficer and 3 rd Engineer were hospitalized at Apollo Hospital in Cuttack and were declared unfit for sailing, and both ABs were treated and declared fit for sailing. Therefore, ABs returned to the vessel on the same day. Subsequently, the vessel had left Paradip Port on 11th October, without the 2nd Officer and 3rd Engineer onboard. However, this was in compliance with the vessel MSMC.

In the earliest hours of 10 October 2010, the owner and a the crew lost their  lives while attempting to board the motor yacht Quo Vadis, which was moored in Inishbofin Harbour, Inishbofin Island, Co. Galway, Ireland.

Location: 3 miles east of Fraserburgh, Scotland Uk
SummaryOfEvents: The lone fisherman was lost overboard, most likely when hauling his first, or second creel leader. A search started six hours later, but he was not found. The investigation found that back ropes are liable to ride out of 'V' wheel haulers if they do not lead correctly onto the potting roller. The investigation also highlighted the hazards faced by fishermen working singlehandedly, and their vulnerability in emergency situations. The skipper did not wear a floatation device or lifeline; nor did he wear a personal locator beacon.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The passenger/ro-ro ship caught fire after an explosion on upper cargo deck 8 miles northwest of Fehmarn island, Germany at 0005 hours on 09/10/2010. All 204 passengers and 32 crew members were rescued and taken to Kiel, Germany. 3 persons were taken to hospital by helicopter for treatment. The blaze was brought under control on 10/10/10 with help from tugs "ASTERIX" and "BUGSIER 26". The accomodation and the cargo decks were completely burnt out.

SOLASStatus: APOLLO S: Unknown/unspecified, GRAND RODOSI: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: At about 14.00 hours on 8 October 2010, the Liberian bulk carrier Grand Rodosi entered Port Lincoln with a pilot on board bound for the grain wharf to load a cargo of wheat. At about 14.48 hours, while the ship was making its final turn towards the wharf with two tugs in attendance, it collided with the portside of the fishing vessel Apollo S that was berthed alongside the Port Lincoln wharf. Apollo S was severely damaged and it sank on its port side. Grand Rodosi berthed with the assistance of the two tugs.

Location: Straits of Florida Off Damas Cay, Bahamas
SummaryOfEvents: On 7 October 2010 at 0430 hrs, the ship MYSTIC struck a submerged object, took water, capsized and sank in the Straits of Florida off Damas Cay, Bahamas.  An initial distress call was received at 1408 hrs on 6 October 2010.  Pumps were air dropped by USCG C-130 aircraft to assist with the pumping out of water.  USCG Cutter NANTUCKET proceeded to the scene, however, was unable to assit due to the adverse weather conditions.  The ship MYSTIC developed 30 degree starboard list.  All 10 crew members abandonded ship to 2 liferafts; 6 crew members were rescued by USCG MH-60J helicopeter; and 4 by a small boat from NANTUCKET.  There were no injuries reported.

SOLASStatus: FAR SWAN: Unknown/unspecified, GLOBAL SUPPLIER: Unknown/unspecified, MICLYN 131: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At about 19.43 hours on 6 October, the platform supply ship Far Swan collided with the unmanned barge Miclyn 131 during its departure from Dampier. Miclyn 131 was being towed by the 18 m Global Supplier at the time and was enroute from Malus Island to Flying Foam Passage. There were no injuries or pollution resulting from the collision. Far Swan sustained a 1m tear in the shell plate above the water line and the barge received minor damage. Far Swan went to anchor in the harbour and Global Supplier proceeded to the Johns Creek Boat Harbour.

M/V Philipp was on a ballast leg en-route from Molfetta (Golf of Manfredonia/Adreatic Sea) to Puerto Magiera (Venice/Italy). The vessel had departed from Molfetta in the early morning hours of 06 October 2010 and sea-going routine was soon dominating.

Around noon time the engine watch crew was faced with an air leakage in the main engine system which caused the chief engineer to report to the master and to ask for a temporary main engine stop to accomplish repairs and to replace with a spare regulator. 

After lunch one of two diesel generators was started and the main engine stopped. Shortly thereafter, the diesel generator failed to function properly and to substitute the shaft generator, which, with the main engine running, had maintained the vessel’s electricity supply.
Various attempts to restart the generator failed and also afford to get the second generator started proceeded unsuccessful. Finally, with all compressed starting air wasted and only the emergency batteries left, the chief engineer had the idea to utilize pressured oxygen from bottles, normally used for welding works, to get a generator restarted.

With orders and instructions received and under supervision of the chief engineer the oiler on duty attempted to arrange a connection mechanism of the oxygen bottle with the generator’s starting air input. 

After a connection was poorly established the oxygen bottle was opened 3 or 4 times until suddenly a violent explosion took place, which severely injured the oiler as well as the chief engineer.
A fire, which broke out next in connection to the explosion, was extinguished with shipboard means rather quick and the two injured crew were recovered with first aid rendered. 

The two seafarers survived the ordeal and were taken by the rapidly approached Italian Coast Guard for hospitalization to port of Manfredonia. The vessel proceeded to Manfredonia as well where she was to be inspected by police and local Authorities as well as by a flag State official.

The accident provoked the flag State to instigate a focused investigation and to prepare a marine safety investigation report.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 6 October 2010, at 1430 hrs, the cargo ship OCEAN PEARL took water in hold No.'s 4 and 5 and developed starboard list while anchored in Chittagong Roads, Bangladesh.  The Coastguard, naval ships and a tug attended the scene.  All crew members were rescued with no injuries reported.  On 8 October 2010 at 1500 hrs, the cargo ship was grounded to prevent it sinking.  The hull sagged in 4 places and sustained serious damage.  It was later reported as being beyond economical repair.

The general cargo ship "HUY HOANG 26" broke anchor chain, drifted and struck gianh bridge. It sank in the Gianh river, Quang Binh, Vietnam at 0700 hours on 05/10/2010 in heavy weather. Two crew members swam to shore, 5 crew dead, wreck cut into 2 sections. It was refloated and removed in December 2010.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Off Coffs Harbour New South Wales
SummaryOfEvents: At about 08.55 hours on 4 October 2010, about 600 packs of deck cargo were lost over board from the mulit-purpose/general cargo ship Mimasaka during heavy seas.

M/V Fitnes is a self discharging dry bulk carrier which’s seven cargo holds are served by two longitudinal conveyor belts, one port and one starboard, feeding to a forward silo where the cargo is subsequently off-loaded via a cargo boom.
 
On 03 October 20110 m/v Fitnes was berthed starboard side alongside in the port of Northfleet/UK. The vessel was in process of discharging a bulk load of slag, previously loaded in Kvinesdal/Norway. The vessel was using her self-discharging boom with all feeding conveyor belts in operation. 

A wiper’s duty pattern on his watch cycle was to physically control the belt operation between two belt rooms, while the off-loading operation was alternatively monitored by either the second or third mate from the vessel’s cargo control room. 

The watch team was equipped with walkie-talkie for communication purposes to report any operational event worthy to note and to alert to potential risk forthcomings.

Without having triggered any alarm or communicated on a potential risk the wiper was associated with some time during his watch he was found dead by the chief mate during one of his control rounds. The wiper had been caught in the conveyor belt and was crushed to death by the port tunnel conveyor roller. 

The discharging operation was stopped immediately and the vessel management as well as local institutional investigators have started to thoroughly analyse the fatality.
The accident provoked the flag State to instigate a focused inspection on-scene, inclusive a detailed vetting of the vessel’s belt operation system. A marine safety investigation will be conducted with a marine safety investigation report to follow.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo ship "HOANG TRUNG 08" sustained cracks in hull, took water in holds and sank in the Cua Lo estuary, Vietnam at 2130 hours on 02/02/2010 in heavy weather. All 8 crew were rescued by local emergency services, 1 crew member was injured and taken to hospital. Cracks were initially developped during sea voyage at 2300 hours on 01/10/2010. The vessel was diverted to shallow waters to lessen sinking risk. The wreck was partially submerged with superstructure still above water.

On 30 September 2010 the Frisian Summer was moored at a waiting quay at Tata Steel (formerly Corus) in Velsen. The ship had sailed there from the anchorage at the end of the morning. The ship was due to be shifted to the unloading quay at any moment and the crew was on standby on deck. it was decided to use the spare time to grease the forward crane. However one of the officers went forward to open the hatches with the hatch crane at the same time. He was not aware of the sailer being in the path of the hatch cover crane..
The sailor was hit ans broke his hip.

While being on passage from Spain to North Africa the crew on Arlau realized that the  cook was missing.
The non-attendance was noted early on a morning in the ship’s messroom when the crew detected that the cook was not at work.
Checking the quarters the crew found the cook’s cabin ransacked with almost all private belongings missing. Also a following diligent search all over the ship revealed the absence of the cook. 
Because the cook was counted to be aboard upon departure from the last port of call it was now safe to assume that the cook had been fallen over board.
At this stage the master prompted MoB alarm. A SAR operation was triggered and coordinated by MRCC Lisbon, which put  Navy ships and aircrafts on task. The master turned Arlau on her way, and together with some other ships having all been in close vicinity they all participated in the SAR operation. However, the missing seafarer was not found. 
Only some 16 days later a ship reported the detection and recovery of a body from the sea which was later identified being the missing cook from Arlau.
The crew member was doing maintenance work in one of the tween decks when he fell inside the cargo hold, sustaining fatal injuries.

On 28 September 2010, at 0150 hrs, the bulk carrier PERLA ADIB stranded SW of Keramia, Chios, Greece.  No injuries or pollution were reported.  Coastguard ships attended to the scene.  On 29 September 2010, the carrier was refloated with tug assitance and towed to Chios for divers inspection,  It was later reported that the carrier had sustained damage to its hull beyond economical repair.  On 11 November 2010, the PERLA ADIB arrived at Aliaga, Turkey to be broken up.

The merchant vessel “FLUMAR BRASIL”, IMO No. 9416836,  DWT 51.000 tons, GT 29.712 tons, Brazilian flag, built 2010, port of registry Maceió, belonging to Flumar Transport of Chemicals and Gases Ltd, having as Operator Petrobras Transporte S.A. – Transpetro, berthed in the Port of Suape at 16.00 hrs on 27 September 2010, proceeding from the Port of Santos, City of Santos – São Paulo and with destination foreseen as the Port of Fortaleza. After the berthing at Port of Suape, Terminal TGL-2, it was judged necessary to effect a re-positioning of the vessel with a movement forward. At 15:50 hours, during this manoeuvre to reposition the ship, during the execution of the figure-of-eight of eight (layers of mooring line around a double set of bitts used to get around a hawser), a deckhand of the bow´s manoeuvring team was hit in the forehead by the hawse which came off the bollard.
