Before arriving at its destination the second officer went on deck to assist in the mooring work, and positioned himself next to a cadet and an able seaman at the winch aft of the forecastle on the starboard side. As the Master manouevered the vessel alongside the platform at the ramps, a sea cadet climbed ashore to receive and make the lines fast. The platform was short and the vessel got a long overhang in the forward, making the spring line quite long. The breast line was led out from the winch, where the second officer was standing. The breast line was led in a tight angle between the winch and the bollards on board, with the roller in the centre. As the line was sent ashore and made fast the second officer was standing at the winch. According to hiim, he heard the Master calling something from the bridge and turned around so his back was facing the railing. He then had the manouevering handle of the winch in front of him and was not sure whether to slack out or heave on the line. He then started to heave on the line by pulling the handle. After securing the spring line, the cadet on the forecastle was about to go aft to assist with the other lines when he heard a cracking sound. He looked towards the place where the second officer was standing, and saw the roller being torn off its fitting. The second officer was hit by the line as it came loose. He fell and instinctively held on to the manouevering handle. This caused the winch to continue heaving and, as a result, his legs were caught in it before he released the handle. The rescue services were alerted and arrived within a few minutes. The mooring rope on the winch was cut off in order to free the second officer. He sustained serious fractures to both legs and lost a lot of blood. His right leg later had to be amputated.

Día 07 julio a 13:00 horas, la señora Silvia GUERRERO Lama, esposa del Patrón de la embarcación pesquera ANGELO ANTONIO con matrícula IO-20837-BM, informando que la citada embarcación zarpó el día 04 julio a 15:00 horas a zona de pesca frente a Talara. CAPILARA, activó RCC, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera Marítima BAP. RIO OCOÑA, Patrulleras de Costa CHORRILLOS y PACASMAYO y la aeronave FOCKER F-60 que efectuó la exploración aeromarítima, CAPIZORI, efectuó coordinaciones con el Cuerpo de Guardacostas del Ecuador, a fin de que active su Plan de Busqueda y rescate, disponiendo el zarpe de la Unidad Guardacostas Ecuatoriana "ISLA PUNA", el dia 14 se recepcionó llamada telefónica de la Capitanía de Puerto Bolivar, informando que el Buque Pesquero CARIBE 2 de bandera Ecuatoriana, ubicó a la embarcación pesquera ANGELO ANTONIO, en aguas ecuatorianas, rescatando a los CINCO (05) tripulantes, arribando el dia 15 a 01:00 horas al Puerto de Manta - Ecuador.

SOLASStatus: LUCERITO DE MI MADRE III: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Día 07 julio a 12:00 horas, el señor Danny Manuel SILVA Mogollon, propietario de la embarcación pesquera LUCERITO DE MI MADRE, informando que su embarcación se encuentra al garete por fallas mecánicas, en la posición Latitud 04° 34`S y Longitud 081° 36´W, con SEIS (06) tripulantes a bordo. CAPILARA, activó RCC, a 14:10 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHORRILLOS, a 15:10 horas la mencionada embarcación fue ubicada por la Patrullera de Costa en la posición Latitud 04° 33`S y Longitud 081° 40`W, a 19:40 horas arribó la Patrullera de Costa al Puerto de Talara remolcando a la citada embarcación.

On 7 July 2010, an explosion occured on ship BELOMORSKIY RYBAK, while it's fuel tank was being cleaned.  This subsequently resulted in the fuel tank catching fire, while moored at Murmansk, Russia.  Three workers were injured and taken to Murmansk regional hospital and one worker was in a critical condition with severe burns.  The ship was later broken up at murmansk.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Fishing vessel NINANITU departed from Grenaa for fishing at Store Middelgrund in Kattegat. On board were two men, and the vessel was navigating by auto pilot on course 085° at approx. 8 knots. During the passage the best hand rested in the cabin forward while the skipper stayed in the wheel house.   

At some time the skipper observed AFRICAN ZEBRA on the radar at approx. two miles and approx. 40° to port. It seemed to the skipper as AFRICAN ZEBRA was going to pass astern of NINANITU and thus he took no action with regard to that ship. 

Bulk carrier AFRICAN ZEBRA was navigating southward by Route T at course 209° at approx. 13 knots. On duty on the bridge were an officer and an AB as a lookout.

After having his dinner, the master came to the bridge. He saw immediately visually a fishing vessel approx. 1½ cable from the ship on starboard bow obviously at risk of a collision. The duty officer and the lookout had not seen the fishing vessel.

Both ships were manoeuvred in attempt to avoid a collision but NINANITU hit into the staboard side of AFRICAN ZEBRA.

AFRICAN ZEBRA turned around and a lifeboat was launched to relieve the fishermen on NINANITU that was at risk of sinking. But none of the fishermen wanted to board the lifeboat. Via a pilot boat and a Dutch navy ship in the area an alert was raised and a rescue operation was initiated. Both fishermen were rescued by a Swedish rescue helicopter.

La nave "Cerro Alegre" ex "Orlando II", se encontraba de para y fondeado a la gira en la Bahía de Valparaíso, con dotación reducida por reparaciones en su máquina.  Fué afectada por un frente de mal tiempo, con características de temporal con vientos de hasta 55 nudos. El fuerte oleaje y las estrepadas que sufrieron sus cadenas terminaron por cortar el fondeo de la banda de estribor.  La nave comenzó a garrear hasta varar en el borde costero de la bahía sin que su dotación sufriera lesiones ya que fueron rescatados exitosamente por la Autoridad Marítima y Agentes de Seguridad desde tierra.
La nave sufrió perdida total constructiva siendo desguazada en el mismo lugar de varada.

Día 04 julio a 14:16 horas se recepcionó Fax del MRCC MADRID, mediante la cual solicitó la evacuación médica del tripulante señor Fernando MARTINEZ Rodríguez de 45 años de edad, quién sufrió accidente (herida en el ojo izquierda con posible afectación del globo ocular) a bordo del Buque Pesquero CARVISA TRES de bandera española, la misma que se encontraba navegando a 760 millas de costa con rumbo al Puerto de Callao. Un Médico Especialista del Centro Médico Naval realizó la consulta radiomédica desde la Costera Callao, confirmando la necesidad de evacuar al tripulante accidentado, por lo que se dispuso el zarpe de la Fragata Misilera B.A.P. “MARIATEGUI”, un helicóptero SH-3D y la aeronave FOCKER F-60 que efectuó la exploración aeromarítima, el día de 06 julio a 12:50 horas el helicóptero SH-3D efectuó la evacuación del citado tripulante en la posición Latitud 14° 35´ Sur y Longitud 082° 36´ Oeste a 355 millas frente al Puerto Callao, el mismo día a 17:40 horas el helicóptero aterrizó en el Centro Medico Naval con el tripulante evacuado en donde se le brindó atención médica servicio de oftalmología.
Accident while launching a personal water craft (PWC). Victim was riding the craft to the water when the lifting slings failed and he and the PWC dropped into the water.

Location: A 25 MILLAS DE PUNTA INFIERNILLOS - SAN JUAN DE MARCONA
SummaryOfEvents: Día 04 julio a 01:25 horas, se recibió la activación de la radiobaliza en el Sistema COSPAS SARSAT, perteneciente al Remolcador Marítimo CELENDIN 15, en la posición Latitud 15° 04`S y Longitud 075° 53`W, se efectuó comunicación con el propietario señor wilfredo ROMERO, quién informó que su Remolcador zarpó el día 02 julio a 20:00 horas del Puerto Callao en demanda Puerto Mollendo, con CUATRO (04) tripulantes a bordo. CAPISUAN, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía correspondiente, y efectuó coordinaciones con CAPISCO a fin de que disponga el zarpe de la PC-220 CAMANA, asimismo, se dispuso el exploracion aeromarítima con la aeronave FOCKER F-27, la misma que lo ubicó a 15:15 horas en la posición latitud 14° 43`S y longitud 076° 33`W, a 15:50 horas la Patrullera de Costa, establecio contacto con el remolcador y se inició el remolque hacia el Puerto de Pisco, arribando el dia 05 julio a 03:45 horas, con los CUATRO (04) tripulantes en buen estado de salud, tripulantes manifestaron que se quedaron al garete al inundarse la sala de maquinas.

The Hong Kong registered general cargo vessel "Easy Development" departed from Masan, Republic of Korea at 0530 LT on 3 July 2010 with 7694 MT of general cargoes bound for Kuching, Malaysia.
     During the voyage, at 1015 LT in approximate position 34-24.0 N 128-43.5' E, the ship's Bosun reported that one ordinary seaman was found missing.  Before the incident, the missing seaman was working on main deck.  Upon receiving the report, all the crew members were summoned to search round the ship for the missing crew member.  At 1040 LT in approximate position 34-20.5 N 128-41.0 E, the Master directed the vessel back to the suspected crew missing position.  At 1050 LT, the Master tasked the 2nd Officer to contact the Korea Coast Guard and he himself reported the incident to the ship's management company.
     At about 1120 LT, the Korea Coast Guard ship No. 512 arrived the crew missing position.  At about 1200 LT, Easy Development also arrived the scene.  The two vessels carried out search operaion with 4 miles range around the most probable area of crew missing position.  No sign of the missing crew was observed within the search area.
     At about 1720 LT, the Master of Easy Development decided to cease the search operation due to dense fog setting in.  He contacted the Korea Coast Guard ship informing them of his intention and reported the same to the Masan Marine Police and the ship's management company.  After obtaining the permission from the Masan Marine Police and the Korea Coast Guard at 1924 LT, Easy development resumed her voyage for her discharging port, Kuching.

Location: Glensada Carry on Loch Linnhe, Western Scotland
SummaryOfEvents:
On 2 July 2010, a major fire and explosion occurred on board the Panamanian-registered, self unloading (SUL) bulk carrier Yeoman Bontrup during cargo loading. The fire spread rapidly, resulting in significant damage to the ship. Fortunately, injuries were minor.
A routine post-discharge survey identified the need for repairs to Yeoman Bontrup’s cargo discharge hopper, which required hotwork on arrival at the remote Glensanda Quarry on Loch Linnhe.

At 15:19 hrs, a fire was discovered near the bottom of the vertical cargo conveyor belt. Although attempts were made to extinguish the fire, it spread to the adjacent engine room. Overwhelmed by the scale of the fire, the crew evacuated the ship. The fire spread rapidly to the accommodation and into the steering gear compartment, which contained a wide variety of ship’s-use chemicals. A violent explosion followed which tore the poop deck from the ship.

At about 04.31 hours local time on 30 June 2010, the Singapore registered container ship Kota Kado, en-route from Nansha, China to Singapore, ran over and was stranded by the underwater obstruction “Lixin Pai” in approximate position 21º 56.76’ N 114º 04.51’ E in the Dadanwei Shuidao between the Jiapeng Liedao and Dangan Liedao in Chinese waters.

	At the time of the incident, the weather was fine with a light breeze, the sea was calm and the visibility was good, about 6 to 12 nautical miles.

	Following the stranding, Kota Kado sustained water ingress into some of her forward underdeck compartments and the vessel was going down from the head despite continual pumping out of ingress water.  The Master assessed that vessel would be sinking soon, so piloted and anchored the vessel in the shallow water area in Hong Kong waters even though he was not granted permission by the port authority, the Hong Kong Marine Department.
	After anchoring, the ship’s forward part continued to sink and her forward bottom part grounded into the seabed, resulting in No.1, No.2 and No.3 cargo holds flooding with seawater.

	Kota Kado sustained serious hull damage in the forward bottom part.  Many containers in the cargo holds were immersed in water and damaged. There was minor oil pollution, but no casualties were reported.

SOLASStatus: PONTUS: SOLAS, SHING CHANG NO. 5: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0131 hours local time on the 30 June 2010, the Panamanian registered cargo vessel MV “PONTUS”, loaded with a consignment (252 steel coils of DWT 2076 tons) of steel products, collided with a Korean Register sand dredger, the MV SHIN CHANG NO. 5 (referred as SC5 in this report) off the South Korean Southern Coast, about 29 miles south west of Keo-Je Island. At the time of the collision, the SC5 was fully loaded with sea sand, which she had earlier lifted off from the seabed. The collision occurred during reduced visibility in position Latitude 34º 14.78’N Longitude 128º 26.34’E.

The point of contact was directly on the midship starboard side of the PONTUS. The bow of the SC5 contacted onto PONTUS when both vessels took last minute actions to avoid collision. The PONTUS, went to Port and the SC5 when to starboard resulting both vessels converging and collision could not be avoided. At the time of the collision, the visibility was about 200 to 300 metres range.

Location: Left bank of the Paraguai river KM 1515.5, in front of the Port of Ladário/MS
SummaryOfEvents: Shipwreck of the Barge SILO 99B, Bolivian flag, that occurred on 29 June of 2010, around 07.15 hours, at the mooring buoy no. 4, left bank of the Paraguai river KM 1515.5, in front of the Port of Ladário/MS, downstream from Corumbá/MS. At the moment of the sinking, the craft was loaded with approximately 1,600 tons of iron ore.  The craft is not manned. There were no personal damages. The cargo that was on board was totally recuperated. There was no registry of pollution related to the accident.

On 29th June 2010 the general cargo vessel LIVARDEN and the M/V Anette were on opposite courses in narrow waters in Haugesund, Norway. The visibility was very low due to fog. Misjudgement from both ships about maneouevering their vessels resulted in a collision.

Location: Bremerhaven fairway, off the lighhouse Kaiserschleuse lock
SummaryOfEvents: En route to the northern lock in Bremerhaven, the tug Steinbock collided with the Norwegian flagged RoRo ship Minerva, which was travelling downstream the Weser river in the dredged channel in front of the Kaiserschleuse lock on 29 June 2010 at 02:23 hrs. After 6 hours of rest, the crew was awoken at 02:00 hrs and was already casting off at 02:16 hrs. The master was alone on the bridge: the planned lookout was on the way to the bridge after clearing away the mooring lines. The view astern on the tug is severely restricted by the funnel. The tug deviated from her route next to the dredged channel. Unnoticed, she drew closer to the approaching Minerva and came into her bow swell. As a result, the tug heeled severely to starboard and water entered the superstructure. There were slight personal injuries and the hull was dented. The tug was able to reach her berth and moor up under her own power after the collision. The tug was light material damage on the Minerva. She tied up on the Columbus quay.

SOLASStatus: QIANG MIN 1: Unknown/unspecified, WMS AMSTERDAM: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The WMS AMSTERDAM was en route from Qingdao to Japan and the QIANG MIN 1 was en route from Shangai to Jingtang.  At about 0550 hours of 28/6/2010 the ships were engaged in a crossing situation, with the WMS AMSTERDAM to be the give way vessel and the QIANG  MIN 1 to be the stand on vessel. 
Then WMS AMSTERDAM did not take any action, like course alteration, and the QIANG MIN 1 although identified the risk only tried to alert the WMS AMSTERDAM by VHF, in chinese.
Eventually the ships came to a close quartern situation and the evasive manouvres were not effective, and the ships collided.
As a result of the cillisiion the QIANG MIN 1 sank  few hours later, and the crew was rescued by another ship.

Location: At Yiulian Shipyard,  Berth No.3, Shekou Port, Shenzhen, China
SummaryOfEvents: On board the Liberian flag ship Ore Fabrica at Yiulian Shipyard, Berth No. 3, Shekou Port, Shenzhen, China, an ordinary seaman was found lying face down in the cabin bed on 28 June 2010. The conclusion of the investigation indicates no foul play points to a sudden death of the seaman.
The passenger ship ATLANTI foundered whilst berthed at Malaga, Spain on 27 June 2010. It was subsquently raised and sold for breakig up.

El 26 de Junio de 2010 el buque tanque Ceibo se encontraba amadrinado al buque Genco Reliance en zona de Fondeo y Servicios del Río de la Plata con cuatro cabos de amarre pasados (dos en proa y dos en popa) más un tercer cabo en proa para refuerzo. En determinado momento falto el portaespia de su arraigo en la amura de estribor y el cabo que se encontraba hecho firme a dicho poprtaespia golpeó a un tripulante que se encontraba trabajando en la maniobra.

Como producto de las heridas se constató su fallecimiento una vez desembarcado en el Puerto de Montevideo.

Location: A 8 MILLAS FRENTE A PUERTO PIZARRO - TUMBES
SummaryOfEvents: Día 22 junio, siendo las 18:00 horas el señor Ismael MAZA, propietario de la embarcación pesquera SARITA COLONIA, informó que su embarcación se encuentra al garete por fallas mecánicas en el arrancador, aproximadamente a 8 millas frente a Puerto Pizarro, con TRES (03) tripulantes a bordo. CAPIZORI, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, a fin de que las embarcaciones que se encuentran en esa área colaboren con la búsqueda y además se efectuó coordinaciones con la Capitania de Puerto Bolívar – Ecuador, quién el día 23 junio a 08:00 horas dispuso el zarpe de la Lancha Guardacostas SANTA CLARA al área de búsqueda asignada y se ha coordinado con la Aviación Naval de Ecuador a fin de que realice búsqueda vía aérea desde la Isla Santa Clara hasta las 100 millas, el día 23 junio, siendo las 04:00 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PACASMAYO al área de búsqueda asignada, arribando a 19:00 horas con resultados negativos, el día 24 junio arribó por sus propios medios.

At 16 :15 hrs on 21 December 2010 in the port of Gioia Tauro, Italy, an 18 years old trainee on the container ship MSC La Spezia fell from a height of 10 m onto a container in Hatch 2 while he was sweeping the coaming. There were no eyes witnesses. The casualty was treated on board by the crew and paramedics and taken to a hospital, underwent surgery and was later flown by Mediflight to Rostock for further treatment. The casualty is still suffering from pain and use of his arm and spine is restricted. Therefore, he has been forced to abandon his training and the profession can no longer be pursued.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: JEHOVA ES MI PROBEEDOR II: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Día 21 junio, siendo las 12:58 horas, el señor Jesús REYES, propietario de la embarcación pesquera JEHOVA ES MI PROBEEDOR II, informó que su embarcación zarpó el día 15 junio a 06:00 horas del Puerto Bayovar a la zona de pesca área Isla Lobos de Tierra, con TRES (03) tripulantes y que no arribó en la fecha prevista, CAPIPITA, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, a fin de que las embarcaciones que se encuentran en esa área colaboren con la búsqueda. Asimismo, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHICAMA, el día 22 junio, siendo las 17:30 horas, el propietario de la citada embarcación, informó que su embarcación arribó por sus propios medios.

The general cargo ship "BILAL CAVUSOGLU" took water, capsized and sank in the Sea of Marmara, Turkey on 20/06/2010 in heavy weather.
All 5 crew were rescued by coastguard vessel "TCSG-106". No injuries or pollution were reported.

SOLASStatus: HAI JUNG: Unknown/unspecified, JING FENG: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
General cargo vessel MV Jing Feng, after loading 16239 MTS of steel products sailed from port Tianjin at 1154 hrs on 19 June 2010 bound for port Haipong. 
At 1330 hrs Pilot disembarked the vessel and, at 1336hrs full away was given on main engines. At 1404hrs in position 38º 53.2´N 118º08.0´E the course was altered to 106º (T) and the vessel was making 11.6 knots on full sea speed.    
On 20 Jun at 0100 hrs, vessel was on a course 098º (T) making a speed of 12.9 knots. The visibility at this time was reduced to about 4-5 nautical miles.
At 0130hrs, on passing the reporting line of entrance to Laotie Shan traffic lane, the vessel reported her movement to port Dalian VTS (China) and altered her course to 126º (T). She then entered the traffic lane, continuing on full sea speed. The visibility by this time was reduced to 50-100 meters due to fog.
The Bridge was manned by OOW (Second Officer) and a helm’s man. Boson and an Ordinary Seaman were posted on forecastle deck, to keep lookout when visibility reduced. The vessel was taken on hand steering by helm’s man.  The weather was good with light breeze from East at 4-6 knots                                                                                                                                            
At 0140hrs a vessel’s echo was observed on radar by the 2nd officer on watch - 60-70º on the starboard bow at a distance of 7 cables.     
On AIS the vessel was identified as M.V. Hai Jung. On identifying the vessel efforts were made by the 2nd officer on watch to call her on VHF but there was no response.
At this time another vessel crossed the stern from port quarter to starboard quarter at a distance of 8 cables and OOW attended to it. Once passed clear it was observed that Hai Jung approached further close and CPA was seen as Zero on Radar. 
By the time the OOW could assess the situation and take avoidance action, it was too late and collision was inevitable.
There were no maneuvering signals or fog signals displayed by the other vessel whilst attempting to cross the traffic lane from starboard to port and the vessel continued on her course with same speed. 
At 0145 MV Jing Feng altered her course to starboard by giving 10 º helms and later by giving hard over helm to starboard. At 0147 hrs the vessel collided with MV Hai Jung in traffic lane in position 38º 31.3´N 120º 57.01´E.  There was no response or action taken by Hai Jung to avoid collision.

The vessels collided in dense fog weather conditions and, therefore, MV Hai Jung could not be seen by any ship’s crew or the OOW either before or after the collision. The point of contact was not known to any one. It was established that after collision she broke and foundered immediately, as observed by Boson, keeping lookout on forecastle deck. 
At 0148 hrs the Master reached Bridge and put the main engine on emergency stop, notified engine room to change over to maneuvering speed. Crew was sent to check the status of damages suffered by the ship. 
The incident was immediately reported to VTS Dalian and they were requested for assistance in search and rescue operations for the crew of Cambodian registered M.V. Hai Jung which had foundered.
At 0155hrs MV Jing Feng commenced Search and Rescue operations. By 0327 hrs the crew of Jing Feng was able to pick up three crew members (two alive and one crew member dead) and took them on board. 
Master reported that the forepeak tank had flooded up to 8.7 meters and stabilized at that level. 
At 0340 hrs rescue boat of MSA Dalian reached the spot of casualty and managed to recover 4 bodies and transferred the corpse on MV Jing Feng by 0530 hrs.
At 0710 the vessel proceeded to port Dalian as required by Dalian port authorities for further investigations. Master and OOW were arranged to go to Dalian by air to assist in investigation.
On 20 June by 1430 vessel was made all fast to berth at port Dalian for repairs and investigation.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The passenger/ro-ro ship "DONA JUANA" foundered and sank whilst moored off Puerto La Cruz, Venezuela on 20/06/2010 at 0100 Hours. No injuries or pollution were reported.  The vessel had been laid up unmanned for several years. It was lying on port side partially submerged.

Location: In the Atlantic Ocean off Waini
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo ship "CAPT. LLOYD '97" caught fire in the engine room in the Atlantic Ocean off Waini, Guyana at 0900 H on 19/06/2010. All 5 crew sustained burns and abandoned the ship. 4 crew members were rescued by an unknown Venezuealan fishing vessel and taken to hospital in Georgetown, Guyana. The commander was missing, the blaze extinguished and vessel completely burnt out. It was towed to Georgetown.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Le 17 juillet 2010 matin, le KALVIN est en action de pêche avec deux hommes à bord, le patron et son père ; le navire tracte une drague à « escargots », dans le Sud-Est de La Grande Motte à 0,8 mille, sur des fonds d’une dizaine de mètres. Il fait route à l’Ouest/Nord- Ouest à une vitesse moyenne de 5 nœuds. En approche du tombant du Roc, le patron met la barre à gauche pour se positionner vent arrière et relever le train de pêche. 
Soudain, la drague croche brutalement dans un obstacle. Le KALVIN se couche à 90° et chavire quille en l’air en quelques secondes. Le père du patron, qui se trouvait sur le pont, est éjecté à l’eau. Le patron, coincé dans la timonerie, réussit néanmoins à s’extraire du navire qui flotte quille en l’air. Aucun des deux marins ne porte de VFI. Deux navires se trouvent à proximité et se déroutent ; l’un d’eux récupère les naufragés indemnes et les débarque vingt minutes plus tard à La Grande Motte. Le CROSS MED fait intervenir la vedette SNSM du port de La Grande Motte, qui prend en remorque le KALVIN quille en l’air ; le convoi arrive au port de La Grande Motte où le KALVIN est hissé à terre.

El 17 de junio de 2010 siendo las 07:45 el 3er Ing. Efren Guia Lobaina procede a prepara la caldera, durante aproximadamente 20 minutos el Ing. El Ing. xxx estuvo calentando y recirculando el combustible, una vez calentado el combustible encendio el ventilador para la extraccion de gases y a las 08:15 encendio la caldera auxiliar, produciendose la explosion, el aceitero Julio Cesar Telemaco Leon estuvo junto al Ing. Efren Guia Lobaina durante todo el procedimient hasta el momento de la explosion. El Ing. sufrió quemaduras en el tórax, cara y brazo derecho, esto debido a que la ubicación del Ing. era frente a la ventanilla de la caldera auxiliar, la cual al generarse la explosion se revento dejando que la llamas
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SOLASStatus: HAMAKO MARU No. 15: Unknown/unspecified, KEIWA MARU: Unknown/unspecified
Location: In the Inland sea, 6 miles of Northeast of Yoshimi
SummaryOfEvents: The chemical tanker "KEIWA MARU" sank after collision with M/V "HAMAKO MARU No. 15" in the Inland sea 6 miles Northeast of Yoshimi, Japan at 2215 hours on 16/06/2010. All 5 crew members were rescued, 1 crew member was injured and taken to hospital. 2 kilometre oil slick were reported in sea.

A group of 28 persons hired an adventure trip by the company RIB Extreme for a trip with RIB (Rigid Inflatable Boat) in the Stockholm archipelago after their conference had ended.
Slightly delayed, around 17.00 on 16 June, they arrived at the restaurant Strandbryggan, close to the bridge to Djurgârden, where they were supposed to embark the boats.
At the place of embarkation there was a general murmur of people speaking and music playing in the background which made it difficult, if not impossible, to hear the safety briefing for those in the group standing in the rear; one of them was the passenger who was later injured.
Two or three laminated safety notes were handed over to the group for reading during the safety briefing and the later injured passenger had just a glance at it.
After the short briefing, conducted by one of the captains of the four chartered RIBs, the passengers went to the boats and shortly after they departed. The boat that the later injured passenger was sitting in could take six passengers but on this trip there were only five. Two were seated in front of the captain and three were seated behind.
The first 15 minutes they proceeded quite slowly, according to the passenger, until they had caught a passenger ferry up trading between Finland and Sweden. At that point the captain shouted a question, asking if the passengers were ready, increased the speed and jumped in the waves for about 15 minutes. After that he overtook the ferry and turned around to meet the waves.
According to the passenger it felt like a "washboard of waves". After the boat had passed what he thought was the last wave, he sat down but yet another wave came and lifted the boat and the seat hits him from below. He heard a crashing sound in his back, he felt an enormous pain and shouted to the captain to slow down, which the captain did. During the passage to a close by jetty the injured passenger shouted to the captain to slow down due to increasing pain when passing the waves. The passenger's colleague has afterwards told him that he also repeatedly tried to make the captain slow down.
When arriving at the jetty the captain asked him how he was doing and he replied that he was in pain. The other passengers helped him up on the jetty and there he immediately lay down.
Sid 1
After a few minutes he sat up with his hands holding his back and when the captain saw this, he manoeuvred away and continued the trip with the other passengers.

The captain has another view of what happened. After departure and when passing Blockhusudden he increased the speed to about 30 knots on average. He overtook a ferry on its starboard side and suddenly the passenger in front of him shouted and he immediately reduced the speed in order to find out what was wrong. The speed at the time of the accident was 15 to 20 knots according to the captain.
He observed that the passenger was in pain and he manoeuvred the boat back to a close by jetty in order for the passenger to get off the boat. When the passenger was ashore, sitting on a bench, he told the captain that he thought he had strained the muscles in his back.
After consultation with both the injured passenger and his colleague he decided to continue the trip with the other passengers.
The injured passenger suffered compression fracture of number X, XI and XII vertebras.

On June 16, 2010 at approximately 0840LT, the Liberian Flag bulk carrier, SOPHIE OLDENDORFF (IMO No. 9138109) was unloading aggregate at the Port of Tampa, Florida  when a fire broke out in the cargo boom conveyor system.  The crew was mustered and all were accounted for; there were no injuries to the crew.  Approximately fifty feet of the cargo boom at the forward end as well as the accompanying machinery suffered varying degrees of burn and scorched damage, while the remaining length of the cargo boom was destroyed.

SOLASStatus: HEBEI LOYALTY: Unknown/unspecified, HYUNDAI No. 107: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On June 16, 2010 at approximately 0255LT, the  HYUNDAI No. 107 was involved in a collision with Hong Kong flagged bulk carrier, HEBEI LOYALTY  while the HYUNDAI No. 107 was anchored at Eastern Special Purpose Anchorage Bravo “J” in Singapore .  As the HEBEI LOYALTY was maneuvering toward its anchorage, the vessel contacted the anchored HYUNDAI No. 107 on her port bow. There were no injuries to the crew reported. The contact resulted in significant damage to the HYUNDAI No. 107’s port bow, the bunkering pipe and the loss of the anchor. The damage to the bunkering pipe caused two-three litres of oil to escape into the water.

Location: En route from Jersey to Portsmouth
SummaryOfEvents:
At 02:42 hrs on 16 June 2010, a fire was detected on the main vehicle deck of the Bahamas registered ro-ro ferry Commodore Clipper. The ship was on passage from Jersey to Portsmouth and the vehicle deck was loaded with many freight trailers.

The crew identified that an unaccompanied refrigerated trailer unit, powered from the ship electrical supply had caught fire.

The crew contained the fire using the vehicle deck water drenching system and boundary cooling from above, but were not able to extinguish it. Fire damage to unprotected cables and pipework in the main vehicle deck caused extensive disruption to systems, affecting the ship’s ability to manoeuvre and contain the fire. Fire-fighting efforts had to be suspended as cargo debris blocked vehicle deck drains, causing water from the fire-fighting effort to accumulate and reduce the ship’s stability.

SOLASStatus: CS CRANE: SOLAS, FU PING YUAN: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: At 2356 local time on June 15th 2010, China-flagged cargo ship FUPINGYUAN of Qingdao Fupingyuan Shipping Co., LTD, en route from Tianjin, China to Incheon, South Korea with 3343 tons of steel onboard, collided with cargoless Panama-flagged chemical tanker CS.CRANE in Incheon NO.1 inner anchorage (approximate position: 37°19′.41N/126°25′.16E) when she was en route from Ulsan to Incheon, Korea. After collision, FUPINGYUAN sank, certain sea area was polluted, but no fatalities and injuries were caused.

Yuzan, a cargo ship which was sailing to Dandong Port, China, and Liao Dan Yu
23935, a fishing vessel presumed to be in fishing work, collided at 00:55 on June 15,
2010 in a crossing angle of 90 degrees, at 14.5 miles Southeast from Daludao Dengta
Shan lighthouse of Bohai Sea.
From this collision, Liao Dan Yu 23935 sank and two crew members boarded on the
fishing vessel are missing.

The F/V "MAJESTIC BLUE" foundered in the South Pacific Ocean, 925 miles Northwest of American Samoa at 1100 hours on 13/06/2010. 22 crew members abandoned the ship and took a life raft, 2 crew members are missing. The crew were subsequently rescued by F/V "PACIFIC BLUE". US coastguard from air station barbers point diverted a C-130 HERCULES to assist in the search and rescue operation. 3 others fishing vessel also attended the scene. No pollution were reported.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The tanker "GULF SUPER DRY" caught fire in engine room whilst moored at Eemshaven, Netherlands at 0950 Hours on 11/06/2010. The vessel was not viable for repairs and subsequently sold for breaking to unknown interests. The blaze was extinguished with assistance from local fire services. No injuries were reported.

On 10 June 2010, the cargo ship SEAGULL 5 stranded in the Arabian Seaa, off Porbandar, India.  The ship was reported to be damaged beyond economical repair and was sold for breaking up.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

Location: A 20 MILLAS FRENTE A LA ZONA PUNTA MERO - ZORRITOS
SummaryOfEvents: Día 07 junio, siendo las 11:00 horas se recepcionó llamada radial vía canal 16 VHF de la embarcación pesquera DON RICARDO 1 con matricula TA-31165-BM, informando que se encontraba al garete por fallas mecánicas, aproximadamente a 20 millas frente a la zona denominada Punta Mero, con TRES (03) tripulantes a bordo. CAPIZORI, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PACASMAYO, para efectuar tareas de búsqueda y rescate, no pudiendo ubicar a la referida embarcación, el día 09 junio, siendo las 19:00 horas el propietario de la citada embarcación recibió una llamada telefónica del Patrón de la referida embarcación quien le informó que se encontraban fondeados en la posición Latitud 03°33`S y Longitud 080°42`W, por lo que se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PACASMAYO, a 20:20 horas el Remolcador Marítimo CABO BLANCO, ubicó a la embarcación pesquera DON RICARDO-1, remolcándolo hacia la Plataforma CX-11 CORVINA, a 21:30 horas la Patrullera de Costa arribó a la Plataforma en mención de donde se inició el remolque de la citada embarcación hacia la Caleta La Cruz, donde arribaron a 23:30 horas.

THE VESSEL WAS APPROACHING JETTY WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF 3 TUGS. WHEN THE VESSEL WAS ALMOST IN POSITION, IT WAS OBSERVED THAT THE VESSEL STILL HAD AHEAD MOVEMENT, IN SPITE OF THE PROPELLOR PITCH BEING AT 'ZERO'. AT THIS STAGE BEST USE OF STERN PROPULSION AND AFT TUG COULD NOT EFFECTIVELY CONTROL THE VESSEL'S AHEAD MOVEMENT, RESULTING IN THE VESSEL MAKING CONTACT WITH THE STERN OF ANOTHER VESSEL BERTHED AHEAD. THERE WAS NO HULL RUPTURE, NO POLLUTION, NO INJURY.

Location: A 32 MILLAS  FRENTE AL PUERTO DE SALAVERRY
SummaryOfEvents: Día 06 junio, siendo las 14:30 horas, el señor Jhony URIARTE Cáceres, representante de la embarcación pesquera JULIO GERMAN, informó que la citada embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas mecánicas al haber sufrido la rotura del eje de la hélice, en la posición Latitud 08° 39´S y Longitud 079° 25´W. CAPISALA, activó RCC, el día 07 junio, siendo las 09:48 horas, durante las operaciones de búsquela y rescate, la embarcación pesuqera DON JUAN matrícula PL-2734-CM, ubicó a la embarcación pesquera JULIO GERMAN, con SIETE (07) tripulantes a bordo, ambas embarcaciones arribaron a 11:30 horas al Puerto de Malabrigo.

The water tanker "DAFNI" caught fire in engine room whilst moored at Chalki, Greece at 0830H on 02/06/2010. The vessel completely burnt out. All 9 crew members were rescued and no injuries were reported. The local fire services assisted with the firefighting operations but were unable to bring the blaze under control. It was subsequently towed to isolated anchorage outside the port for safety reasons. Some oil pollution were reported in the Sea. The anti-pollution booms were deployed, the blaze eventually extinguished and towed to Piraeus, Greece by tug "AEGEAS" on 4/06/2010.

On 2 June 2010, at 0430 hrs, the carrier SHINPO 18 sank after colliding with the ship BOSOWA VI in the Bali Sea, 21 miles north of Celukan Bawang, Bali, Indonesia.  All 16 crew members were rescued by BOSOWA VI.  There were no injuries reported

Location: ISLA COLA DE SANTA A 11 MILLAS DE COSTA
SummaryOfEvents: Día 02 junio, siendo las 01:18 horas el señor Nemesio TUME, propietario de la embarcación pesquera MI LALY, informó que su embarcación sufrió varadura el día 01 junio a 15:00 horas en la zona denominada Isla de la Cola del Santa, aproximadamente a 11 millas de costa con SIETE (07) tripulantes a bordo, posteriomente siendo las 17:30 horas fueron rescatados CINCO (05) tripulantes por la embarcación pesquera MI ANITA, encontrándose DOS (02) tripulantes desaparecidos señores José RISCO More (46) y Daniel SANTIAGO Espinal (44), asimismo que la embarcación siniestrada fue remolcada al Puerto de Chimbote, CAPIBOTE, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, con la finalidad de que las embarcaciones que operan por la referida zona colaboren con las tareas de búsqueda, el día 02 junio, siendo las 12:50 horas, durante las operaciones de búsqueda y rescate, la embarcación pesquera DOS HERMANOS, rescató el cuerpo sin vida del señor José RISCO More, cuerpo que se encontraba flotando a la altura del cabezo Isla Cola del Santa. Durante los días 02, 03, 04, 07 y 08 junio se efectuó búsqueda en el área de posible ubicación del tripulante señor Daniel SANTIAGO Espinoza, quien a la fecha se encuentra en la condición de desaparecido en la mar.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo ship "HEVEA" foundered in the Atlantic Ocean, South of Soublake, Ivory Coast at 0200 hours on 01/06/2010. Local vessels and 2 UN helicopters effected SAR operation. 16 persons were rescued, 4 dead and 7 misssing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: A 15 MILLAS A LA CUADRA CALETA LOBITOS - TALARA
SummaryOfEvents: Día 02 junio, siendo las 09:00 horas el señor Juan CERNA Soto, propietario de la embarcación pesquera PATRICIA, informó que el día 01 junio a 00:30 horas recibió llamada telefónica del Patrón de la embarcación pesquera PADRE ETERNO, indicándole que su embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas mecánicas (arrancador), en la zona de pesca a 15 millas a la cuadra de la Caleta Lobitos, con CINCO (05) tripulantes a bordo, CAPILARA, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitania, Durante los días 02 y 03 junio, se efectuó búsqueda a bordo de las Patrulleras de Costa CHORRILLOS y PACASMAYO, con resultados negativos, el día 04 junio, siendo las 09:00 horas se recepcionó llamada telefónica de parte de los familiares de los tripulantes de la embarcación al garete, informando que fueron rescatados por la embarcación pesquera NICOL matricula ZS-32472-BM, habiendo arribado ambas embarcaciones a la Caleta Cancas.

On Sunday 30 May 2010, at approximately 12:00 hours, the owner left Doire Fheartha Mor, Carraroe, Co. Galway in his 18ft. timber, outboard engine powered currach to go fishing for mackerel in Greatman’s Bay. Sometime later, he was heading north up the bay past Calladh Thaigue, Carraroe when he fell overboard. His empty boat was spotted from ashore. The owner’s brother and others put to sea to search for him. They found him later floating in the water. All times quoted as local time.

On 30 May 2010, Mr and Mrs X entered the water in their kayaks at the League close to Raheen Town, Co. Cork, Ireland and paddle South South-East, for about 40 minutes until they reached Horse Island.

The pair rested in their Kayak for about 20 minutes observing sea birds and then continued on their journey, leaving the Island from the western side. Shortly thereafter, Mrs X turned and noticed that Mr X was in the water. His kayak was about 10 metres away from him.

Mr X was pronounced dead at the Accident and Emergency in Cork University hospital at 16:50 hrs that evening. Post mortem report gave the cause of death as cardiac failure due to hypertensive cardiomyopathy following immersion on cold water and associated hypothermia, with a medical history of hypertension.

At 08:32 hrs on 29 May 2010 the 3252 gt Norwegian registered platform supply (PSV), Skandi Foula, made heavy contact with the moored Panamanian registered supply ship OMS Resolution, in Victoria Dock, Aberdeen

On the 27 May 2010 at 09.00 am the passenger vessel Juno departed from Gothenburg
with 27 passengers and 11 crew members on board. The destination was Stockholm via
Gota kanal
Gota kanal stretches from Sjòtorp at lake Vânern to Mem in the Baltic Sea and is
managed by Gota kanal AB (Kanalbolaget). West of Sôderkôping, the channel passes an
area called Klevbrinken where a guest harbor, a camping site and a place for winter
docking of boats are located on the north bank. After the harbor, towards Sôderkôping, at
an old bridge abutment on the north side the channel, the width temporarily decreases from
approximately 25 to 14 meters. This area is known to cause a bank effect for the vessels
passing. Bank effect can be described as unequal latéral forces on a ship in narrow areas.
The old bridge abutment was not part of the guest harbor and it was according to
régulations prohibited for boats to moor there. Kanalbolaget allowed boats to be moored
in the harbor 14 days free of charge in conjunction with launching or docking.
The sailing boat Bolero was launched in Klevbrinken after winter Storage on the 19th May
2010. It was moored at the old bridge abutment since there was no space in the harbor.
On the 29t h at approximately 07.20 pm, Juno left the lower locks of Duvkullen and
continued towards Sôderkôping. The Chief Offîcer was conning the ship, an Able seaman
was lookout and the Master had just come up to the wheelhouse. The crew on board Juno
noticed that the harbor was full of boats and that a sailing boat was moored at the bridge
abutment. The Chief Offîcer and the Master discussed the situation and realized that it
would be a tight passage but decided to do it anyway as there were no other alternatives.
If they stopped there was a risk that Juno would have drifted across the channel and
collided with the boats moored in the guest harbor.
The Chief Offîcer slowed down and kept more south in the channel. Just before the
abutment the bank effect caused Juno to turn to port towards the sailing boat. The Chief
Offîcer put the rudder hard to starboard and gave a kick on the engine in an attempt to
stop the turn. When he realized that a collision could not be avoided, he put the engine
control handles to full astern to stop the ship. At 07.30 pm Juno collided with the Bolero
which suffered extensive damage to its hull and took in water. There were no persons on
board the Bolero at the time of the collision. On board Juno the roof above the portside
bridge wing was slightly damaged when it was hit by the mast of the sailing boat.

On 28th May 2010 the Panamanian bulk carrier TRIPLE STAR struck the shore elevator and sustained damage to starboard side lifeboat and accommodation ladder whilst departing berth 17 at Three Rivers, Quebec.

The ADRIATIC ARROW stranded at Khor Al-Zubair, Iraq on 28 May 2010. It was refloated on 15 July and subsequently inspected. It was declared not financially viable for repairs and was broken up at Gadani beach, Pakistan on 15 March 2011. No injuries or pollution was reported.

M/V “ AANN” INCIDENTAL REPORT FROM AGENT M/S INCHCAPE SHIPPING DOHA. 
0900/25th: The following message received from the MV “AANN” on VHF radio Ch-14 

Vessel is in her voyage from India to Doha , present location is 2.6 Nautical Miles North East of Halul Island , the vessel is taking water in the cargo tank and she is listing 7 deg to starboard,  The vessel is intending to drop anchor at Halul. 

Advised the captain not to drop anchor around Halul except the designated Tanker Anchorage due to the existence of pipelines, 
The vessel don’t have proper BA chart onboard to lead him to the Tanker Anchorage, position of the Tanker anchorage (Lat 25  40.8N, Long : 052  27.3E), 

The captain is not sure what type of assistance he may required, he will Know only after he drop the anchor. 
The marine Vessel "Zakher Duty" is on standby at Halul . 

Vessel Name        : “AANN” 
Type of Ship         : steel hull cargo ship 
Owners                 : Sea link international Shipping – UAE 
Agent                    : Inchcape shipping – Doha Qatar 
Length over all       : 72.45M 
Cargo                    : 2000tonns jumbo bag of fly ashes 
Crew                     : Total 11 (2 Russian, 2 Srilankans, 3 Bangladeshi, 5 Indians) 
Last position          : at 0930/25th; lat: 25  45.6N,  Long:  052  32.5E ) 
Course                  : 230 deg.  Speed: 5 Kts. 

1048/25th :   MV “AANN” arrived 2 NM North East of Halul, and decided not to drop his anchor in the position given and decided to come closer to the island for shelter and requested to drop his anchor in sheltered area, 

1127/25th “   Zakher Duty” deployed a marker buoy in position; (Lat: 25  40.4N , Long: 052 25.3E ) for MV “ AANN” to deploy her anchor. ( Zakher Duty on  stand by) 

1142/25th :  MV “AANN” dropped anchor Lat: 25  40.4N , Long: 052 25.3E, after some time the anchor started dragging, the Capt. Recovered the anchor. 

1400/25Th : MV “AANN” dropped anchor for the second time in position  Lat: 25  40.4N , Long: 052 25.3E, after some time the anchor started dragging again. the Capt. recovered the anchor and waited for assistance. 

1415/25th : M/V “AANN” situation is stable, the list is still 4 deg to starboard, they recon the list is caused by cargo that has shifted to starboard due to weather. 

They pumped out the water from the cargo hold, last sounding was 5cm, they are monitoring the water ingress every 30minutes. 

No assistance from Halul Marine is required, the ship owners are arrangement for divers and other assistance may require. 

1530/25Th “ AL MAHA extended the length of the pick up rope on M/Buoy No. 22, so M/V “ AANN” can pick up the buoy rope 

1545/25Th “MV “AANN” secured to the M/Buoy No. 22, situation is the same as reported at 1400/25th. 

1800/25Th : M/V” AANN” situation is the same as reported at 1400/25th.The Capt instructed by Halul Marine to listen on VHF CH. 09 and to report to Halul Radio if the situation changed or if required any  other assistance. and the Marine Boats “Zakher Duty” & “WASSIT” on stand by for assistance. 

No calls or any update recieved from the vessel during night time. 

0542/26Th : “ Halul Marine called  M/V “ AANN” on VHF and asked for any updated, the Capt reported the following: 
(AANN is  listing to starboard about 9 deg, Bilge level in Starboard cargo Hatch level is 84cm and increasing, 
The Capt. Requesting immediate diving assistance, some of his crew thinking to abandon the ship. 

0545/26Th : QP Diving Support Vessel “ Khattaf” on stand by for assistance., ROV check carried out but due to thick sea growth on the hull cannot detect the damage on the hull 

additionally The following Marine Vessels mobilized to assist as required : "Zakher duty" , "Wassit", "AL MAHA", "AL DANA", "Halul-31", "Halul-26". 
0727/26Th: M/V “ AANN” : Captain Decided to abandon ship as the ship is listing by 10 deg. to Starboard and the list is increasing gradually, the Captain was advised to carry with him all the ship & Crew documents including ship plans, stability book charts passports, log book …….etc. 

0730/26Th : M/V “ AANN” Capt reported 9.8MT Diesel oil in ship tanks, 430Ltrs Lube oil in drums and 200Ltrs Hyd. oil in drums. 

0745/26Th : M/V “ AANN” Capt asked if he can beach the vessel on Halul island. 

0808/26Th : M/V “ AANN” all crew 11 Persons abandoned the ship and was picked up by DSV “ KHATTAF” 

0825/26Th : M/V “ AANN” capsized on her starboard side , about 120 deg, still attached to the buoy and partly afloat in position : (Lat: 25  39’  55.4” N, Long: 052  25’  38.0” E) , ( N2839172, E643249) 

0945/26th May 2010: M/V “AANN” all crew 11 Persons landed at Halul and handed over to the Navy & Security.

SOLASStatus: BUNGA KELANA 3: Unknown/unspecified, MV WAILY: Unknown/unspecified, WAILY: SOLAS
Location: 13 kilometres southeast of Changai East, Singapore
SummaryOfEvents:
On 25 May 2010, the oil tanker BUNGA KELANA 3, carrying 62,000 metric tonnes of Bintulu light crude oil and condensate, collided with the bulk carrier WAILY,  in the Singapore Strait at 06.00 hours LT. The incident occurred 13kms southeast of Changi East when the bow of the bulk carrier WAILY struck the oil tanker BUNGA KELANA 3, as it was travelling in the Singapore Strait. No reports of injuries to crew members, but the oil tanker BUNGA KELANA 3 suffered damage to one of its cargo tanks. Resulting in a 10m tear in the left side of the tanker, which caused 2,500 metric tonnes of light crude oil being spilled into the sea at the location of the collision. Current reports indicate an oil slick ti the size of 4km by 1 km.
Both ships are currently anchored in the Singapore Strait.

Día 24 mayo, siendo las 10:00 horas el señor Eladio SEMINARIO, familiar de los tripulantes de la embarcación pesquera JOSE LUIS, la misma que zarpó del Puerto de Paita el día 20 mayo con destino a la zona de pesca, habiendo sido avistada por ultima vez el día 22 mayo a 20:00 horas en faenas de pesca, no arribó en la fecha prevista, CAPIPITA, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, el día 25 mayo a 18:00 horas el señor xxx, informó que la embarcación pesquera SIEMPRE CON DIOS, ubicó a la embarcación pesquera JOSE LUIS en la posición Latitud 03° 35’ S y Longitud 082° 00’ W, posteriormente y después de solucionar los problemas mecánicos, ambas embarcaciones pesqueras arribaron el día 27 mayo a 09:50 horas.

On 20 May 2010, the vessel completed the loading operations in the port of Rostov-nas-Donu.  Following the finalisation of all formalities, the vessel set sail with a cargo of grain to the discharge port of Beirut.

The voyage was uneventful until 24 May 2010.  After clearing the Dardanelles passage, the master handed over the watch to the second mate at 2400.  After several checks, the master retired to his cabin at about 0130.  Both main engines were running smooth.  Visibility was good with calm seas.  The vessel had the port side radar running, whilst the GPS was giving a speed of approximately 7.5 knots.  About 30 minutes prior to the grounding, the second mate altered course from a southerly heading.
At this point, the full disk capacity alarm on the INMARSAT-C unit was activated.  The second mate investigated the alarm and subsequently started to check and clean the messages from the disk.  Whilst investigating the matter, he noticed that the vessel was very close to a small island.  At about 0328, he called the master to inform him of the situation.  However, before making to the bridge, the master felt the ship vibrate and heard the noise of metal against te seabed.  The vessel had ran aground at a speed of about seven knots, near Lesvos Island, Greece in position 390 19’N  260 26.6’E.

Although the propulsion system did not sustain any damages, the vessel sustained deformation and cracks on part of her bottom shell plating.

Location: Norweigan Sea, 24 miles NW of Smola, Norway
SummaryOfEvents: On 24 May 2010, at 0040 hrs, chemical tanker ONARFJELL caught fire in the accommodation area, in the Norwegian Sea, 24 miles NW of Smola, Norway. An electrical fault is said to have caused the fire.  Unknown ships, AHTS HAVILA MERCURY and 2 other ships assisted at the scene.  All 13 crew members were rescued with no injuries reported.  ONARFJELL sustained serious damage to its accommodation and bridge area.  ONARFJELL was later towed by HAVILA MERCURY to Kristiansund, Norway for inspection and then on to Haugesund, Norway on 16 October 2010 by tug STADT TUG where it eventually arrived at Alang on 20 January 2011 where it was classified beyond economical repair and broken up.

On 23 May 2010 the general-purpose oilfield support vessel Marsol Pride was conducting underwater operations within the Tui oil and gas field off the west coast of New Zealand. The Marsol Pride was fitted with a fixed carbon dioxide (CO2) fire smothering system for its engine room. Late that night a valve on one of the CO2 pilot cylinders developed a leak and charged the system ready for release. A second leak in the main control valve then caused the entire system to activate resulting in an uncontrolled release of CO2 gas into the engine room.

An automatic alarm in the engine room had warned the duty engineer there of the impending release so he had left the engine room to investigate the reason for the alarm. The incident caused one of the 2 main propulsion engines to shut down due to air starvation; other than that there was no damage to the vessel and no one was injured.

Two men departed from Helvick Pier, Co. Waterford on 23 May 2010 in a small RIB to go to angling close to Helvick Head. The alarm was raised when the RIB was seen drifting and empty with one man close-by in the water. Both men were lost overboard and their remains were recovered on 25 May 2010.

Location: at the "Bard Offshore 1" wind farm about 50 nm north-west of Borkum
SummaryOfEvents: At 12:33 hrs on 23 May 2010, an accident involving the shipboard heavy crane occurred on the Wind Lift 1, an installation ship for offshore wind turbines, in the offshore wind farm “Bard 1” about 50 nm north-west of Borkum. The ship was flying the flag of Germany. The ship had elevated herself from the water independently by lowering four legs and in so doing had become a working platform connected with the seabed (so-called self elevating unit). Using the heavy crane, an iron pipe (so-called “pile”) of 85 metres in length weighing 425 tonnes and with a diameter of about 3.5 metres was to be lowered into the water in a vertical position, where together with two other pipes of the same dimension and with about half of it driven into the seabed, it was to be used as the foundation of a wind turbine. In executing this task, the upper end of pipe, which was lying alongside, was grasped by the heavy crane by means of a hydraulic grab and raised on one side. At an elevation angle of about 35 degrees and a height of about 40 metres, the pipe suddenly slipped out of the grab and fell with great force back onto the deck of the ship. Three people on deck were slightly injured while trying to move to safety and/or falling due to vibration.  The superstructure sustained heavy material damage. The pile’s direction of fall and the fact that at midday there were only a few people on deck prevented the consequences from being more severe.

The owner went fishing in his Arvor 18 sport boat on the morning of the 22 May 2010. It is known that he had returned from the fishing trip and was securing the boat on its mooring in Mulranny Harbour, Co. Mayo at 12:11 hrs.

At approximately 13:00 hrs, the owner was found dangling over the bow of his boat with his head and upper body in the water. Local persons went to his assistance and brought him ashore where CPR was carried out. The CPR was unsuccessful and the owner was pronounced dead at the scene.

On 21st May 2010 the ro/ro vessel DUBAI MOON was caught in a tropical storm which then turned into a cyclone west of Jazirat Samhah. The vessel listed heavily with its cargo of vehicles crashing around the deck. HMS Chatham was in the area and when the weather improved slightly the warship launched a Lynx helicopter and, in an operation that lasted for over 3 hours, the 23 crew members were winched by helicopter to safety from the Dubai Moon and transferred to Suqutra Island. The Dubai Moon sank shortly afterwards.

Location: FRENTE A LA ISLA SAN LORENZO - CALLAO
SummaryOfEvents: Día 21 mayo, siendo las 15:00 horas la Oficina de Tráfico Marítimo Callao, recepcionó llamada radial de la embarcación pesquera MARIA SOCORRO-I con matricula CE-3057-BM, informando que sufrió varadura en la posición Latitud 12° 03’ S y Longitud 077° 11’ W, frente a la Isla San Lorenzo, CAPICALA dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa SAMA, al arribar a la zona de siniestro observó que la embarcación pesquera BELISSA, se encontraba prestando auxilio a la tripulación, efectuando la Patrullera el rescate de los OCHO (08) tripulantes quienes fueron traslados al Terminal Pesquero del Callao.

Location: FRENTE A LA CALETA MANCORA - TALARA
SummaryOfEvents: Día 20 mayo, siendo las 09:00 horas, la señora Luz HERRERA, familiar del Patrón de la embarcación pesquera CUTRIÑO con matricula PT-27726-BM, informó que citada embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas mecánicas en la posición Latitud 04° 02`S y Longitud 081° 15`W, con SEIS (06) tripulantes a bordo, CAPILARA, dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHORRILLOS, a 14:50 horas se ubicó a la mencionada embarcación en la posición Lat. 03° 59`W y Long. 081° 07`W, efectuando el remolque hacia la Caleta Máncora, donde arribó a 16:30 horas.

Día 20 mayo a 02:50 horas, la señora xxx, propietaria de la embarcación pesquera LOURDES CAROLINA, con matricula TA-12325-BM, informó que el Patrón de su embarcación le comunicó que se encuentran al garete por problemas eléctricos, con CINCO (05) tripulantes a bordo, CAPILARA, dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHORRILLOS, a 09:30 horas se ubicó a la referida embarcación en la posición Lat. 04° 36`S y Long. 081° 24’ W, la misma que estaba siendo remolcada por la embarcación CARA SUCIA, arribando a 11:00 horas al desembarcadero artesanal del puerto de Talara.

On 18 May 2010 at 1255 hrs, the tug PHILADELPHIA collided with the ship RHEIN BRIDGE in the Bitter Lakes, Suez Canal, Egypt and sustained 1.5 metre gash in the port hull.  The quantity of oil spilled into the water is unknown.  A clean-up operation was effected.  No injuries were reported.  The ship was anchored for inspection and subsequently sold for breaking up.

On 17 May 2010 two crew members were killed and two others seriously injured when one lifeboat on the drillship Ocean Ambassador, IMO 8752556, call sign V7FZ9, Marshall Islands flag, built 1975, became detached from its falls during a lifeboat drill. The lifeboat fell upside down into the sea approximately 15 metres below. There was no pollution and the accident is under investigation by the Brazilian Maritime Authority.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: A 40 MILLAS A LA CUADRA DE LA CALETA CERRO AZUL - PISCO
SummaryOfEvents: Día 17 mayo, siendo las 01:26 horas se recibió señal de activación de radiobaliza en el Sistema COSPAS SARSAT, de la embarcación pesquera ROSA SONIA, con matricula PS-26309-BM, se efectuó llamada telefónica al propietario sin respuesta, CAPISCO activó RCC, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CAMANA, con destino a la zona de activación de radiobaliza, siendo las 14:35 horas del mismo día, en la posición Lat. 13º 00’ S. Long. 077º 09’ W la PC-220 ubicó a la referida embarcación la misma que se encontraba semi hundida, con CUATRO (04) tripulantes a bordo, quienes fueron rescatados y trasladados al balneario de Pucusana donde arribaron a 17:50 horas.

Location: A 20 MILLAS FRENTE A LA CALETA CABO BLANCO - TALARA
SummaryOfEvents: Día 16 mayo 2010, siendo las 15:00 horas el señor xxx, informó que la embarcación pesquera JUAN PASTOR, zarpo de la caleta Constante con rumbo al Puerto Talara donde no ha arribado en la fecha prevista, CAPILARA activó RCC, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHORRILLOS, a efectuar la búsqueda, el día 18 mayo siendo las 09:15 horas, la Patrullera de Costa ubicó a la referida embarcación a 20 millas frente a la caleta de Cabo Blanco, con TRES (03) tripulantes a bordo, siendo remolcada al Puerto de Talara.

Location: In the Caspian Sea, 80 miles southeast of Makhachkala
SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel "KAPITAN YEVSEYEV" developed list and sank in the Caspian sea, 80 miles southeast of Makhachkala, Russia at 1118 hours on 16/05/2010 whilst under tow of F/V "TYULEN-10". Two crew members were rescued by "TYULEN-10". No injuries or pollution were reported. The vessel was being towed to repair in Baku, Azerbaijan.

On 16th May 2010 the gas tanker BRITISH SAPPHIRE was launching a fast rescue craft off the coast of Darwin, Australia. However, the crew lost control of the craft as it was lowered into the water,  and all 3 persons on board were injured.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Off Grenore Point, Rosslare, Co. Wexford
SummaryOfEvents: On 15 May 2010 the Irish Coast Guard was alerted to an incident, which had occurred off Greenore Point, Co. Wesford. The report indicated that a small ship had foundered and that a crew member was missing at sea. The casualty was subsequently recovered.

The general cargo ship "EMELIE" stranded 1 mile East of Durres, Albania on 15/05/2010. It subsequently was broken up at Aliaga, Turkey on 17/11/2010. No injuries or pollution were reported. A refloating operation were effected.

Location: Gulf of Tonkin, 3 miles East of Hon Dau Island, Vietnam
SummaryOfEvents: On 14 May 2010, at 0840 hrs, the cargo ship SHUN AN XING developed list to starboard and sank in the Gulf of Tonkin, 3 miles east of Hon Dau Island, Haiphong, Vietnam.  All 18 crew members and 2 pilots were rescued, with no injuries reported.  A serious oil pollution was reported at sea.  A clean-up operation was effected.

Location: southern part of Bay of Bengal
InitialEvent: The death of the Steward on the vessel
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 1650 local time on 13 May 2010, the Steward of the Hong Kong registered bulk carrier Genco Carrier fell from near the top of the stairway outside the galley down to the floor of one deck below outside the dry provision storeroom while he was carrying a pile of bowls about 10 to 12 pieces with both hands and ascending the stairs to the galley.  Just before the incident, the vessel experienced a sudden and swift rolling movement which caused the Steward lose his balance and fall.  As a result, the Steward suffered serious head injury with blood bleeding from his mouth and nose.  Despite immediate and continuous shipboard first aid and medical treatments, the Steward passed away at 1855 local time on the same day.
     At the time of the incident, the vessel was carrying a cargo of iron ore and en-route from India to China via Malaca and Singapore Strait.  The incident occurred while the vessel was at sea in approximate position 06° 06.3’ N 090° 01.3’ E about 300 nautical miles to the west of the Malaca Strait.
     The weather was fine.  The sky was cloudy.  The visibility was about 7 nm.  The wind was southwestly with force 4.  The sea state was slight to moderate with swell of wave height about 1.5 metres.
     The investigation revealed the following contributing factor:
     The Code of Safe Working Practice for Merchant Seamen (COSWP) was not observed and followed by the Steward who was walking upstairs with both his hands holding a pile of bowls rendering him no free hand to grasp the handrail when he lost his balance and fell to his death as the vessel suddenly rolled swiftly from one side to the other in the prevailing winds and swells.

On May 12, 2010 at approximately 0458LT, the Liberian Flag container vessel, YM CYPRESS was involved in a collision with the Coast Guard vessel from Taiwan, China, CG-126, while transiting from Kaohsiung to Keelung, Taiwan, China . The YM CYPRESS was transiting in a high traffic area and had altered course to avoid some fishing vessels. The YM CYPRESS then resumed her original course when the CG-126 was noted to be on her starboard bow. The CG-126 altered her course to starboard with a distance of two miles between herself and the YM CYPRESS and was deemed to be crossing in front of the YM CYPRESS. The YM CYPRESS moved to port to attempt to avoid a collision with the CG-12; however the maneuver was ineffective and the two vessels collided.

Día 11 mayo, siendo las 11:30 horas se recepcionó llamada telefónica del representante de la empresa pesquera DIAMANTE S.A., informando que la Chata SAN ANTONIO II, matrícula SE-12182-AM, sufrió incendio en la bahia de Supe, de inmediato se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PUNTA ARENAS, en apoyo al personal de la citada empresa a 12:45 horas se controló el incendio.
The passenger ship "KAMELIA I" foundered at Eleusis, Greece on 11/05/2010. No injuries or pollution were reported. The vessel was lying in SITU and submerged at moorings at Eleusis.

Location: A LA CUADRA DE COLA DE SANTA - CHIMBOTE
SummaryOfEvents: Día 15 mayo, siendo las 10:52 horas se recibió señal de activación de radiobaliza en el Sistema COSPAS SARSAT, de la embarcación pesquera DOÑA ROXANA II, con matrícula PL-19965-CM, por lo que se efectuó llamadas telefónicas al propietario sin respuesta. CAPIBOTE activó RCC. Siendo las 12:45 horas del mismo día, el representante de la referida embarcación informó que su embarcación sufrió hundimiento total en la posición Lat. 09º 05’ S y Long. 078º 49’ W a la altura de Cola del Santa, habiendo sido rescatada la tripulación por la embarcación pesquera YAMANASHI.

Location: Off the Coast of Fujairah, United Arab Emirates
SummaryOfEvents: On May 5, 2010 at approximately 14.15 hours LT, the Liberian Flag container vessel, LISSY SCHULTE  suffered an engine room explosion approximately 35 nautical miles off the coast of Fujairah, United Arab Emirates. The Master stated that he heard a pop, felt the vessel lurch forward, and then the the electricity was cut off. The Master realized that the engine room was destroyed and ordered the auxiliary generator to be stopped so as not to cause electrocution or fire. A Mayday was broadcast on VHF and assistance was rendered by local United Arab Emirates and Iranian authorities. Four crew members of the LISSY SHULTE were seriously injured and one crew member (messman) died as a result of the explosion. No pollution was reported; however, the vessel sustained heavy damages and was towed to the Port of Jebel Ali.  A flag state investigating officer was appointed to attend the vessel and conduct an on-scene investigation.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately 07:08 hours on 06 May 2010, a male passenger on a Delta 8.5m rigid inflatable boat (RIB) suffered lower back compression fractures while the boat was transporting him, with fellow workers, to a jack-up rig on River Thames. The injury occurred as the passenger landed heavily on a locker lid, where he had been sitting, after he had been momentarily lifted off the lid due to the motion of the craft. 

After the accident, the passenger was landed ashore and taken to hospital, where he received prompt attention for his injuries. He was subsequently fitted with an external body support brace and was still receiving physiotherapy treatment at the time this report was published, some 8 months after the accident.

Location: 9 Miles NW of Himeshima, Oita, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 May 2010, at 0430 hrs, the carrier SOYA MARU No. 5, collided with the ship QING SHUN and sank in the inland sea, 9 miles NW of Himeshima, Oita, Japan.  All four crew members abandoned ship to liferafts and were subsequently rescued.  No injuries were reported.  A 500 metre oil slick was reported at sea.

Día 09 mayo a 23:30 horas el Operador Estación Costera Mollendo, recepcionó comunicación frecuencia 8255 de la embarcación pesquera MACO II, la misma que recepcionó comunicación radial de la embarcación pesquera DOÑA MERCEDES II, informando que se encuentra al garete por posible rotura de cigüeñal en el motor, en la posición Lat. 18° 14´S y Long. 073° 00´W, CAPILO, activó RCC, el día 10 mayo a 10:25 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera Marítima RIO ZAÑA al punto de emergencia, el día 11 mayo a 00:30 horas la Patrullera Marítima, efectuó contacto visual con la citada embarcación, a 01:40 horas, rescato a los CUATRO (04) tripulantes, a 19:55 horas la Patrullera Marítima arribó al Puerto de Ilo, remolcando a la embarcación pesquera DOÑA MERCEDES II.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 9 May 2010, the stern trawler NUEVO APENINO sustained a leak in the hull, took water and sank 60 miles NW of Nouakchott, Mauritania.  All 16 crew members abandoned sip to liferafts and were rescued the following day by 3 fishing ships NUEVO ARTIS, LORE MAR and ALCALDE I.  Four Spanish crew members were transferred to the hospital ship ESPERANZA EL MAR and taken to Arguineguin, Las Palmas.  There were no injuries or pollution reported.

SOLASStatus: C. VISION: SOLAS, ZHE LING YU 23594: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Cargo ship C.VISION proceeding to dangjin port, korea to discharge cargo from brazil.
And she collided with chinese fishing vessel.
Then chinese fishing vessel sunk and 6 fisher mans died and 1 fisher man lost.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Le 6 mai 2010 matin, le Talisman appareille du port du Guilvinec pour sa première marée après réparation des dégâts de l’incendie du 15 avril 2010. Il met en pêche le même jour à 16h30. Le 3ème trait de chalut débute le 07 mai à 04h15. A 07h30, le navire se trouvant dans le Sud-Ouest de la pointe de Penmarc’h, le patron prend son quart à la passerelle. Vers 08h30, il perçoit une odeur de fumée, puis l’alarme incendie machine se déclenche.
Il alerte aussitôt les hommes d’équipage et constate que le compartiment est envahi par la fumée. Le chef mécanicien envoie la charge de CO2 de l’installation d’extinction fixe dans le compartiment machine. La ventilation mécanique stoppe automatiquement, mais la présence d’une épaisse fumée empêche la mise en place des volets d’obturation de la ventilation machine.
L’équipage se prépare à évacuer. Le CROSS Etel, alerté via un navire sur zone relayé par le CROSS Corsen, dépêche sur zone des moyens importants. L’incendie étant devenu incontrôlable, le patron stoppe le moteur et ordonne d’abandonner le navire. L’équipage met à l’eau les deux radeaux de survie et y embarque au complet : la mer est belle et le vent faible. A cet instant, le Talisman est en flammes. A 09h30, l’équipage du TALISMAN est recueilli par le palangrier espagnol Mariva Vidal. A 10h28, les quatre rescapés, sains et saufs, sont hélitreuillés et acheminés vers la BAN Lanvéoc Poulmic. Le Talisman sombre à 15h35.

The trawler "HIMA-PECHE II" caught fire and subsequently sank 12 miles east of Puerto de la Luz, Canary Islands at 0300 hours on 07/05/2010. The fire started at 1115 hours on 06/05/2010 whilst moored in Puerto de la Luz harbour. The vessel had been laid up for 2 years. It was towed out to sea by coastguard PCV "MIGUEL DE CERVANTES" and 2 tugs for safety reasons. The blaze could not be controlled and subsequently sank. No injuries were reported. The fire started when illegal stowaways who had been occupying the vessel attempted to cook some food.

Vessel was engaged in discharge of coal at Wedel Vitton Fall power plant jetty. An intermediate survey and testing of the auxiliary boiler plant was conducted in the morning by a DNV Surveyor. In addition, 3 crew members, namely Third Engineer, Engine Cadet and Electrician Officer were also present. The boiler work had finished and the Safety valves had been floated in the presence of Class. The safety cutouts of the boiler were started and stopped approximately 12-5 times without any abnormalties. At this point, in accordance with the Chief Engineer's explanation, while running in automatic mode, all relevant safety valves and safety alarms and devices were tested and found ok.

Afterwards, the boiler was turned into manual mode (as used in emergency situations) by the operator with a key switch on the operational panel. Then the boiler was pre purged before being lit to carry out one more test. The intention of the surveyor was to check one (1) remaining item, ie Low level alarm in the boiler drum and due to this cut off fuel to the burner. Unfortuantely, it appeared that the pre purging was insufficient and there was a flash back situation when the crew started the manual operation ignition procedure. It was during these tests, that the boiler back fired resulting in an explosion in the combustion chamber. All three (3) crew members and attending Surveyor sustained severe burns and were transported into specialist hospital Boberg. 

As a consequence of the expolsion, the complete door with the burner and the adjacent equipment were opened. Both bolts of the locking devices of the door were broken and the support of the electric motor for the atomizing the fuel was craked, resulting in damage to the motor as well.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Día 05 mayo, a 09:00 horas se recepcionó Protesta de Mar, presentado por el señor xxx, propietario de la embarcación pesquera PADRE ETERNO, informando que su embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas mecánicas aproximadamente a 15 millas frente al Puerto de Talara, con CINCO (05) tripulantes abordo, CAPILARA activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanías, a fin de que las embarcaciones del área colaboren con la búsqueda, el día 06 mayo a 10:20 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PACASMAYO, al área de búsqueda asignada, a 20:05 horas la Patrullera de Costa, ubicó a la citada embarcación pesquera, navegando por sus propios medios hacia caleta Acapulco, procediendo escoltar hasta su arribo a la citada Caleta.

On 4 May 2010, at 1622 hrs, the cargo ship PING YANG No. 1 collided with ship KENOS ATHENA off Busan, Republic of Korea and subsequently sank at 1640 hrs the same day.  Nine crew members were rescued, with 1 missing.  Oil pollution was reported and a cleaning operation was effected.

Dia 04 Mayo, siendo las 09:00 horas, se recepcionó la Protesta de Mar, presentado por el señor xxx, representante de la embarcación pesquera R-4, quien informó que la citada embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas mecánicas en la posición Latitud 04° 47`S y Longitud 081° 30´W, con SEIS (06) tripulantes a bordo. CAPILARA, activó RCC, a 09:40 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHORRILLOS, a 11:15 horas la Patrullera de Costa ubicó a la citada embarcación en la posicion antes señalada, siendo remolcada por la embarcación pesquera MI PADRE YAVET, a 17:00 horas arribaron ambas embarcaciones al Puerto de Talara, escoltado por la Patrullera de Costa.

InitialEvent: Double fatality resulting from enclosed space entry
SummaryOfEvents:
On the afternoon of 3 May 2010, the bulk log carrier TPC Wellington was loading logs in Port Marsden, Northland. When the chief officer entered a cargo hold that was full of logs that had been loaded at a previous port, he rapidly lost useful consciousness (lost the ability to hold on to the ladder) and fell from the ladder onto the cargo below. 
The ship's bosun had accompanied the chief officer to the cargo hold access and when the chief officer fell he alerted nearby deck crew before leaving to collect rescue equipment. One of the nearby crew members went to the hold access and on seeing the unconscious chief officer below, entered the hold with the intention of rescuing him. He too rapidly lost useful consciousness and fell from the ladder onto the cargo below. 
The 2 crew members lost useful consciousness owing to the combined effects of an oxygen-depleted atmosphere and the likely presence of toxic gases, both consequences of the organic decomposition of the logs in the closed cargo hold. The oxygen levels in the cargo hold were as low as 1% to 3%, which would cause loss of effective consciousness within 3 to 9 seconds, and total unconsciousness very soon afterwards, followed by death within 5 minutes. Both crew members were pronounced dead at the scene after they had been rescued from the hold access. 
The dangers of the organic decomposition of logs and other organic cargos in enclosed spaces are well known in the international maritime community, and were documented on board the TPC Wellington, but in spite of this the high risk this posed to the crew had not been identified, no specific training had been given to the crew members to heighten their awareness of the risk, and no emergency drills had been conducted in recent times for rescue from enclosed spaces. 
The emergency response by the ship's crew to the accident was not well co-ordinated, which reduced the possibility of saving the lives of the 2 men in the cargo hold. 
Internationally a disproportionately high number of deaths attributable to entry into enclosed spaces has prompted a review by the International Maritime Organisation of what can be done to improve safety in this area. The Commission has not been able to make any new and meaningful recommendations to address this well known safety issue. The Commission will, however forward this report to the IMO and invite the appropriate committee to note the contents of the report for any future programmes to improve awareness of the dangers associated with entry into enclosed spaces.

On Sunday 2 May 2010, a 14 year old sea cadet, fell from a yard on the fore mast of the sail training ship TS Royalist when the vessel was at anchor. The sea cadet was assisting other cadets to stow the fore course sail when he fell backwards and struck the starboard gunwale 8m below, before falling into the sea.
He was quickly recovered from the water by the vessel’s sea boat and transferred to a coastguard helicopter which flew him to hospital. Sadly, the cadet died as a result of the severe injuries he had sustained. This was the first fatality on board TS Royalist in her 39 years of service.
