The sea cadet fell to the deck because he unclipped his belt harness from the wire jackstay provided on the fore course yard, contrary to his training and onboard procedures for work at that position.

SOLASStatus: BRIGHT CENTURY: SOLAS, SEA SUCCESS: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0524 local time on 02 May 2010, the Hong Kong registered bulk carrier Bright Century collided with the Liberia registered bulk carrier Sea Success in approximate position 37º 38.15’ N 123º 07.33’ E, in the waters off Weihai, Shandong Province, China.

At the time of the accident, the weather was bad with dense fog, the visibility was about 50 to 100 metres, the wind was southeast force about 5, and the sea state was rough.

Following the collision, Bright Century took in water and foundered in about 30 minutes with full cargo of iron ore and about 420 MT of fuel oil.  All twenty-three crew members onboard were rescued.  Sea Success sustained serious hull damage in the forward part and was towed to a sheltered anchorage near Weihai, and all her crew members were rescued.

No casualties were reported in the incident.

On May 2, 2010 at approximately 0030LT, the Second Officer on the Liberian Flag container vessel, NORTHERN DEMOCRAT (IMO No. 9391787) went missing while the vessel was transiting from Cape Town, South Africa to Port Kelang, Malaysia. Second Officer ad visited the Second and Third Engineers in their accommodation prior to his watch duty on 02 May 2010 at about 0001 hrs. The Second Officer was reported missing at approximately 00.30LT. A complete search of the vessel was conducted and when the Second Officer was not found a search and rescue operation was launched. No sign of the Second Officer was found. There being no indications of foul play or suicide, it was concluded that the loss of Second Officer was an accident.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On the morning of 01 May 2010, at 06:15 hrs, the small fishing ship Craig and Justin, with a crew of 4 on board, capsized and sank approximately 1 nautical mile west-northwest of Margaree Harbour, Nova Scotia. Three crew members were quickly recovered from the water by nearby fishing ships. 
One crew member drowned
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The Beluga Revolution was fully laden with 8,030 tons of scrap metal and sailing from Noumea in New Caledonia to Pohang in South Korea. The navigator calculated the voyage plan for Noumea to Pohang; the total distance was 4,225 nm and the planned duration 11 days.

In addition to the required navigation equipment, the bridge was equipped with an electronic chart system to supplement the charts in paper form.
On 30 April, the ship was located to the north east of the Bismarck Sea in the South Pacific Ocean. It was steered on autopilot and moving at 16 kts. At no point did the 3 officers on watch or the master notice that from the last waypoint at 18:00 hrs, the track practically led over Tench sland. The Beluga Revolution grounded on ENUS (Tench) Island at 22:10 hrs in a westward setting South Equatorial Current and tropical showers, which blurred the radar image.

The shell plating was dented and the forepeak cracked as a result of the ship grounding. There were no injuries and no pollutants escaped.
collision between fishing vessel and bulk carrier

The fishing carrier AINMIRE took water and sank 23 miles Northwest of Isle of Lewis, UK at 10.50 on April 30.   An initial distrss call was received at 0530 hrs earlier the same day.  All 5 crew members were rescued  by fishing carrier OUR HAZEL and taken to Ullapool, UK.  A Stornoway CG helicopter and an RNLI lifeboat attended the scene.
On 28th April 2010, during her approach to Nexø, Bornholm, the fishing vessel RYTAS missed the harbour entrance and grounded just north of the northern break water.

Location: Off Kochi, West Coast of India
SummaryOfEvents:
On 26 April 2010 while underway fully laden with iron ore from New Mangalore/India to a not yet defined port of call in China, a fire broke out onboard MV Arosia during the night within the accommodation area.

An AB awoke in his cabin on upper deck of Arosia at about 22:00 hours, when he smelled and then sighted light smoke followed by darker smoke in his cabin coming through the side bulkhead. He investigated by opening the adjacent cabin door and observed the cabin ceiling, in way of the florescent light area, on fire. He immediately closed the door and started shouting “Fire”, ran up to the poop deck and activated the fire alarm.

The bosun, who appeared on-scene first, joined the AB and both triggered action trying to put out the fire. As the fire intensified, the bosun ordered the meanwhile congregated crew to open the accommodation doors on upper deck and poop deck as the smoke was getting thicker and breathing was become difficult for them. The crew proceeded outside rigged hoses and started to fight the fire and cooling the boundary.

Without having the ship’s crew correctly mustered at initial stage when the fire alarm was first triggered, all present crew was engaged in fire fighting activities with only little control and leadership at the beginning. During the process it was realized that two o the ships staff were missing and a search was prompted. Confusion was increased when some of the staff reported to having seen the two missing crew only recently.

Only after several unsuccessful attempts searching for the missing crew, ship staff donned breathing apparatuses and fireman outfits to enter the cabins of the missing persons.

At 22:45 hrs and 23:10 hrs a missing engine fitter and a deck fitter were found unconscious on their cabin floors. The two casualties were placed on the boat deck where the ship staff attempted to revive them, including several times with cardiopulmonary resuscitation. However, all efforts made were unsuccessful. Both seafarers died on-scene.

The fire spread from the upper deck to the poop deck and then to the boat deck before finally being extinguished. All other crew remained unharmed.

Arosia deviated to Kochi/India, having been the closest port, only some 70 miles away. There, the deceased seafarers were passed to the local Authorities for repatriation and the ship underwent major temporary repairs prior being released.

Location: A 120 MILLAS FRENTE AL PUERTO SUPE
SummaryOfEvents: Dia 25 abril, siendo las 20:19 horas se recibió señal de activación de radiobaliza en el Sistema COSPAS SARSAT, de la embarcación pesquera NATIVIDAD, se efectúo comunicación con la propietaria de la referida embarcación, quien informó que su embarcación se encontraba en zona de pesca y que no tenia comunicación, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera Marítima RIO NEPEÑA, Unidad que zarpó en misión SAR, el día 26 abril, siendo las 21:07 horas la Patrullera Marítima, ubicó a la embarcación  pesquera NATIVIDAD, en la posición Lat. 10º 23’ S y Long. 079º 50’ W con CUATRO (04) tripulantes a bordo, los mismos que fueron rescatados en buen estado de salud, asimismo, la embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas mecanicas, los tripulantes se embarcaron a la Patrullera Marítima siendo trasladados al Puerto Callao, la embarcación al garete fue remolcada por la embarcación pesquera ANALENI, al Puerto Huarmey, el dia 28 abril, siendo las 12:05 horas, la Patrullera Marítima RIO NEPEÑA, arribó al Puerto del Callao, con la tripulación rescatada.

Location: A 120 MILLAS FRENTE AL PUERTO ILO
SummaryOfEvents: Dia 25 abril, siendo las 06:20 horas se recibió señal de activación de radiobaliza en el Sistema COSPAS SARSAT, de la embarcación pesquera DOÑA PAULA I, se efectúo comunicación con la propietaria de la referida embarcación, informando su embarcación se encontraba en zona de pesca y que no tenia comunicacion, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera Marítima RIO ZAÑA en misión SAR , el día 26 abril, siendo las 00:20 horas la Patrullera Marítima ubicó a la embarcación pesquera DOÑA PAULA I, en la posición Lat. 18º 04’ S y Long. 073º 33’ W con TRES (03) tripulantes a bordo, los mismos que fueron rescatados en buen estado de salud, asimismo, la embarcación se encontraba al garete por fallas electricas, se brindó apoyo eléctrico, baterias y al no haber solucionado los problemas de la maquina, a 09:30 horas se procedió a remolcar hacia Puerto Ilo, el día 27 abril, siendo las 02:50 horas, la Patrullera Marítima RIO ZAÑA arribó al Puerto de Ilo, con la tripulación rescatada y remolcando a la embarcación pesquera.

The general cargo ship FU WEI stranded off Baisha township, Penghu islands at 23.03 Hours on 22/04/2010 in heavy weather. It sustained damage to hull and took water. All 13 crew members abandoned ship, 8 crew members were rescued by air force helicopter and taken to Jibei island. 5 were rescued by coastguard rescue boat and taken to Makung, Penghu islands. No injuries were reported. Some oil were reported in the sea. The anti-pollutoin booms were deployed, the ship was refloated and towed to unknown port.

The “CARNIVAL ECSTASY”, sailed out of port of Cozumel in Mexico on 20th April 2010, and commenced Voyage No. AC – Ecstasy 5041710. At 1615 hrs, according to the ship’ s bell book, the pilot disembarked, the Master took over the vessel’s conning and commenced sea passage at 1618 Hrs with a total of 2342 passengers and a total crew of 882 including the Master, observed sea water draft of 7.86 meters Forward, 7.90 meters Aft, 7.80 meters Mid - ship, sea water density being 1.025gms/cc, GM (corrected for free surface) 1.42 meters, HO 871.50 MT, DO 90.60 MT, Ballast 674.80 MT, Fresh Water 1606.40 MT upright with no list. Being a passenger ship there was no cargo loaded on board for commercial transportation. 
The vessel was schedule to call the port of Galveston, TX, her next port of call, where she arrived at and ended her sea passage (EOSP) at 0618 Hrs (LT) on 22nd April 2010 and safely berthed Starboard side alongside, Passenger Berth, at 0806 Hrs on 22nd April 2010, on a draft of 7.74 meters Forward, 7.89 meters Aft, 7.81 meters Mid – ship, sea water density being 1.025gms/cc, GM (corrected) 1.42 meters, HO 698.70 MT, DO 100.30 MT, Ballast 1014.90 MT, Fresh Water 1359.90 MT upright with no list

On 21 April 2010, the chief engineer on board the UK registered container ship Ever Excel was killed when he became trapped between the top of the ship’s passenger lift and the edge of the lift shaft.

Ever Excel was alongside in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, China undergoing a preliminary environmental compliance inspection, which required that the pit of the lift shaft be checked for oil residues. The second engineer was unable to open the lift shaft doors to gain access to the lift pit and the chief engineer intervened to resolve the problem. Without stating his intentions, the chief engineer entered the lift car, climbed through an escape hatch to reach the top of the lift car, and closed the hatch behind him. 

The second engineer reset the lift controls, incorrectly assuming that the chief engineer had taken manual control of the lift from on top of the lift car. The chief engineer had not, and the lift was returned to its normal automatic operating mode. The lift moved upwards at its usual operating speed and trapped the chief engineer against the door still of the deck above, asphyxiating him. It is not known exactly what the chief engineer intended to do, but it is likely that he was looking at the back of the lift shaft doors to establish how the licking mechanism worked.

On 21 April 2010, an explosion occurred on board the privately own cruiser Maurenella at Lowtown, Co.Kildare. The owner was injured and hospitalized.

Whilst the causes of the explosion cannot be conclusively determined, all the indications are that it occurred due to a gas leak which may have ignited when the engine was started.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: South of Geomundo island, South Korea
SummaryOfEvents: The tanker "HAEKUP PACIFIC" sank after a collision with M/V "ZHENG HANG" 20 miles South of Geomundo island, South Korea at 2200 Hours on 20/04/2010. The ship sustained damage to hull, took water in engine room and sank at 0800 Hours on 21/04/2010. All 10 crew members were rescued and no injuries were reported.

On 20th April 2010 an explosion on the DEEPWATER HORIZON offshore drilling rig, operating in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana, resulted in a fire that sank the rig and caused a massive-scale oil spill. Eleven rig workers were missing and presumed dead, and 17 others were injured. The oil spill covers a surface area of at least 2,500 square miles and is the worst drilling accident in the Gulf of Mexico for over three decades.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The accident occurred on the after deck during hauling operations. The clump weight had been stowed and the starboard trawl door had been secured alongside by two of the four deckhands. The skipper, who was inside the wheelhouse using CCTV screens to view the after deck, had heaved the port trawl door until there was 0.5m of trawl wire left outside the trawl block. One of the deckhands placed a hook into one of the trawl door inner chain links. The hook was attached by shackles to a 2m-long, 32mm polypropylene rope strop, the other end of which was attached to a pad eye welded to the top of the bulwark. As the skipper heaved in the last 0.5m of wire, the rope strop tightened and bowsed-in the trawl door alongside the bulwark. Just as the skipper stopped heaving, the hook opened up under load, causing it to be released from the chain. The rope snapped back and the hook struck the head of one of the deckhands.

The third engineer and the duty mechanic carried out maintenace of the oil filter of the No. 2 generator engine. The third engineer did not follow the maintenance procedure as described in the operator's manual. The air bleeding valve was overslackened and came out. The oil injected to the hot surface of the turbocharger and caught fire.

On April 19, 2010 at approximately 0745LT, the Liberian Flag bulk carrier, POLLUX was involved in a collision while berthed at the Port of Nea Moudhania, Greece. The Maltese cargo vessel, RED SPIRIT, was coming into berth behind the POLLUX and collided with the aft of the POLLUX. It was alleged that RED SPIRIT was proceeding at an excessive rate of speed. As a result, the POLLUX sustained damage to the poop deck and lower aft end. A Germanischer Lloyd Class Surveyor attended the vessel and condition of class was imposed for temporary and permanent repair to the satisfaction of the attending surveyor at the next port of call but not later than April 27, 2010. There were no injuries to the crew and no incident of pollution was reported.

El PAM "Kings Bay" había fondeado a la gira con un ancla en la Bahía "Maiquillahue", para descanso de la dotación, en circunstancias que se cortó la cadena de fondeo en el paño 3, derivando la nave de noche hacia costa hasta vararen la playa. 
Dado que el objetivo de haber fondeado era descansar, la guardia de puente se cubrió solamente con tripulantes de cubierta, mientras el capitán y los oficiales de guardia dormían. Los tripulantes no tenían suficiente idoneidad para controlar que se mantuviera el punto de fondeo por lo que cuando se cortó la cadena y la nave quedó a la deriva no se percataron de la anomalía.

On 18 April 2010, at 0010 hrs, the stern trawler RAIRO caught fire in the Norwegian Sea, 155 miles SW of Aalesund, Norway.  The blaze was extinguished by the crew, with no injuries reported.  The extent of the damage is unknown.  The trawler arrived in tow at Aalesund for inspection and later arrived at Gurskoya, Norway, where it was laid up awaiting repair decisions.  On 14 February 2011, the trawler arrived at Grenaa, Denmark where it was reported as being damaged beyond economical repair and sold for breaking up.

Location: 3.10 Open Sea (Black Sea - approaches to Kerch Strait
SummaryOfEvents:
On 17th April 2010 whilst handling mooring ropes on the vessels forecastle deck, at approximately 16:45hrs, a fatal accident occurred involving the bosun on board the Isle of Man registered vessel Virtsu.

Although the alarm was raised very soon after the event was thought to have occurred (there were no actual witnesses), due to the degree of injury received, resuscitation attempts proved unsuccessful and the Bosun was reported dead by the Chief Officer at 17:10hrs the same day.

A casualty investigation was conducted by the flag state upon the vessels return to Constanta Romania.

On 17th April 2010 the Panamanian tanker SEA PRINCESS II was at anchor in the port of Aden. At approximately 14.30 LT a fire broke out in the engine room, which was extinguished at approximately 15:55 hours LT. There were no casualities, and no pollution was caused.  The Maritime Affairs Authority later sent an investigation team to the site, and more details of the incident will be forwarded at a later date.

The tanker ANUKET IVORY was on river passage towards Calabar under pilotage when the echo sounder went into alarm.  The speed was reduced from half ahead to slow ahead.  A few minutes afterwards the vessel developed a 7 degree list.  Ballasting operations were carried out to minimise the list and when the vessel was alongside it was found that the hull had a 1m tear in way of WBT 2 stbd.

The company investigation found:
"	The river channel was not well marked
"	There was no information available for the river passage
"	There was poor bridge team management with the officers relying entirely on the pilot
"	The river had a charted depth of 5.1m and the height of tide at the time was 0.9m giving a depth of 6.0m.  The draft was 5.8m giving a static UKC of 20cm.  However, no allowance was made for squat

The vessel was dry-docked and repaired to class satisfaction just over two weeks later.  The master was dismissed from the company.

Le jeudi 15 avril 2010 à 06h15, le Talisman  appareille du port du Guilvinec avec un équipage de quatre hommes, pour une campagne de pêche au large du Sud-Finistère. Après l’appareillage, les deux matelots et le chef mécanicien descendent se reposer dans leur poste, le patron assurant seul le quart à la passerelle.
Vers 08h30, le navire toujours en route pêche, l’alarme incendie compartiment machine se déclenche. Le patron alerte aussitôt l’équipage, ordonne aux deux matelots de préparer la drome de sauvetage en vue d’une évacuation et commence à préparer la lutte contre l’incendie avec le chef mécanicien. La charge de CO2 de l’installation d’extinction fixe est envoyée dans le compartiment machine. La ventilation mécanique est ensuite stoppée et les bouches de ventilation machine obturées. Le moteur stop sous l’effet du CO2.
A 08h32, le patron émet un appel de détresse à destination du CROSS. Le feu est maîtrisé peu après et le TALISMAN remorqué au port du Guilvinec.

During testing of the launch system of the MOB-boat in connection with a periodic survey of the RoRo passenger ship DUEODDE encountered an unexpected situation.

The MOB boat got inadvertently caught in a curtain plate at the ship’s side. When the crew tried to remedy the situation, the MOB-boat slid off the curtain plate, turned around 180 degrees and got into severe oscillations along the ship's side.
 
One of the two ABs on board the MOB-boat fell into the water from approx. 15 m height. The AB drifted towards the pier and was recovered. He was subsequently rushed to the hospital.

The AB suffered injuries that led to two months' sick leave.

Location: East China Sea off Ieo Islet, South Korea
SummaryOfEvents: On 12 April 2010, at 1840 hrs under heavy weather conditions, the bulk carrier ORIENTAL HOPE, stranded on reef in the East China Sea off Ieo Islet, South Korea.  The carrier sustained damage to its ballast tanks.  Two coastguard ships attended to the scene.  Fourteen crew members were rescued; with 8 remaining on board to assist with the salvage operations.  Nippon Salvage assisted with lightering of cargo.  There were no injuries or pollution reported.  The carrier was reported as being beyond economical repair.

The bosun entered into No. 1 cofferdam, which was a confined space, alone by himself without notifying other crew on board. The Chief Officer found that the manhole door of No. 1 cofferdam was opened and suspected the bosun was inside. The bosun was later found lying in the second deck inside the cofferdam. He was sent to hospital for treament and certified dead

Location: 10 NM south east of Cork Coast, Ireland
InitialEvent: Suspected dislodged engine coolant (raw water) intake pipe
SummaryOfEvents: While fishing alone on 10th April 2010, it is believed that a flexible portion of the raw water engine coolant intake pipe became disconnected, thus causing uncontrollable flooding of the engine room. The vessel sank shortly afterwards. There was no loss of life, and the owner/skipper was rescued and did not sustain injuty. The full investigation is continuing.

On 7 April 2010, 3 persons entered the water in their kayaks at Curraghmore Estate in Whitestown, Co. Waterford, Ireland and paddled downstream for about 30 minutes until they reached the weir at Portlaw.

Whilst attempting to navigate the weir, 2 of them lost their lives.

1.“PAR GRARNET” WAS DRIFTING AT 2112H LT, 6 APRIL 2010 IN CJK ANCHORAGE;
2. “PAR GRARNET” ’S ENGINE WAS READY BUT FAILED TO MANOEUVER TO AVOID COLLIDING “APPOLLO MIYO” WHO ANCHORED IN THE ANCHORAGE.

At about 2215 local time on 4th April 2010, Panama flagged LPG carrier GOLDEN CRUX NO.18 was navigating near to the south-east of Changjiangkou 2# anchorage, Shanghai, China, when her main engine’s turbocharger exploded and the big fire ensued; the C/E and an oiler were trapped in E/R and died.

The Endeavor was en route from Bremerhaven to Klaipeda. She was classified to Traffic Group 4 for the passage through the Kiel Canal (NOK). Upon reaching the main siding at Audorf-Rade on 4 April at 00:20 hrs, she was met with a stop signal and proceeded slowly towards the end of the siding shortly after the Endeavor. The stop signal did not apply to her as she was classified to Traffic Group 3. Therefore, she maintained a constant speed and prepared to overtake the Endeavor: The pilot of the two ships discussed this manoeuvre.

When the forecastle of Cranz was on a level with the aft superstructure of the Endeavor, the bow of the Cranz was drawn toward the Endeavor due to hydrodynamic effects. This turning movement led to a collision between the two ships, which pushed the Endeavor further forward, causing the Cranz to separate from her again. It was not possible to bring the turning movement of the Cranz under control and the momentum caused the ship to move towards the southern embankment of the NOK with such force that it was only possible to refloat her with tug assistance.

Location: FRENTE AL DESEMBOCADURA RIO SUPE Y CALETA VIDAL
SummaryOfEvents: Día 03 abril, siendo las 20:00 horas la chalana a remos DAYRON con número de registro SE-0370, sufrió varadura en circunstancias que se encontraba en la zona de pesca, con DOS (02) tripulantes a bordo, de los cuales el tripulante Deny HUARACHI Ramos, desapareció en la mar, CAPISALA, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanías, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PUNTA ARENAS, con con resultados negativos. El día 09 mayo a 07:30 horas fue ubicada el cuerpo sin vida del citado tripulante en el área de la desembocadura del Rio Supe y Caleta VIDAL, por personas del lugar.

Location: South China Sea, off Shanwei Guangdong, China
SummaryOfEvents: On 3 April 2010, at 0658 hrs, under heavy weather conditions, the cargo ship SUN EXPRESS foundered in the South China Sea, off Shanwei, Guangdong, China.  All 16 crew members were rescued by ship YUAN FENG SHUN and transferred to the Chinese Rescue ship DONG HAI JIU 199 and taken to Xingang Wharf, Huangpu, Guangzhou, China where they arrived on 4 April 2010 at 0825 hrs.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

Location: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, Douglas Shoal,  AUSTRALIA
SummaryOfEvents:
The 230 metre SHENG NENG 1 was sailing at full speed in a restricted zone of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park on 3rd April 2010 when she hit Douglas Shoal, 120 kms off the coast of Rockhampton, Australia, and 70 kms east of Great Keppel Island. The vessel was carrying 65,000 tonnes of coal and 975 tonnes of fuel on board when it went aground, piercing one of the fuel tanks. Initially, some three to four tonnes of oil seeped into the water, creating a 3 km x 100 m slick. Booms have been deployed around the vessel and dispersants sprayed in an effort to contain and disperse the slick, in order to limit environmental damage to the fragile marine ecosystem around the Great Barrier Reef. The double bottom of the vessel was pierced and water has seeped in. The remaining fuel was pumped to other tanks within the vessel to prevent further leakage.
Reports indicate that the vessel was travelling more than 28km off course when it ran aground.

On 01 April vessel departed from port of Ho Chi Minh City to Malaysia, after discharging cargo. After dropping pilot at 1300 hrs vessel later steered true course of 189 degrees at speed of 8 knots when 2 fishing boat crossed from her stbd to port. At 1400 hrs the other fishing boat making a course of 110 degrees and speed of 6 knots, located 0.8NM on stbd bow also attempted to cross the bow from stbd to port. On seeing this the OOW blew ship’s whistle to warn the fishing boat and later fishing boat began to alter course to her port. But she could not turn to port because of her engine problem. Panama vessel reduced her speed and finally stopped but the vessel’s bow collided with the fishing boat at 1410 hrs in position Lat10º11.54´N Long 107º05.51’E causing fishing boat to sink.

During a mooring manoeuvre of the m.v. Edisongracht between two mooring buoys in the port of Soyo in Angola on 1 April 2010 at around 9:00 a.m. (LT), a mooring line slid off a guide roller and subsequently broke. The mooring line hit two crew members. One crew member was fatally injured to his head and a second crew member suffered from a broken leg and a head injury. Due to the late arrival of the pilot, the mooring manoeuvre was initiated 2.5 hours later than planned. As a result, the manoeuvre was performed when the tidal current was nearly at its peak: the moment at which the current is at its strongest. A spring tide was also present at that moment.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The MV Pelagitis (ex- Atlantlic Freighter) was laid-up in Dec. 2008 in Port aux Basques, NL, Canada. The vessel was under new ownership and on the 15th of March 2010, the vessel had new crew on board and initiated preparation for departure to Piraeus, Greece, where repairs and maintenance would be undertaken. At 17:05 LT on the 31st of March 2010 the ship unmoored its last line and proceeded to recover its starboard side anchor. Weather conditions included strong easterly winds of 40 km/hr. No pilot or tug services were requested by the Captain. 
The winds pushed the vessel against the pier making her hit the dock twice on her port side while she was manoeuvring astern to clear the pier ‘Fords I’. Once the ship cleared said pier, the captain initiated a 225° turn left to position the vessel towards the outbound channel using the two engines and the bow thrusters. This manoeuvre in a confined area of about 320 m in length was challenging, as the strong winds kept pushing the vessel against the ferry terminal. The Captain managed to turn the vessel, but hit the outer corner of the ferry terminal in the process. The vessel finally grounded on top of the buoy QP9 at the beginning of the outbound channel. The vessel sustained damages to its bottom plates, rudder and starboard side propeller. No cracks to the bottom plates were found and no pollution was caused. The vessel was refloated in the evening of March 31st, 2010 and brought back to the pier. The investigation concluded that the grounding was caused by human error. It was the first time the Captain manoeuvred the ship and he disregarded the strong easterly winds and decided against requesting pilot and tug services
On 31 Mars 2010, the UK register high speed ferry Norman Arrow was damaged when she struck fixed fendering in Portsmouth international Port while attempting to move between berths

The refrigerated cargo "KEA" developed list to port and sank in the Bay of Biscay, 160 miles off Cabo de Vilan, Spain at 1330 hours on 30/03/2010. Initial distress call received at 2030 hours on 29/03/2010 after cargo shifted in heavy weather. 22 crew members were rescued and 2 missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 28th March 2010 the container vessel VEGA GOTLAND was at Port Botany, loading 40' containers on deck, when a stevedore was crushed between two containers. He was fatally injured as a result of the accident.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The 2,926gt Marshall Islands registered general cargo ship OUTSAILING 9 collided with the 199gt Japanese registered general cargo ship NISSHIN MARU in Naruto Kaikyo (Straits), Tokushima Pref., Japan (approximately 34-13.9N, 134-39.1 E) on March 28, 2010. Following the collision, OUTSAILING 9 sustained a minor damage at forward part, while two crews onboard NISSHIN MARU went missing and the Captain was injured as a result of the vessel sinking.

On March 25, 2010, at approximately 1835LT, a fire occurred on the Liberian Flag container ship, MAERSK MIAMI  in the Indian Ocean. At approximately 1835LT, the fire began in the vessel’s boiler flat and heavy smoke was observed coming from the port side funnel. The crew attempted to contain the fire using fire pumps and CO2 release mechanisms; however, thirty minutes later, the fire was out of control and the vessel subsequently lost power. When not able to control the fire, the crew evacuated the accommodation space to the forecastle until assistance arrived. At 1942LT, the Indian Coast Guard responded to the vessel’s distress signal and began assistance operations. Despite the extensive damage to the vessel’s engine room and superstructure, there were no injuries to the crew reported as all crewmembers were evacuated. The fire led to considerable hull damage on the port side of the vessel and rendered the vessel unfit to proceed.

On 26 March 2010, while embarking passengers and loading vehicles at Heysham, England, the ro-ro passenger ferry Ben-My-Chree moved approximately 8 m along the quayside, causing serious damage to the passenger access structure. The foot-passenger walkway detached at both ends and collapsed onto the quayside, and the gangway detached from the vessel’s side shell door and was left hanging on a single rope. Fortunately, there were no injuries. Eight passengers were trapped in the gangway compartment of the shore structure and were later rescued by the local fire service.

On 24 March 2010 at 09:25 hours LT at sea an AB was hit by gushed green water while working with an angle grinder on the forecastle of BBC Northsea. He got electrocuted and with no reflexes washed down the stairways on to the main deck. The AB was found unconscious apparently not breathing at the bottom of the stairs. First aid was immediately rendered by his near-by working shipmates on deck, followed by ongoing reanimation attempts by the alerted 2nd officer, combined with medical advice the master had meanwhile gained from TMAS Medico Cuxhaven/Germany.
All attempts to reanimate the AB with shipboard means failed and further outside medical help could not be rendered on time. The vessel changed course towards Durban, having been the closest port to reach. However, the seafarer died prior arriving. The accident occurred during fair weather conditions while the vessel was utilizing the Agulhas Current some 200 miles south of Durban on her way from Cape Town to Singapore. The green water penetrated trough the anchor hawse pipes when the vessel was forced to heavily pitch after being hit by a couple of high swell waves in an otherwise almost calm sea.
At 10:20 hours LT, not even an hour after the accident had happened, the master started to call MAYDAY, asking for medical assistance from a nearby vessel with a doctor probably on board. All calls were in vain. None of his calls were even responded.

The Stena Pioneer grounded in soft ground while negotiating a bend in the Fleetwood Channel.  She remained aground for approximately 45 minutes and refloated on the raising tide.  There was no pollution and she suffered only minor damage to her hull paintwork.

SOLASStatus: GLOBAL PURITY: SOLAS, ICGS VIVEK: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd March 2010 the bulk carrier GLOBAL PURITY was being manouevered in the turning basin of Indira Docks, in good weather conditions. During the maneouvre the vessel collided with ICGS VIVEK, and Indian coast guard patrol ship, which was already berthed at the knuckle of the turning basin. Following the incident the ICGS VIVEK listed about six degrees (P) and then began taking in water through the opening created by the removal of the shell plating (5 x 1 metre), and about 05. metres above the water line on the Port side, and 6 x 1 metres above the water line on the Starboard side.

The general cargo ship UNO was on voyage from Nordenham, Germany, to Hamburg with a cargo of large cable containers. The ship departed Nordenham 20 March 2010. Before departure the cable containers were secured by help of lashings and cargo stoppers. On arrival the cargo securing was to be removed before discharging. The cargo stoppers that were welded to the tanktop were to be removed by the crew with angle grinders. During the removal of the cargo stoppers, an AB cut two fingers seriously on his left hand.
The M/V ASSAFA caught fire whilst moored at Ras El Hilal, Libya on 22 March 2010. It subsequently stranded whilst under tow and left as lies. It sustained severe damage to accomodation block.
The M/V AMANECER stranded in the Parana river, Argentina on 21 March 2010. It was abandoned and left as lies.

1. LEFT BERTH AND AHEAD DEEP CHANNEL, ARRIVED YUANYUANSHA; 2. ONE SHIP ACROSS FROM HER BOW VERY CLOSELY, SO “INDIGO AOI” CALL HARD STARDBOARD AND SUCCESS AVOIDING HER; 3. FAILED TO AVOID “LORD VISHNU” AT THE STARBOARD SIDE AND COLLIDED WITH HER.

”Monica” left the Rekefjorden 15/3 and was lost 4 days later the 19/3. The vessel had been fishing 3 - 4 days and was underway when the accident occured. 

There were no fishing gear in the water. The wind was about 15 - 16 sek.meter from SW. There was som swell and heavy rain. The speed was 4 to 5 knot heading against the waves so the waves and wind was hitting port bow. No waves came over the bow or went over the shipside. Everything was normal until about 23:00 hours. Suddently the navigator and look out on the bridge heard a bang from the bow area. Shortly after the shipp started to act more heavily in water and started to list to starboard. Shortly after the waterpumps on the workdeck under maindeck started. Only minutes after that several alarms started on the bridge. The navigator tried to change heading all in an attempt to work against the listing bur with no success. He then raised the alarm and sent the look out to call out one crew member still sleeping. When this crewmember shortly after headed up to the bridge, he observed through a window from the corridor and into the work deck that there were water at about one meter hight on the deck following the listing of the ship.
When all 3 crewmembers was standing on the bridge, it was decided to abandon the ship due to the klisting being so bad that water was entering hatches and doors. Shortly after the ship sunk. The crew saved their lives just about. All events happend within a very short time.

An ROV Inspection some months later revealed no damaged to the part of the ship that was visible above the seabed. Unfortunately the ship hull from the load line and down was covered by the seabed.
The ship was 7 years old and in very good condition. Based on the ROV examination, available drawings and inspection report and the witness statements from the crew, the most likely cause was that the ship hit an object floating in the sea, the hull damaged and water went into storage rooms below load lines. Open hatches from storage room to the work deck,  made it possible for the water to fill several rooms and eventually leading to the loss of the ship.

On 19 March 2010, at 0600 hrs, the bulk carrier THEODORE JR, caught fire in the engine room after an explosion on board, 24 miles East of Ceuta, Spain.  Tugs LUZ DE MAR and SUCAR DOCE proceeded to fight the blaze.  Sixteen crew members were rescued by SAR boat EL PUNTO and 5 were transferred to tug LUZ DE MAR to assist with firefighting operations.  The blaze was extinguished and the carrier was towed by tug MED FOS to Piraeus, Greece for inspection where she was reported to have sustained severe damage to the engine room and accommodation block.  On 15 October 2010, the carrier arrived in tow at Varna, Bulgaria for cargo discharge.  On 26 October 2010, she arrived in tow at Aliaga for demolition, having been damaged beyond economical repair.
On 19 March 2010, the cargo ship PRIYANKA foundered in the Gulf of Khambhat, 17 miles SW of Jafrabad, India.

The second engineer, third engineer and the fitter were engaged in fitting protection shields, supplied by the manufacturer on cylinders No 1 & 7 of the main engine, while the vessel was alongside in Rotterdam. No risk assessment was carried out and the protection shield around cylinder No 1 was completed with ease within an hour. After lunch, the fitting of the protection shield on cylinder No 7 became more complex, necessitating the removal of platform plates, a non-pressurised pipe and the grinding of a protective bracket. No attempt was made to re-evaluate the risks. Shortly after the pipe was removed, the second engineer responded to an alarm on the boiler. The third engineer, thinking that a bracket which had supported the drain pipe had to be removed, slackened and removed the bolts which were also holding the jacket cooling water pipe connection. As the third engineer and fitter attempted to manoeuvre the shield around the cylinder, it dislodged the cooling water pipe, which resulted in the fitter becoming drenched with hot water (85º C) at 3.4 bar and sustaining serious injuries.

Location: CUADRA PLAYA SANTA BARBARA - CALETA CERRO AZUL
SummaryOfEvents: Dia 17 marzo, siendo las 21:00 horas se recibió llamada telefonica Comisaria PNP Caleta Cerro Azul, informando que a la altura de la cuadra playa Santa Barbara, se encuentra una embarcación efectuando señales de socorro. El dia 18 marzo a 06:00 horas, se dispuso el zarpe de la embarcación pesquera BEATITA MELCHORITA, con personal Guardacostas, siendo las 08:00 horas se ubicó a la citada embarcación con DOS (02) tripulantes a bordo, embarcación se encontraba al garete por falta de combustible, siendo remolcado hacia la Caleta de Cerro Azul.

Día 17 marzo, siendo las 20:00 horas, la embarcación pesquera ISRAEL, con SEIS (06) tripulantes a bordo, colisionó con un bajo ocasionandole su hundimiento total, frente a la Caleta Yacila, la embarcación pesquera REYNA FARA, recibió comunicación radial de pedido de auxilio, esta efectuó busqueda por la zona con resultados negativos, CAPIPITA, activó RCC, asimismo dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHICAMA, hacia el área de siniestro, retornando a 02:30 horas con resultados negativos, posteriormente el representante de la citada embarcación informó que la totalidad de los tripulantes llegaron nadando a la citada Caleta en buen estado de salud.

Location: FRENTE A LA CALETA CABO BLANCO - TALARA
SummaryOfEvents: Dia 17 abril, siendo las 09:46 horas la Capitania Guardacostas Maritima de Zorritos, recepcionó la Protesta de Mar presentada por el señor Tomas PINGO Chiroque, propietario de la embarcación pesquera MILAGRO DE JESUS, informando que su embarcación zarpó a zona de pesca frente a la Caleta de Cabo Blanco - Talara, el dia 11 abril debiendo arribar el dia 16 abril. CAPIZORI, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitania. El dia 18 abril a 03:00 horas arribó la citada embarcación a la Caleta de Cancas, por sus propios medios.

SOLASStatus: MANAS: Unknown/unspecified, SAINT JACQUES II: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On Tuesday 16 March at 1.00 am, the trawler SAINT JACQUES II, flying French flag, was fishing at the entry of the north-east bound traffic lane of the strait of Dover, between Bassurelle buoy and Greenwich buoy. She was sailing at a speed of 3 knots and was making good a westerly course. The AB on watch on the bridge had just taken over from the skipper, who went to his cabin. In the crew’s quarters the chief engineer and the ABs were resting. At the same time, the chemical tanker vessel MANAS, flying Malta flag, was making good a 075° course at an average speed of 14 knots in the north-eastbound traffic lane of the strait of Dover. She was at 9 nautical miles in the West of SAINT JACQUES II. The second officer had taken over the 4 hour watch at 0.40 am.
At 1.31 am, both vessels were at 46 miles in the bearing 254° from Mont Saint-Frieux when they collided; at first MANAS bulb knocked in SAINT JACQUES II port stern under works, then got under the port warp which broke very quickly; at the same time MANAS anchor and the upper part of her port forecastle got in contact with SAINT JACQUES II port superstructures and damaged them severely. Then both vessels parted and SAINT JACQUES II stabilized. Once apart both vessels slowed down, stopped and stayed in the area.
SAINT JACQUES II skipper informed Gris-Nez MRCC that his vessel was seriously damaged, however no significant leak was reported. The AB on watch on-board the trawler had been wounded. MANAS captain confirmed to Gris Nez MRCC that his vessel collided with SAINT JACQUES II and proposed to assist her. After having investigated the damages, SAINT JACQUES II skipper decided to sail toward Boulogne-sur-Mer, her home port escorted by the Maritime administration patrol boat THEMIS. The convoy got alongside at 10.45 am. MANAS that suffered only minor material damages resumed her course at 2.26 am, in agreement with Gris-Nez MRCC.

On 16th March 2010 the captioned vessel “KING DUCKLING”, operated by NOS Ship management Pte, Ltd., was undertaking way from her dry dock off Shanhaiguan Shipyard, Qinhuangdao China to Dabo Singkep Indonesia, in ballast condition. 
1) That at about 0045h/16th Mar., Main engine commenced emergency stop due to water jacket cooling problem (Water Burst) at A5. 
2) That at about 0130h/16th Mar., one explosion heard from engine room, particularly at boiler, and automatic alarm activated due to fire started. 
3) That immediate mustering of all crew carried-out and sent to respond to fight the fire in heavy smoke, by the use of portable fire extinguishers. All ventilation covers shut down and electrical isolated from that area, and the fire pump started. Boundary cooling procedure set up to have an entry at Steering Gear Room & the other at Main Entrance of Engine Room in the accommodation. 
4) That at about 0200h/16th Mar., the master called the NOS office to inform the incident, meanwhile the fire fighting was in progress. 
5) That at about 0215h/16th Mar., the Chief Mate reported smoke in engine room slowly disappeared, boundary cooling kept on. 
6) That at about 0225h/16th Mar., the Chief Mate reported that engine room temperature drop to about 22 Degree Celsius as per thermometer reading nearby boiler. On this time fire was observed to climb through the funnel pipe (Chimney) and boundary cooling applied. Water spray spreaded all over the funnel and later inside the funnel. 
7) That at about 0315h/16th Mar., the fire in the funnel was restricted and the master called NOS office for update. 
8) That at about 0330h/16th Mar., doubled checked and confirmed fire completely out. Main engine, auxiliary & electrical motors were gotten wet. Boiler Automation Panel burned and some nearby electrical boards were wet. 
9) That at the time when incident happened at 0130h/16th Mar., the captioned vessel’s position was at Lat. 33-32.0N & Lon. 123-35.9E.

Location: FRENTE A LA CALETA DE ACAPULCO - ZORRITOS
SummaryOfEvents: Día 14 marzo, siendo las 21:10 horas, la señora xxx, propietaria de la embarcación pesquera JOSE MERCEDES, informó que su embarcación no arribó a Puerto en la fecha prevista, dicha embarcación zarpó el día 12 marzo a 17:00 horas de la Caleta Acapulco, con DOS (02) tripulantes a bordo, hacia zona de pesca a 2 millas frente citada Caleta, CAPIZORI, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, el día 15 marzo a 04:30 horas, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa PACASMAYO, hacia área de búsqueda, retornando con resultados negativos, el día 15 marzo a 06:00 horas la mencionada embarcación arribó por sus propios medios a la Caleta de Acapulco.

Location: A 53 MILLAS FRENTE AL PUERTO DE ILO
SummaryOfEvents: Día 13 abril, siendo las 15:00 horas se recibió señal de activación de radiobaliza en el Sistema COSPAS SARSAT, perteneciente a la embarcación pesquera CELESTE, por lo que se efectúo comunicación con el representante de la referida embarcación, quién informó que la embarcación se encontraba al garete con fallas mecánicas, se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa RIO ZAÑA, el día 14 abril, siendo las 01:50 horas la Patrullera Marítima, ubicó a la embarcación pesquera CELESTE en la posición Lat. 18º 19’ S y Long. 071º 49’ W con CINCO (05) tripulantes a bordo, los mismos que fueron rescatados en buen estado de salud, asimismo, la embarcación se encontraba con la popa hundida y la sala de máquinas totalmente inundada, por lo que no fue posible su remolque, siendo las 08:20 horas del mismo día, la Patrullera Marítima RIO ZAÑA arribó al Puerto de Ilo con la tripulación rescatada.

The M/V AN PHAT 18 took water, developed 20 degree list and sank in the Gulf of Tonkin, 45 miles North of Hue, Viet Nam at 0730 Hours on 13 March 2010 in heavy weather. The M/V PHU GIA 36 proceeded to assist and rescued all 15 crew. No injuries reported.

On 13 March 2010, whilst moored off Zanzibar, Tanzania, the engine room of the passenger ship SERENGETI caught fire.  The blaze spread to all areas of the ship and was completely burnt out. The fire is reported to have started during welding operations.  All 15 crew members were rescued with no injuries reported.

Día 11 marzo, siendo las 19:15 horas la embarcación pesquera VIRGENCITA DE CHAPI, sufrió varadura en la zona de playa meca, Caleta Morro Sama, con SEIS (06) tripulante a bordo. Luego de realizar la recuperación de boliche y remolque de la embarcación, se tuvo el saldo de un tripulante desaparecido, CAPILO, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía, desde el día 12 al 18 marzo se efectuó búsqueda con resultados negativos, Posteriormente el dia 22 marzo a 13:40 horas los perscadores de la zona La Poza - playa Meca, encontraron el cuerpo sin vida del tripulante desaparecido.

The F/V ARGENOVA XI took water in engine room and sank 90 miles Northeast of Mar del Plata, Argentina at 0130 Hours on 11 March 2010. All 8 crew members abandoned the vessel to liferafts and were later rescued by F/V TESON. No injuries were reported.

The passenger ship "ILIDA" caught fire whilst moored at Kerkyra, Greece on 10/03/2010. It was subsequently broken up in Corfu, Greece. The blaze was extinguished with assistance from local fire services. No injuries were reported. The vessel sustained serious damage to bridge and accomodation.

Día 10 marzo, siendo las 09:10 horas la señora Selene CORAL Peña, propietaria de la embarcación pesquera SHALON, informó que su embarcación no arribó en la fecha prevista, dicha embarcación zarpó del Puerto de Talara con destino a zona de pesca el día 08 marzo, con CUATRO (04) tripulantes a bordo, CAPILARA, activó RCC, emitió Aviso de Capitanía. Siendo las 10:45 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CHORRILLOS, fin efectuar búsqueda retornando con resultados negativos, el día 11 marzo, siendo las 00:20 horas arribó la citada embarcación por sus propios medios al Puerto de Talara.

Dia 10 marzo, siendo las 02:00 horas, la embarcación pesquera JUAN DANIEL, con SIETE (07) tripulantes a bordo, sufrió varadura en la zona de roquerio playa meca, entre los distritos de Morro Sama y Ite, se efectuó coordinaciones con embarcaciones de la zona a fin de prestar auxilio, siendo rescatados la totalidad de los tripulantes, posteriormente la embarcación fue remolcada hacia la Caleta Morro Sama.

THE SHIP ARRIVED IN TARANTO ON FEBRUARY 27, 2010; AFTER DISCHARGING SHE LEAVED THE BERTH AT 00.15 ON MARCH 3, 2010 AND WENT TO ANCHORAGE AREA, WAITING FOR ORDERS, IN POSITION 40° 27’ 59.8 N - 016° 58’ 22.2 E. THIS POSITION IS ABOUT 0.9 N.M. OFF SHORE, IN FRONT OF CASTELLANETA MARINA LOCATION. 
SEVEN LENGTH WERE DROPPED; ALLOWANCE UNDER KEEL WAS ABOUT 25 MTRS.
THE SHIP STAYED AT ANCHOR FOR SEVERAL DAYS, UNTIL MARCH 10, 2010. 
DURING THIS PERIOD, WEATHER WAS FINE AND ALL, ONBOARD, WAS EFFICIENT AND SAFE. 
ON MARCH 9, 2010, SEA BULLETIN ISSUED BY ATHENS MARINE METEOROLOGICAL CENTRE, VALID FROM 092200 UTC UP TO 101000 UTC, NOTICED A GALE WARNING, AS FOLLOWS : 
“NORTH IONIO EAST OF19.30 WITH SOUTHEAST NEAR GALE 7 TLOCALLY GALE 8  AND FROM 100200 UTC GALE 8 LOCALLY GALE 9” ;
ALSO IT WAS NOTICED A STORM WARNING, VALID FROM 100400 UTC UP TO 101600 UTC, AS FOLLOWS:
“SOUTH ADRIATIC AND BOOT - NORTH IONIO AND SOUTH IONIO WITH SOUTHEAST GALE 8 LOCALLY STRONG GALE 9”.
BASED ON THESE INFORMATIONS, IN THE LAST HOURS OF MARCH 9,2010, THE DAY OF CASUALTY, WEATHER CONDITIONS IN TARANTO ROAD WERE EXPECTED TO GET WORST.
INDEED, DURING 3RD OFFICER WATCH WIND FORCE GOT INCREASED AND WEATHER CONDITIONS PROGRESSIVELY DETERIORATED.
AT MIDNIGHT, 3RD OFFICER REPORTED WIND FORCE 7/8 BEAUFORT SCALE. 
AT 0050, MARCH 10, 2010, 2ND OFFICER REPORTED WIND FORCE STILL INCREASING TO 8/9, WITH HEAVY ROLLING AND SWELL. 
AT 00.54, 2ND OFFICER REPORTED THE SHIP STARTED TO DRIFT.
AS SOON AS HE RELIZED IT, HE CALLED THE CAPTAIN AND ADIVSED ENGINE ROOM TO “STAND BY”. 
NEARLY IN THE MEANTIME, AT 00.56 TARANTO COAST GUARD CALLED M/V. BURGAS INFORMING ABOUT THE S DRIFT. THE SHIP WAS MOVING AT 2,5 KNTS SPEED TOWARDS SHORE. 
ENGINE WAS READY AT 01.09 AND CAPTAIN IMMEDIATELY STARTED TO MANOUVRE WITH ENGINE, BOW THRUST AND RUDDER, IN ORDER TO KEEP THE VESSEL CLEAR FROM SHORE AND AVOID GROUNDING. BOATSWAIN AND TWO CREWMEN WERE ORDERED TO GO TO HEAVING THE ANCHOR.
ENGINE WAS PUT “FULL  ASTERN”. 
AT 01.10 TARANTO COAST GUARD CALLLED M/V. BURGAS ASKING WHETHER CAPTAIN NEEDED TUG ASSISTANCE: THE ANSWER WAS NEGATIVE, BUT JUST A FEW MINUTES AFTER, AT 01.15, CAPTAIN HIMSELF RECALLED COAST GUARD ASKING FOR IMMEDIATE TUG INTERVENTION.
ANYWAY, IT WAS TOO LATE: AT 01.30, IN DESPITE OF ANY ATTEMPT, THE VESSEL GROUNDED IN POSITION 40° 28,521’N - 016° 57,829’ E. 
AT 09.55, MARCH 10, 2010, A TUG REACHED THE POSITION OF GROUNDIG, BUT COULD NOT GIVE ANY ASSISTANCE BECAUSE OF BAD WEAHTER.    
AT 16.20, MARCH 1O, 2010, THE SHIP WAS GROUNDED ON STARBOARD SIDE, PARALLEL TO THE COAST LINE. 
FROM 01.09 IN THE MORNING UP TO 16.20 IN THE AFTERNOON, CAPTAIN M/V. BURGAS AND HIS CREW TRIED TO REFLOAT THE VESSEL, WITHOUT SUCCESS. 
AT 16.20 OPERATIONS WERE SUSPENDED IN ORDER TO AVOID ANY POSSIBLE DAMAGE TO ENGINE COOLING CONNECTIONS.
UNGROUNDING OPERATIONS ENDED ON APRIL, 25, 2010.

The vessel was at anchor and was awiting for pilotage to proceed to the port. At about 16.15 hrs the vessel commenced preparation for pilotage and berthing and started M.E. At about 16.45 hrs load of the M.E. decreased, arrow indicating position of the propeller blades fell to position "full astern" and stopped. CPP alarm came out and at 17.05 hrs the M.E. was stopped. At about 19.10 hrs it was established that the propeller is not rotating, the vessel can not proceed without assistance. The vessel was towed to the homeport by tug. Here it became clear that the proppeller shaft in the stern tube is broken.

ShipsInvolved: CMA CGM DEBUSSY (IMO 9235907), HACI FATMA SARI (IMO 7600079), VADENI (IMO 7623423)
SOLASStatus: CMA CGM DEBUSSY: SOLAS, HACI FATMA SARI: Unknown/unspecified, VADENI: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The CMA CGM Debussy was manoeuvring off her berth with three tugs to assist. Whebn the vessel turned beam onto the wind she was quickly set down onto the Haci Fatma Sari which was alongside an adjacent berth and also made contact with the tug Vadeni which was pinned between the CMA CGM Debussy and the quayside close aster of the Haci Fatma Sari. The CMA CGM Debussy suffered material damage as a result of the contact and once the vessels had seperated she was made fast to an adjacent berth to facilitate temporary repairs to enable her to resume service.

Location: Ionian Sea, off Nisida Pontikos Island, Greece
SummaryOfEvents: On 7 March 2010, at 2115 hrs, under heavy weather conditions, the cargo ship SEA OMAR stranded in the Ionian Sea, off Nisida Pontikos Island, Greece.  No injuries or pollution were reported.  Messolonghi Port Authority ship attended to the scene and on 9 March 2010, at 1630 hrs, the cargo ship was refloated with assistance from Tug AMAZON, having sustained damage to the keel.  The ship proceeded to Platygiali, Greece for cargo discharge and inspection.  On 16 December 2010, the ship was broken up at Aliaga, Turkey.

At approximately 09.15 on 7 March 2010, the crew onboard the Netherlands registered vessel Cormorant commenced rigging the sheerleg crane in preparation for a salvage operation the following day.  At 09.56, the vesse'ls commercial agent boarded the vessel and the rigging operation was paused whilst the master dealt with ship's business. The operation re-commenced at, or shortly after 09.58, with the agent still onboard.
At 10.01, a loud bang was heard forward, followed by an observation of the port forward preventer wire and deck securing fitting being catapulted into the air.  Immediately the crane and its supporting structure started to fall backwards.  There were two crew stationed on the deck, and two in the wheelhouse with the agent.  All took cover as the 85 tonne sheerleg crane fell backwards onto the deck.  No one was injured, but the crane, its supporting frames, the loose gear, and the wheelhouse suffered substantial damage.

The tanker "IVY QUEEN" took water and sank in the Gulf of Oman, off Khorfakkan at 2020 hours on 06/03/2010. All 12 crew members were rescued from a liferaft by M/V "SEA KING" and taken to Khorfakkan. No injuries were reported.

InitialEvent: Sudden release of Steam under pressure burning 4th Engineer
SummaryOfEvents:
On the 4th March 2010 the passenger ship BOUDICCA was berthed alongside in the Port of Malaga, Spain.
While in the Port of Malaga, the 4th engineer spotted a small leak through the inspection glass fitted on the cascade tank located in pump room no. 3. 
The 4th engineer decided to repair the small leak without consulting a senior officer.
Work started, but all of a sudden steam under pressure was released from the top inspection hatch burning the 4th engineer and two oilers as well as the 1st engineer who was leaving the compartment at that time.

SOLASStatus: APL SEATTLE: SOLAS, EVER URANUS: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On March 3, 2010 at approximately 0230LT, the  APL SEATTLE  , while in ballast condition, was involved in a collision while transiting in the East China Sea towards Shanghai, China . The Panamanian container vessel, EVER URANUS, with no prior indication (sight, sound) collided with the bow of the APL SEATTLE. There were no injuries to the crew or incident of pollution reported. Both vessels were surveyed and the APL SEATTLE sustained damage to the shell plate, bulwark, main deck, hawse pipe, and starboard anchor. The vessel was determined fit to proceed to port where it was inspected and began repairs on the damages. The APL SEATTLE was detained by the MSA Zoushan on account of the PSC’s investigation of the collision; however the vessel was subsequently released.

On 3 March 2010, the cruise ship LOUIS MAJESTY was hit by three 'abnormally high' waves up to 26-feet (8 metres) high near the French Mediterranean port of Marseille.  The waves broke glass windshields in the forward section and killed two passengers.  The ship was sailing from Barcelona to the Italian city of Genoa with nearly 2,000 people on board.  The ship had asked permission to make an emergency docking in Barcelona after it was hit by the wave.

Location: FRENTE ISLA SAN MARTIN - VEGUETA - PUERTO HUACHO
SummaryOfEvents: Día 02 marzo, siendo las 2220 horas se tomó conocimiento sobre la varadura de la chalana a remos BRISELL con número de registro HO-311, con DOS (02) tripulantes a bordo, frente a la caleta Vegueta, siendo las 22:45 horas se dispuso el zarpe de la Patrullera de Costa CANCAS, rescatando con vida al señor Victor COLLANTES Medina (41), luego se efectuó la búsqueda del tripulante Denys MEDINA Canales, con resultados negativos, CAPIACHO, emitió Aviso Capitanía correspondiente, se activó RCC y desde el día 03 al 10 marzo, se efectuó búsqueda a bordo de la Patrullera de Costa CANCAS, con resultados negativos, actualmente el cuerpo del citado tripulante se encuentra en la condicion de desaparecido en la mar.

InitialEvent: Fatality in enclosed cargo oil tank
SummaryOfEvents: 4 crewmembers entered cargo oil tank without permit for entry into enclosed space. 2 crewmembers fainted due to toxic gas. During rescue operations by crew using SCBA and lifting one of the crewmember, the stretcher slipped from a height of 10 metres causing fatal injuries resulting in death
M.V. JINDAL MANJULA was at anchor. M.V. EVNIA, while awaiting pilot under estimated the strength of thge current and collided with M.V. JINDAL MANJULA

On 1 Marsh 2010, the deckhand on board the UK registered workboat Llanddwyn Island, was struck by a towing hawser when it parted. He died at the scene. 

The workboat was moving a dredger in Roscoff, France and the deckhand had moved into the “snap-back zone” of the hawser while it was under tension. The failed element was a chain connected to the stern of the dredger. The chain had not been provided by the ship’s owner and its use in the hawser was not in accordance with best practise. There were not written procedures for towing and pushing operations provided on board, and the ship’s risk assessments had not been reviewed since 2006.

The bulk carrier "JEBEL-E-RAHMAT" stranded off Indonesia in March 2010. The damaged were beyond economical repair and arrived at Chittagong, Bangladesh on 06/04/2010 for breaking up. No injuries or pollution were reported. The extent of damage were unknown, refloated and sold for breaking up.

On 28 February 2010, the ship, TOBAGO caught fire whilst moored at Kirkenes, Norway.  All 6 crew members were rescued and the captain sustained minor injuries.  Local fire services proceeded to assist, however the ship developed list due to the ingress of water from the firefighting operations.  The ship was towed to safe anchorage in Bokfjorden.  Coastguard ships BETA and HARSTAD also assisted with the firefighting operation.  On 2 March 2010, the blaze was brought under control.  The interior of the ship was completely destroyed.  Reports indicate that the cause of the fire was due to an electrical fault.  In September 2010, the ship was towed to Stokksund, Norway where it was broken up, having been reported as being damaged beyond economical repair.
At 1855, FEB. 27TH 2010, MV “DONG HAI” collided with fishing boat “Zheshenyu 01225” off Changjiangkou area, Shanghai, China, caused the fishing boat capsized and all her 8crews went missing.

Location: At the Asmar shipyard, Talcahuano, Chile
SummaryOfEvents: The bulk carrier "LAUREL" stranded on top of drydock after being struck by a tsunami at the Asmar shipyard, Talcahuano, Chile on 27/02/2010. The carrier took water in the engine room and steering compartment.  Temporary repairs were effected.  On 16/05/2010 the carrier was dewatered and refloated with assistance.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

VESSEL ARRIVED HANKO FREEPORT AND COMMENCED BERTHING. PORT OF HANKO WAS FULL OF ICE. MASTER TRYIED TO BERTH VESSEL USING ENGINE AND ROPES. STERAN ROPE WAS PARTED AND HIT HIS HEAD A/B WHO WAS ON AFT STATION

On February 26th 2010 the Italian-flagged cruise ship COSTA EUROPA, with 1,473 passengers on board, hit a pier in the Egyptian resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh. As a result, three sailors were killed and four tourists injured. Strong winds may have been a factor.

Location: Niger Dock Jetty, Snake Island, Lagos, Nigeria
SummaryOfEvents: A parked road oil tanker laden with 33,000 liters of Automotive Gas Oil (AGO) rolled into the waters at Niger Dock Jetty, Snake Island, Lagos, Nigeria on 25th February, 2010, spilling the AGO into the water. The tanker rolled into the sea while waiting to discharge the AGO into a waiting barge. Consequently, all the AGO was spilled into the water. The AGO discharged on water later evaporated thereby not needing cleanup. The vehicular tanker was pulled out within 24hrs of the incident.

Location: Port of Hamburg, junction river Rethe to Koelbrand
SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd February 2010, as the MV PETERSBURG was  departing one dock facility and being phased into a main port waterway at Hamburg, she ran into the outer starboard shell plating of the passing chemical tanker Oak Galaxy, which had just crossed the junction and was already traversing the main waterway. Both vessels sustained minor damage, but then, due to a temporary engine breakdown the Master, who was the sole crew member on the bridge of the PETERSBURG, was unable to gain propulsion control and a collision ensued. As he had earlier failed to check on the proper functioning of the VHF during a pre-departure bridge check he was also unable to communicate with the surrounding traffic in a timely way.

The chemical tanker Vingatank arrived at Brofjorden on the Swedish west coast after a ballast trip from Kristiansand in south Norway. It was very cold with a temperature of 10ºC below zero.
The 2:nd officer checked the P/V valves after arrival and the loading of vacuum gasoil started at 20.05 on the 22:nd of February.
Just before midnight a high pressure alarm sounded from tank no. 2 port. The OOW shifted over the loading to tanks no. 3 starboard and port. He reset the alarm and ordered the AB to check the P/V valve. The AB saw fumes coming out of the valve which made the OOW think that it was OK to commence loading. The pressure in no. 2 port tank was normal when the loading of the tank started after the first alarm.
After a while there was a second high pressure alarm from tank no. 2 port. Also at this time the AB saw fumes coming out of the P/V valve. The OOW then assumed that the sensor did not work properly.
At 00.35 just a few minutes after the second alarm there was an explosion in no. 2 port tank.
At the shipyard one discovered an ice plug in the ventilation pipe. The ice plug did not choke up the pipe completely so it was obvious that some fumes passed the ice and could be seen by the AB when he checked the P/V valve.

InitialEvent: INSPECTION OF PORT RECEPTION FACILITIES ON AN ITALIAN VESSEL MV JOLLY ZAFFIRO
SummaryOfEvents: On 22nd February 2010 three officials from the Nigerian Maritime Administration and Safety Agency boarded the JOLLY ZAFFIRO for inspection in order to ensure compliance of the usage of Port Reception Facilities requirement and proper disposal of ship waste. Two of the officials were allowed to proceed to the garbage station by the Chief Engineer. On their way to the station, a  dog was released from its cage, which chased away the officers. In an attempt to escape attack from the dog, one Nigerian official fell over and sustained multiple fractures. He was taken to the Agency's SAR Clinic. Consequently the vessel was detained and subjected to inspections, and fined $10,000.00. The vessel Owner/Operator co-operated and signed an undertaking with the Agency.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On February 22, 2010 at approximately 0845LT, the Liberian Flag container vessel, FRISIA SPREEwas involved in a collision while transiting the Qiongzhou Strait in the vicinity of Precautionary Area No.2  (Lat: 20, 11.8 N; Long: 110, 13.9 E). While in the Strait, vessel was advised by Qiongzhou VTS on VHF channel to avoid two other vessels in the vicinity and FRISIA SPREE altered its course accordingly. While passing the two vessels, the vessel XU YUN 205 suddenly altered its course, subsequently colliding with the port quarter of the FRISIA SPREE.  There were no injuries or pollution reported and minimal damage to the vessel was sustained. The vessel was inspected and determined fit to proceed and was instructed by the Qiongzhou VTS to proceed to Haikou Anchorage for Investigations.

The container ship ANGELN took water, developed list to starboard, capsized and sank 2.5 miles SouthWest of Vieux Port, Saint Lucia at 22.00 H on 21 February 2010. All 12 crew were rescued. The vessel was lying on starboard side almost completely submerged. No pollution reported. 230 tons of bunkers were removed by TITAN SALVAGE.

On 21 February 2010, the cargo ship VEGA II took water in the engine room at kilometre 77 in the River Danube near Reni, Ukraine in freezing conditions.  The local emergency services proceeded to assit.  on 3 February 2010, water was pumped.  It is reported that the failure of kingston valves due to the freezing temperatures caused the water ingress.  The ship had been laid up unmanned since 2008.  In December 2010, the ship was broken up in Kerch, Ukraine

On 21 February 2010, under freezing conditions, the cargo ship, RUZHANY took water in the engine room at kilometre 77 in the River Danube, near Reni, Ukraine.  Local emergency services proceeded to assit.  Water was pumped out by 25 February 2010.  The cause of the water ingress was failure of kingston valves, due to the freezing temperatures.  The ship had been laid up unmanned since 2008.  The ship was subsequently sold for breaking up.

Location: In the river Danube near Reni, Ukraine
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo ship "KAPITAN GRINENKO" took water in engine room and developed starboard list at kilometre 77 in the river Danube near Reni, Ukraine on 21/02/2010 in freezing conditions. It was subsequently broken up at Midia, Romania in January 2011. The water was pumped out by 03/03/2010. The cause of water ingress was the failure of kingston valves due to freezing temperatures. The vessel had been laid up unmanned since 2008.

Location: At Crow Rock, off Linney Head, Wales
SummaryOfEvents: At 17 :25 hours on 20 February  2010, the UK-registered crabber Kerloch (J235) was returning to port when she ran aground on Crow Rock, off the Pembrokeshire coast. The ship began to sink rapidly and all four crew donned their lifejackets, then deployed and got into liferaft. The crew were recovered from their liferaft by another fishing ship and subsequently transferred to the Angle ALB and then ashore. There were no injuries and no pollution.

InitialEvent: Serious injury to mooring crew member
SummaryOfEvents: While securing the vessel alongside the berth, a mooring line parted and sliced off the lower part of the mooring crew member's foot.

El 20 de Febrero de 2.010, a las 03:26 cuando navegaba sin dificultad el Canal Sarmiento de Sur a Norte, a la cuadra del Faro Escala Alta y realizaba la caída a babor para tomar el nuevo rumbo que lo dejaría enfilado para cruzar la Angostura Guía, la nave contrariamente a lo planificado por el capitán, su equipo de puente y el práctico de canales que tenía el control del puente en ese momento, se salió del track y tocó fondo en la ribera este del Canal, en el sector Norte de Punta Passage.
Su capitán tenía nacionalidad Ucraniana y la dotación de oficiales y tripulantes estaba compuesta principalmente por Rusos y Ucranianos. Los dos prácticos de canales embarcados eran de nacionalidad chilena.
La travesía  por los canales interiores chilenos tenía por destino el Puerto de Puerto Montt, lugar donde descargaría las 14.300 toneladas de fertilizante a granel, consistentes en  Nitrato Amónico Cálcico (CAN 27 la cual no es considerada carga peligrosa y cuyo fabricante era FERIBERIA S. A. Sagunto España.
Producto del accidente, no se registraron lesiones a personas, ni contaminación al medio ambiente marino y los daños se circunscribieron a  la obra viva, con abolladuras y fracturas de casco, comprometiendo la integridad de 4 estanques de lastre, al quedar comunicados con el mar. 
La estabilidad de la nave no fué afectada gravemente, registrando escora de hasta 10°, pero en consideración a la magnitud de los daños, debió ser descargada y posterior a ser descargada en Puerto Montt, sometida a reparaciones en dique.

Le 20 février 2010 en début d’après midi, le fileyeur La Presqu’il se trouve à
16.milles dans l’Est de Saint-Vaast-La-Hougue, son port d’attache. Après avoir remonté 8.tessures1 de filets, il fait route vers ce port à la vitesse de 8,5 noeuds. Il y a six hommes d’équipage à bord.
Les conditions météo sont bonnes : vent d’Ouest-Sud-Ouest 15 noeuds, mer 2,
visibilité 8 milles. C’est la fin du flot et le coefficient de marée est de 66. Le courant porte au 112° à 1,2 noeud. La température de l’eau de mer est de 7°C.
Le patron est à la barre et les matelots sont occupés à nettoyer et à ranger la dernière tessure de filets. Cette opération est en voie d’achèvement lorsque le matelot, chargé du rangement des filets dans le parc situé à l’arrière, chute à la mer. Personne à bord n’a vu l’accident se produire et ce n’est qu’au bout de plusieurs minutes, lorsque le patron cherche à contacter ce matelot, que l’alerte est donnée à bord.
Le patron prévient le CROSS Jobourg et manoeuvre immédiatement pour faire route inverse. Quinze minutes plus tard, l’équipage de LA PRESQU’ILE aperçoit le marin inanimé en surface. L’homme disparaît, malgré les efforts pour l’agripper.
Les recherches coordonnées par le CROSS Jobourg ne permettent pas de retrouver la victime.

InitialEvent: Fall from height of a shore worker in a cargo tank
SummaryOfEvents:
At 22:58 hours on 19 February 2010, a German, shore worker was fatally injured on board the oil/chemical tanker Bro Arthur.

Bro Arthur had part-discharged at Rotterdam before arriving in Hamburg to offload her remaining crude palm oil cargo. A team of three cargo “sweepers” had been arranged under the operational direction of a supercargo. While existing N° 2 cargo tank on completion of the “sweeping” operation, one of the “sweepers” fell to the bottom of the tank.

La M/N "TUPUNGATO" navegando de Weste a Este el Canal Darwin, cargado con 30.038 toneladas de piedra caliza, tocó fondo con un bajo a la cuadra de Islotes Locos. Al momento de la varada el equipo de puente  no se percató que la nave estaba más a babor del track planeado y que se acercaba peligrosamente a un bajo fondo,  el cual no había sido debidamente destacado en la carta náutica como peligroso, durante la planeación del viaje.
Las condiciones de mar, viento y visibilidad en el área eran buenas.

Location: Ionian Sea, 85 miles SW of Zakynthos, Greece
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 February 2010, at 1730 hrs, the cargo ship YAVUZ SULTAN SELIM sustained mechanical problems in the Ionian Sea, 85 miles SW of Zakynthos, Greece.  The ship sustained a broken crankshaft and was assisted by a tug, which towed the ship to Augusta, Sicily, Italy for inspection.  She was later broken up at Aliaga, Turkey.

Location: 300 Miles SSE off Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 February 2010, at approximately 14:23 hrs, the sail training yacht Concordia was knocked down and capsized after encountering a squall off the coast of Brazil. All 64 crew, faculty, and students abandoned the ship into liferafts. They were rescued 2 days later by  2 merchant ship and taken to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. One crew member suffered broken bones.

After departure from Sct. Petersburg NC NORDIC was following guidance from Sct. Petersburg Traffic Control. Sct. Petersburg Traffic Control kept outgoing and ingoing traffic on opposite courses.
The visibility was poor and the navigation took place in thick ice. When an ingoing icebreaker was abeam NC NORDIC wanted to turn to and follow the channel in the ice made by the icebreaker. On the radar NC NORDIC observed two targets on the port side. Actually there were three, but two of the target seemed like one target on the radar. Having visually observed two ships passing SC NORDIC turned port and collided with the third ship MAGDALENA that were following the two other ships.

On 16th February 2010 the RIVER EMBLEY was at Gladstone anchorage, Queensland, when an explosion took place in the engine room. The engine room was evacuated and all power to the engine room equipment and lighting was shut down. There was considerable oil mist in the engine room. Three crewmen were medivaced to hospital due to smoke inhalation. The incident is believed to have been the result of pressure build up in a compressor.

SOLASStatus: FICHA SEGUNDO: Unknown/unspecified, FICHA SEGUNDO: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel "FICHA SEGUNDO" took water in hold, capsized and sank in the bay of Buscay, 23 miles north of Burela, Spain at 1536 Hours on 15/02/2010 in heavy weather. 7 crew members were rescued by F/V "MARPA II" and 1 crew member body was recovered. 2 crew members were subsequently airlifted to hospital in Burela with hypothermia symptoms.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 06:23 hours on February 15, 2010, ESTEBROKER, a Liberian container ship, was maneuvering to dock at the Port of Manzanillo, Mexico. The pilot adjusted the engine speed to “Dead Slow Astern” but with no response. The pilot again tried to put the lever on stop, however, the engine still did not respond and the vessel continued towards the pier. The pilot ordered the crew to drop the starboard anchor. The anchor held still however, the vessel had contacted the pier causing notable damage to the starboard bow and the stem (the forward most part). There were no injuries or any incidents of pollution.

The general cargo ship "HOLLGAN STAR" dragged anchor and stranded on Takwa Bay beach, Lagos, Nigeria on 14/02/2010 in heavy weather. The wreck was abandoned in SITU. No injuries or pollution were reported.
The tanker "MORLAP TRADER" dragged anchor and stranded on Takwa bay beach, Lagos, Nigeria on 14/02/2010 in heavy weather. The wreck was abandoned in SITU. No injuries or pollution were reported.

The tanker "F K BADMUS" dragged anchor and stranded on Takwa bay beach, Lagos, Nigeria on 14/02/2010 in heavy weather. The wreck was abandoned in situ. No injuries or pollution were reported. The salvage attempts was abandoned and the engine room flooded. The wreck subsequently was looted by local vandals.
The tanker "ELLA L" dragged anchor and stranded on Takwa bay beach, Lagos, Nigeria on 14/02/2010 in heavy weather. The wreck was abandoned in situ. No injuries or pollution were reported.

Location: 11 NM SW of Fastnet Rock, Ireland
SummaryOfEvents:
The Irish Fishing Vessel Janireh was engaged in fishing operations approximately 11 nautical miles South West of Fastnet Rock.

At about 01.45 hours on the 13th of February 2010 a crewmember fell from the vessel into the water. Efforts by the vessel to recover the man were unsuccessful.

In spite of an extensive air and sea search in the area the remains of the missing crewman have not been recovered  to date.

InitialEvent: Crew man overboard and subsequent missing
SummaryOfEvents:
Le chalutier pêche arrière Bara’Mann quitte le port du Guilvinec dans la matinée du 4 février 2010 pour une nouvelle marée au chalut de fond d’une quinzaine de jours en zone VIIh CIEM - Shamrock.
Les conditions météorologiques sur zone sont mauvaises. Le vent d’ENE est d’environ 25/30 noeuds, la mer est agitée.
Le 11 février, comme tous les jours, il est prévu 5 traits de chalut. En raison d’une pêche relativement médiocre, alors que le navire se trouve à 48 milles dans le 290° de Ouessant, le patron décide de changer de secteur de pêche.
Les chaluts sont à poste sur les enrouleurs, ne restent que les panneaux, en pendant à l’extérieur des hiloires de pavois, à positionner et à saisir. Pour cette opération, le Bara’Mann est en avant lente. Les captures du dernier trait de chalut sont dans les parcs prévus à cet effet
sur le pont arrière, en attente d’être traitées.
Deux marins sont affairés au panneau tribord et deux autres à celui de bâbord.
L’opération nécessite de passer un câble dans le réa d’une poulie située en avant de la chape
du débordeur (boucle d’oreille). Cette manœuvre est rendue d’autant plus délicate que le navire roule dans ces conditions de mer difficiles.
Le matelot chargé du panneau tribord grimpe sur une serre de renfort entre deux jambettes de pavois au-dessus du sabord de décharge et sur le panneau afin de passer le câble par la poulie. Durant cette opération, alors qu’aucun membre d’équipage ne porte de VFI, il chute à la mer. Alerté par l’équipage, le patron engage une manœuvre afin de tenter de récupérer le matelot à la mer. Un des marins se jette à l’eau pour le secourir. Les tentatives de récupération des deux hommes à la mer ne permettent pas de les ramener à bord. Epuisés par leurs efforts et pris par le froid, les deux marins partent à la dérive.
D’important moyens maritimes et aériens sont mis en œuvre, coordonnés par le CROSS Corsen. Les recherches cessent le 12 février 2010 en fin de matinée. Les deux hommes ne seront pas retrouvés.

On 11 February 2010, the passenger ship, TRACARRIER sank whilst moored at Perama Anchorage, Greece.  No injuries or pollution were reported.  Anti-pollution booms were deployed as a precaution.  The ship has been laid up unmanned since 2004.

On 10 February 2010 at 4:36 am local time, the chemical tanker SICHEM OSPREY, on her way from Panama to Ulsan (South Korea) stranded at more than 16 knots on the northeasterly part of Clipperton Island, although an OOW and a lookout AB were on the bridge and no damage was reported prior to the accident. A 100 metre fore part of the ship had been grounded. No pollution had been observed.
A major salvage plan had been rapidly set out by the French authorities.
After less than 48 hours, a salvage agreement was signed between the owner and the Svitzer Salvage company.
After number of attempts, and two cargo lightening operations done by pumping to an alongside ship, SICHEM OSPREY had been refloated on 6 March 2010, with the help of 2 tugs.

The general cargo ship "MERSIN D" stranded and subsequently sank in the Sea of Marmara, 8 miles northeast of Bandirma, Turkey at 1804 hours on 09/02/2010. No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship sustained damage to propeller and ballast tanks and took water in No. 1 hold. All 10 crew members were rescued by coastguard vessel "KEGM-8". It subsequently listed and sank at 1630 hours on 14/02/2010. The wreck was lying on the port side almost completely submerged and anti-pollution measures were deployed.
